PROCTEXT.PARA: COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
PARLIAMENTARY DEBATES
SENATE
Hansard
FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY-SIXTH PARLIAMENT
(FOURTH PERIOD)
The Senate, on 21 June 1991, adjourned to 13 August 1991, unless the President fixed an earlier day of meeting.
Pursuant to the Resolution of the Senate passed on 21 June 1991, the Senate met on Tuesday, 13 August 1991, at 10 a.m.
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the current industrial dispute affecting the Parliament and advise that the matter is before Commissioner Smith of the Industrial Relations Commission in Melbourne. I am advised that his decision will be handed down today at 2.30 p.m. When the decision is known and the Speaker and I have had a chance to discuss this decision with the Joint House Department, I will make a full statement to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

Mr President, whilst I appreciate what you have said and that hopefully later today you will be able to give to the Senate a full explanation as to what is occurring, I nevertheless remind you, with respect, of your responsibility as a Presiding Officer to ensure the proper functioning of the Senate. Today and before today, it seems, there has been disruption of the business of the Senate, in particular in regard to such aspects as the delivery of mail. I understand that constituents' mail is still not getting through in full to senators. Other services are clearly being disrupted. Senators this morning have not had the delivery of newspapers and other normal services that are necessary for the proper functioning of their responsibilities. The work of senators has clearly been disrupted and they have been questioned in matters relating to transport. There is still a question as to whether all senators are actually here today.

Whilst my colleagues and I will be interested to hear your full and complete statement later in the day, I would appreciate it if you would at this stage advise the Senate as to what actions you have been taking up to now to ensure that these disruptions are minimised or avoided, and give us an explanation at the moment as to the extent of the disruptions taking place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the best course would be, so as not to inflame an industrial relations situation any further, for me to make a full statement this afternoon when I get the result of the Commissioner's decision.

—With respect, Mr President, there may be an industrial action-and apparently there is. You are seeking a verdict of the Industrial Relations Commission as to how that should be handled from now, but that does not answer the questions about the disruption that has occurred today. I accept that it goes beyond simply your responsibilities, in that there is now a question as to whether the police carried out their functions and responsibilities correctly this morning in their apparent protection of this picket line. There is a question of the responsibility of Comcar drivers-I would say a responsibility to be prepared to pick up senators and take them to work, not to drop them halfway between their place of overnight abode and the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot understand how the giving of a factual explanation as to what the situation is to date can be said to be inflaming industrial action. Mr President, I have asked you what is the position to date and what action you have taken, as President of the Senate, to try to minimise the damage this situation has caused to the proper functioning of this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the points made by the Leader of the Opposition, I will look to bring down a statement earlier than 2.30 p.m., which is what I originally promised to do. I am not in a position to answer all of the questions that Senator Hill has raised at this stage. Is that satisfactory, Senator Hill?
—No.
—Do you want an answer later this morning on how you get your mail?
—No.
—Well, I am not in a position to make that statement now, I am sorry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my understanding that other unions have become involved and have instructed members of other unions to support the ban. That would seem to me to be a secondary boycott. Today, the traffic was being turned back simply by a group of self-appointed people who had no authority whatsoever to disrupt traffic. There seemed to be no evidence that the Presiding Officers had made any attempt whatsoever to involve the Federal Police in this unlawful blockade.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that there has been an acquiescing in the action that has been taken, seemingly in the hope that the whole thing might just go away. We would appreciate it, Mr President, if you would tell us now, this morning, what action has been taken; why the police were not involved; why secondary boycotts have, apparently, been allowed to be put in place; and just what sort of action you contemplate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak briefly to the motion. I think it is important that the Senate and the public note the inherent contradiction in the arguments that are now being advanced by Opposition senators. They support the process of privatisation, but then seem to be surprised by the consequences of it. We are simply living with the inevitable consequences of a decision which they supported. We are living with the inevitable consequences of a process which has been badly handled.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is reasonable for us and for the public to observe that a process has been supported by the Opposition, the consequences of which it is finding very painful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that this matter is presently before the Industrial Relations Commission in Melbourne. It always concerns me that we, as one of the arms of government, should want to intrude into the other arm. If we have a proper process-which, in this case, as I understand it, the union and the employers are using-we ought to let that process take place. As I understand it, it will be concluded by today. Mr President, it was in light of the fact that it will conclude today that I understood your position to be that you were going to wait until that happened. That could be this afternoon. I cannot imagine that the House will be greatly inconvenienced by having to wait for three or four hours. The waiting of three or four hours will allow a proper process to take place.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Parliament set up the Industrial Relations Act-most senators here today were here when that Act was passed-surely we would want that proper process to take place. If we want to be revolutionaries or radicals we could go ahead and talk about it now, but what about the proper process? What about a little conservatism and a little tradition?
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The accusation from the other side is that I am a bit on the conservative side, but I think in this situation conservatism counts. I think we ought to wait until this afternoon to let the process take place. Let us not be lawless; let us wait for the proper process to be concluded. Mr President, you can come back this afternoon and tell us about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to this motion, particularly after Senator Cooney's contribution. Senator Cooney does not understand, and I fear you, Mr President, have not grasped it either, that this is not simply an industrial relations matter. This is a matter relating to the operations of the Parliament and to the primacy of the Parliament. It is not a radical solution for the Parliament to demand that it be allowed to conduct its proceedings on behalf of the people of Australia without impediment, it is the right of the Parliament to do so. It is a radical view that a self-appointed group of union people should be given the right, unhindered, to prevent the proper operating of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past kings and princes have tried to interfere with the operations of the Parliament and have failed. Not even the kings and princes of the present day-the trade union leaders of Australia-should be allowed to interfere with the proper operations of this Parliament which is here to serve the interests of the people of Australia and not here to be dictated to by a small group of union thugs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly want to respond to what Senator McLean said because that, to me, is not the issue in this particular debate. He said that we were the champions of privatisation and that now we are complaining about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the following point to Senator McLean, through you, Mr President, because unfortunately he obviously does not understand our position on privatisation: our position on privatisation is to create competition, not to create a monopoly as has been done in this place, so Senator McLean should not try to draw in a red herring.

In this debate we are trying to find out from the President exactly what he has done. Mr President, I direct the question to you: what have you done to date to ensure the delivery of mail from our constituents to our parliamentary offices, the delivery of our newspapers so that we are aware of what is going on in the real world outside, the delivery of all other documentation, and the delivery of printing, which we have had done in this building for our constituents, to our electorate offices? Surely that is something you do not need to be briefed on between now and 2.30 p.m., or now and a later hour this day. Mr President, you should be able to give me and the Senate an answer as to exactly what has been done to date to ensure the proper running of this Parliament.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on behalf of the Government and Government senators I wish to support the position which you have put forward. The appropriate time to debate the particular matters which have been raised-some of which are quite important, I agree, and some of which are pompous and irrelevant-is when you, Mr President, bring forward that statement. We welcome the fact that you have said you will bring forward a statement as soon as possible about those matters. I think the debate will be enhanced by a considered and comprehensive statement by you, which is what I would have thought Opposition senators would welcome. We look forward to that statement from you. We feel that the appropriate time for a debate on this matter will be at that stage. Given a little bit of cooperation now, we would be happy to facilitate a discussion at that time rather than going through this less than constructive exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a question similar to one which has already been asked. When we left this place at the end of last session we were assured that the contract that was to be let out would include an assurance that all those already employed would be given 12 months employment or a redundancy package and that they could choose whichever they wanted. We have now heard many rumours, admittedly only via the grapevine, including a rumour that many people have been sacked.

SPEECH.PARA: We were told that a contract was to be let. We also knew well before we left here that Spotless would be awarded the contract. It appears that that rumour at least was accurate in that Spotless has been awarded the contract. I ask you, Mr President: is it a fact that the assurance in the contract to give staff members already working in Parliament House 12 months employment or a redundancy package has been altered and that some of the staff have been sacked?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek an assurance from you that you will not be intimidated in performing your functions by anything that might happen should this dispute escalate. There have been suggestions made to me that, for example, the power and the air-conditioning will be turned off. I seek your assurance that, notwithstanding what else happens, you will continue as planned to call this Senate together for the rest of this week so that honourable senators can continue their function of governing this land.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of points have been made this morning by Opposition senators which only reinforce my attitude that I should make a statement after 2.30 p.m. Three or four grossly wrong statements have been made. People have reacted to misinformation that has been put out. Let me just say very briefly to Senator Macdonald: my belief has always been that no industrial dispute will stop the operation of this Parliament. It never has in the period that I have been here and it will not while I am one of the Presiding Officers.

INTERJECT.PARA: I have not been helped by some honourable senators replying in the media this morning to some of the misinformation that I have heard this morning about the contract. I am not prepared now to make what is going to be a very long statement, including a statement, Senator Walters, about the process by which the tenderer was picked. A detailed statement is being prepared in my office now.

I expected the Industrial Commissioner's verdict last Thursday or Friday. Unfortunately, we have to wait until 2.30 p.m. today. I think the Senate would be much better served by waiting until I have that information. I assure the Senate that I will cover in that statement all the points raised by the Opposition.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEAHAN; BOLKUS; BOSWELL; BUTTON; COATES; COONEY; COULTER; FAULKNER; GILES; HILL; LOOSLEY; MACDONALD; RAY; REYNOLDS; RICHARDSON; SCHACHT; TATE; VANSTONE; WALSH; WALTERS; WATSON
PETITION.NAMEIDS: NE4; XE4; YE4; 4F4; LF4; SF4; TF4; 5K4; XG4; BH4; BS4; YW4; UI4; XI4; 4E4; 4J4; NJ4; 7E4; TJ4; UJ4; VJ4
PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Beahan (from 50 citizens), Senator Bolkus (from 28 citizens), Senator Boswell (from 66 citizens), Senator Button (from 70 citizens), Senator Coates (from 30 citizens), Senator Cooney (from 69 citizens), Senator Coulter (from 50 citizens), Senator Faulkner (from 127 citizens), Senator Giles (from 50 citizens), Senator Hill (from 31 citizens), Senator Loosley (from 200 citizens), Senator Macdonald (from 49 citizens), Senator Robert Ray (from 124 citizens), Senator Reynolds (from 29 citizens), Senator Richardson (from 102 citizens), Senator Schacht (from 24 citizens), Senator Tate (from 19 citizens), Senator Vanstone (from 46 citizens), Senator Walsh (from 50 citizens), Senator Walters (from 29 citizens) and Senator Watson (from 24 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Smokefree International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii) call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (IACO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by IACO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bell (from 120 citizens), Senator Giles (from 120 citizens), Senator McMullan (from 100 citizens), Senator Reid (from 120 citizens) and Senator Reynolds (from 120 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Electoral Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Senate to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Macdonald (from 102 citizens), Senator Parer (from 543 citizens) and Senator Reid (from 76 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Durack (from 31 citizens) and Senator Powell (from 31 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
- That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
- That the right to life to all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
- That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
- That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
- That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
- That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator McLean (from 163 citizens) and Senator Reid (from 60 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Directory: Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Since the introduction of three (3) regional West Australian telephone directories there has been a constant demand from users to revert to a consolidated country directory which is convenient to all users.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled urge the Minister for Communications to direct Telecom to recognise the requirement of rural West Australians and revert to a single consolidated country telephone directory.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and senators in the Senate assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesmanlike leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:-

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Senate will, as a matter of urgency, establish a Committee of enquiry into
a) the export of Australian military hardware and services;
b) the adequacy of existing controls over Australian arms exports;
c) the implications of the international arms trade and ways in which it might be reduced.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wealth Inquiry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That in Australia, the rich are getting richer while poverty is increasing, as shown by recent research that 10% of the population own 50% of the wealth while people in poverty have increased from 1.5 million in 1982 to 2.1 million in 1986.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Request the Australian Government-
to establish a Wealth Inquiry as a first and essential step to the achievement of a more just society;
and that this Inquiry should seek to establish-
the current distribution of wealth, how it has changed over time and the causes of these changes
the effectiveness of the Australian taxation system in raising revenue at all levels of taxpayers' income and assets
the measures which should be taken to achieve a more just society

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
- That every abortion kills an unborn baby.
- That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
- That the first duty of the Parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life.
- That in 1989/90 alone Medicare subsidised 69,587 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to subsidise abortions through Medicare by passing the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes:

(i) with dismay and profound disappointment the dumping of subsidised wheat by the US Administration under its Export Enhancement Program in traditional Australian markets, including Yemen, despite promises that it would not,
(ii) that the Federal Government has done little to convince the US that its trade war with the European Community (EC) is hurting Australia far more than it is affecting any EC markets, and

(iii) that the Federal Government has done nothing to convince the EC that its trade policies are affecting trade across the globe and there appears to be no constructive plans to send missions to EC countries to argue Australia's case; and

(b) calls on the Federal Government to press more firmly the US Administration to take its trade fight more directly to the EC and not use Australian markets as target practice in what is supposed to be a trade war between the EC and US, not an attack by one friendly nation on another, that is, the US on Australia.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Collins, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he will move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act relating to the carriage of goods by sea, and for related purposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That consideration of committee reports under standing order 62 take place on Thursdays, after the time for the consideration of General Business.
(2) That this order be a sessional order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that:

(i) the Commonwealth Car Service accepted contracts on 13 August 1991 to drive Senators to a formal sitting of the Parliament and breached that contract by failing to drive Senators to the Parliament, and

(ii) in doing so, the Commonwealth drivers clearly committed the grave offence of contempt of the Parliament in materially obstructing the attendance of members of Parliament at a formal sitting of the Parliament and thereby breached the Parliamentary Privileges Act; and
(b) calls on the Government to dismiss instantly those drivers guilty of contempt of Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes the corruption of international wheat markets by European Community (EC) subsidies and retaliatory subsidies by the United States;
(b) deplores the damaging effects these subsidies have had on the efficient, unsubsidised exports of Australian wheat and the serious flow-on effects for the Australian economy as a whole;

(c) notes that the Australian Government, along with other Cairns Group countries and the United States, continues to fight in the Uruguay Round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations for curtailment of export subsidies;

(d) expresses its desire to the EC, in particular, and its member governments, that the EC should show vigorous leadership to the nations of the world in the pursuit of free trade by imposing immediate, serious and wide-ranging disciplines on its program of export restitutions and by desisting from using that program to compete with US subsidies; and

(e) urges the United States, at the same time, to impose the same disciplines on its Exports Enhancement Program and, until the successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round, to target its subsidies in such a way as to minimise damage to non-subsidising exporters such as Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) condemns the actions of the United States Government in dumping subsidised wheat onto the Chinese, Phillippino and Algerian markets as well as into the traditional Australian market of Yemen;
(b) notes that these actions could cause the loss of up to $1 billion to Australian wheat growers in the next harvest; and
(c) calls on the Government to take a tougher stance with the United States on these matters, preferably before President Bush's visit later this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Crimes Act 1914.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act relating to crimes and certain other acts committed on or in respect of certain aircraft, aerodromes, airports and air navigation facilities, and for related purposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Freedom of Information Act 1982, and for related purposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that:
(i) the loss of 129 200 teenage full-time jobs in Australian over the year to July 1991 is the largest 12-month job loss ever recorded for 15-19 year olds in Australia's history,
(ii) there are only 301 100 15-19 year olds in full-time work, or 236 300 fewer than ten years ago under the Fraser Government,

(iii) as a result, youth unemployment has risen (seasonally adjusted) to 28.5 per cent, or three times more than the adult unemployment rate and the worst level since the 1930's depression, far exceeding the 1983 recession peak of 27.6 per cent, and
(iv) the five Labor-governed states had the worst youth unemployment rates, while Liberal/National New South Wales had the lowest at 25.5 per cent, well below the average;
(b) demands that the Hawke Government end its deliberate attack on jobs of young Australians that is part of the recession it says we had to have; and

(c) calls on the Hawke Government to implement the economic rescue package of reform of the labour markets, of infrastructure and of the chaotic tax system (including the replacement of the unfair hidden sales tax with an honest non-discriminatory goods and services tax) that is essential if we are to end the recession and restore job opportunities for young Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I acknowledge your comments made in an earlier debate. Nevertheless, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes with deep concern:

(i) the fact that the premature and hasty privatisation of the Parliamentary Catering Service has not only led to the unnecessary and wrongful dismissal of many workers who have served us well, but also gives rise to massive disruption which will affect the operation of the Parliament for days or weeks and potentially damages morale, the effects of which may last for months, and
(ii) that the President has undertaken to provide a comprehensive report to the Senate, at the earliest possible time, to clarify:
(A) why the decision to privatise was made, upon what factual basis and by whom and the analysis of the questionnaire circulated among Members and Senators,
(B) what redundancy packages were offered, to whom, and upon what criteria,
(C) what alternative strategies were considered, other than privatisation, and
(D) what degree of consultation was entered into with employee representatives and with what outcomes; and
(b) calls upon all Senators to respect the intention of the picket and not use the privatised catering service until the President has adequately reported for our deliberation.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report by 5 November 1991 and that the Committee give specific consideration to:
(a) those aspects of the bill which infringe on freedom of political expression in Australia; and
(b) the disclosures aspects of the bill in respect of:
(i) adequate safeguards against, and penalties for, intimidation of donors or potential donors to political parties; and
(ii) fair and equitable treatment in respect of taxation and other matters of all donors to all political parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that on 30 June 1991 the last Soviet occupying troops left Hungarian soil;
(b) recalls the struggle and sacrifice of the Hungarian people to win their freedom;
(c) believes the example of the Hungarian people in their struggle for freedom played a vital role in helping to liberate the countries of Eastern Europe from Soviet oppression; and
(d) congratulates the Australians of Hungarian origin on their strong support for freedom and democratic rule in Hungary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes the boast by the former Treasurer (Mr Keating) that he is very happy with the outcome of his period as Treasurer;
(b) notes that among the outcomes of Mr Keating's eight years as Treasurer are:
(i) the worst recession since the 1930's depression,
(ii) record unemployment and job losses, especially for young Australians,
(iii) record and still rising foreign debt which requires more than $1 billion a month simply to service, so continuing Australia's disastrous Balance of Payments crisis, and
(iv) record bankruptcies, especially for small businesses;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to be an appropriate time to raise with the de facto Minister, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan), the program for this week and this session. We had agreed to come back for this unprecedented sitting during the week before the Budget session on the basis of the weight of business before the Senate and the fact that there was an overload of business at the end of the last session. I do not think even the Government would justify that in the light of an orderly program. It was largely business that entered the parliamentary process too late. It was not dealt with and an alternative was put of the Senate sitting during July, which would have meant it was sitting during every month of this year, which was unsatisfactory for a number of reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of all those concerns, we have said-I think we may even have volunteered-that we would be prepared to sit a week earlier to facilitate the Government's program. What has happened is that the program has collapsed. We now know that the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991, which was to be the principal matter for debate and the matter of such great urgency for this week, is now no longer to be debated in this chamber this week. That issue is clearly going to be debated in greater length in a moment or two, but I remind you, Mr President, that we on this side of the chamber urged and moved notices of motion asking that the committee consideration of that Bill take place during the parliamentary break in order that debate could take place in an orderly way in here this week. The Government and the Australian Democrats refused that orderly process and now we come back here and find that they have changed their minds and now want to refer the legislation to a committee. So the purpose of our coming back this week, as far it relates to that piece of legislation, has been lost.

We have already found that other pieces of legislation that were so important and were to be dealt with this week are now not going to be dealt with. I understand that the fisheries legislation is to be put off. Yesterday morning the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs had a hearing to try to facilitate the process of the copyright legislation. It is incomplete; the Committee is now going to meet again on Thursday to try to put that in shape for debate on Friday of this week, but at this stage it must be regarded as very doubtful. The social security legislation was dealt with by the Standing Committee on Community Affairs yesterday. I understand that that was found to be wanting and that debate on that Bill is now likely not to take place for several weeks whilst matters are sorted out.

The question therefore is: why are we back here this week in the light of this collapse of the Government's program? The Parliamentary Secretary might now use this brief debate to explain to the Senate what the business of the Senate is to be in the course of this week. I would ask him to put that in the context of the planned business for the whole of this parliamentary session.

We have had a view for some years that finishing the parliamentary session a day or two before Christmas is unwise. There are a lot of reasons why honourable senators should be back in their electorates for a week or two before Christmas. It was hoped that with orderly programming that might be achieved this year. I remind you, Mr President, that during the period of the Fraser Government, with orderly programming, it was able to be achieved but during the period of this Government, due to its inability to put a program in reasonable order, legislation is not introduced until late in the session and the Senate finishes too late in the year.

We are keen to work constructively with the Government this session to allow the Senate to get up at least a clear week before Christmas. At the moment, the Government's program has the Senate finishing the week of 21 December which, in our opinion, is too late. If the Senate had had a full program of work this week, that reasonable desire to finish a week earlier may have been met. The collapse of the program this week will make it even more difficult. I ask the Manager of Government Business to address the program for the session in the light of that reasonable desire to finish at a sensible time this year.

As the Parliamentary Secretary knows, there are a number of mechanisms that could be adopted, such as bringing forward the cut-off date, which would make it more difficult for the Government. We do not want to adopt such measures if the programming can be handled in an orderly and sensible way. We are more than happy to give an undertaking that legislation be treated in that way. We can get through much of this material more sensibly than we have been able to in the past. I want to put on the record now, at the beginning of the session, our desire to finish one week before 21 December because that is a sensible legislative process, and for no other reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to put on record a similar sentiment to that expressed by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) and I welcome his comments. It is essential, if we are to get through the business of this place as it is presented before us, that we do all cooperate. My colleagues and I certainly concur with the view that the Senate should not be sitting virtually until Christmas Eve on a regular basis in the way that it has been.

SPEECH.PARA: Through you, Mr President, I would like formally in this chamber to convey to the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan) and the Leader of the Opposition our willingness to cooperate in the program as it proceeds throughout the year. I think it will be necessary for us continually to review progress. We are certainly willing to do that. That could lead to a better finish, an earlier finish and one that is less rushed.

I suggest to the Manager of Government Business that perhaps he should consider the situation for this week. Quite clearly, as Senator Hill as pointed out, we will not be dealing with some legislation this week in the way that we expected to. I notice that there are Bills on notice for introduction by Senator Tate, at least, and I would suggest that if it is the case that this week's program is not looking as busy as we expected, consideration be given to shortening the session this week. All of us have other work to do. If there is no productive work here, I suggest that we might have productive work elsewhere. At least we will be able to take our mail home with us now that we are here in Parliament House.
To begin this session with a spirit of cooperation is a good beginning. I simply want to acknowledge and to put on record our willingness to do that throughout the session, including this week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In support of Senator Hill's remarks, in particular, I wish to refer to one matter and that is the advantage for honourable senators in having a shortened sitting in December. For at least the last 10 years I do not recall having had the opportunity to attend community functions in my electorate of South Australia during December. At the moment we are to sit, according to the schedule, for three weeks out of four in November; the Senate only is due to sit during the first two weeks of December; and presumably the House of Representatives will return while the Senate is scheduled to sit, at the moment, in the third week of December. I wish to state, I think on behalf of a number of honourable senators on both sides of the chamber, that there are a number of important community functions that occur in our electorates-the end of the school year and Christmas functions-at which members of parliament are often expected to be in attendance.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, there is a general impression during December that the Parliament has risen because the House of Representatives is not sitting in the first two weeks of December. Whilst members of the House of Representatives can attend a number of these important December functions around Australia, senators are denied that opportunity, and have been denied it for at least the last decade. I therefore very strongly support Senator Hill's suggestion that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is sitting in the chamber, gives every consideration to us being able to attend electorate functions in December.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I welcome the positive notes put forward in the latter part of Senator Hill's comments and in Senator Powell's contribution. This week there is still a substantial body of legislation to be dealt with. In order to facilitate the continuing smooth flow of business so that we do not have a lull now and a rush later, we have sought to initiate legislation in the Senate today. So legislation will start here and flow to the House of Representatives subsequently for this week and next week. As far as possible we wish to be cooperative in that matter and that is why those notices of motion were given this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously in the Budget session there is a large amount of legislation that can only be introduced in the House of Representatives and that creates a bunching of legislation. There is no alternative to that. The Appropriation Bills and taxation legislation, et cetera, are a major part of the debate. So there will inevitably be that bunching of Budget legislation. A substantial amount of Senate time is also taken by Estimates committees and consideration of legislation at the committee stage. That will also put some pressure later on.

However, we are endeavouring to put as much business forward as possible in these early stages for the reasons outlined by Senator Hill and Senator Powell. In terms of the positive elements of their contribution towards seeking cooperation about programming, I would be very happy this week to convene a meeting with Senator Hill and Senator Powell and talk about programming for the rest of the session in an attempt to get some cooperative format that will expedite the program.

Nobody wishes to be here a day more than is necessary to pass the legislative program. I cannot give an undertaking to Senator Teague that we will achieve what he desires. Wherever I might live, I can assure him that there are many other Government senators who are as enthusiastic as he and Senator Hill to be in places other than Canberra in the week before Christmas. But I cannot give a guarantee on that.

I will call a meeting as soon as possible for Senator Hill and Senator Powell, where we can talk about these things and try to cooperate in getting a program that will facilitate and expedite the business of the Senate so that we can discharge our responsibilities and get home as early as possible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: WILDLIFE PROTECTION (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Since the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 came into effect in 1984 the courts have recognised the seriousness of wildlife offences and have been imposing progressively heavier penalties on those convicted of illegally exporting and importing wildlife. This trend, together with the work being undertaken cooperatively by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS), the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service, the Australian Customs Service, State and Federal Police, and State wildlife agencies, is making wildlife smuggling an increasingly risky business. There is also developing, through the arrangements in effect under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), an increasingly effective international cooperative effort to stem the illegal international wildlife trade. These efforts are complemented and assisted by the work of the international network of the Trade Records Analysis of Flora and Fauna In Commerce (TRAFFIC) offices. The TRAFFIC office in Australia has directly assisted the work of State and Federal Agencies, and is also to be commended for its work in helping to raise Australian awareness of wildlife smuggling.

There nevertheless remains the fact that smuggling wildlife out of Australia is potentially lucrative, and in the case of illegal importations, could sow the seeds of an environmental disaster. A court recently accepted that 10 Gang Gang Cockatoos, 23 Major Mitchell's Cockatoos and 4 Musk Lorikeets that a person was attempting to smuggle out of Australia had an overseas value of US$325,000.

Australia also has a history of exotic species that have become established in the wild. Rabbits, foxes, cats, cane toads and the prickly pear have either changed, often permanently, parts of the Australian environment or been implicated in the demise of some of our native fauna. The risks to the environment of uncontrolled introduction of exotic species are clearly as great as the risks of introducing exotic diseases.

It is essential that the penalties available to the courts are sufficient to deter those who would smuggle wildlife. Clearly a monetary penalty, or an insufficient custodial sentence, are not wholly effective. For example in a case brought under the Wildlife Protection Act, the presiding Judge commented that, considering the seriousness of the offence, he would have considered imposing a heavier sentence had it been available.

This Bill therefore includes an amendment that will raise the maximum custodial penalty under the Wildlife Protection Act from 5 to 10 years, and also gives the court the option of imposing both a monetary penalty, as well as a custodial sentence.

Provision will also be made requiring the Designated Authority under the Act to give notice on an annual basis, inviting interested persons or groups to register their interest in commenting on any proposal for declarations of approved management programs and proposals for declarations of controlled specimens. These amendments will go a long way towards addressing the concerns that no provision was made for public comment. The only channel for public redress was to apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of a decision after the event, which frequently exposed the applicant to a costly and time consuming process.

The exercise of controls on Australian international wildlife trade requires, in addition to a commitment to effective law enforcement, the efficient and effective administrative control of legitimate trade in wildlife and wildlife products. The Wildlife Protection Act sets out the circumstances under which transactions for scientific research and zoological display may occur, and defines the circumstances under which private and commercial transactions may be permitted. Originally the provisions of the Wildlife Protection Act did not fully take into account the range of circumstances under which private and commercial wildlife trade may occur, the various ways in which wildlife products are obtained, or the enormous differences in status and biology of the large number of species covered by the Act. Previous amendments to the Wildlife Protection Act largely addressed changes to administrative procedures that have improved operating efficiency.

Other parts of this Bill make further changes to administrative procedures, that will improve operating efficiency without compromising the protection of wildlife and the Australian environment. These changes have largely arisen from decisions made following the review of government export controls. The amendments will allow a more case specific approach to the requirements for a management program and the type of Australian wildlife and wildlife products. The changes will not affect controls on species subject to commercial utilisation like kangaroos, or species whose status could be adversely affected if levels of utilisation were not strictly controlled, like the estuarine (saltwater) crocodile. There are however a wide range of common species that are subject to small scale utilisation, often by means that have little impact on wild populations. The Bill allows a more flexible approach towards defining the need for information on the biology of the species, and the nature and extent of controls that need to be applied to these activities.

Associated with these changes to assessing management programs is provision for approval of programs to be conditional. For example it will be possible to set quotas or levels of harvest. Such conditions applied to the approval of kangaroo programs will enable harvesting limits to be set in accordance with a recommendation of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare.

These changes will not apply to endangered or rare species whose protection and conservation is of special ongoing concern to this Government. To address this concern the Government has established an Endangered Species Unit within ANPWS and an Endangered Species Advisory Committee (ESAC), which prepared a national strategy for the conservation of species and habitats threatened with extinction. ESAC provides an effective framework for the involvement of non-government organisations in the conservation of endangered species. The global loss of species is of increasing concern to the community, and the Endangered Species Unit and ESAC, while mainly addressing problems faced by native species, also direct their attention to Australian activities that can support conservation of endangered species in other parts of the world.

Nor will these changes alter the current ban on private and commercial export of live native fauna. The arguments of those in favour of allowing commercial export of live native birds have been well documented in the media. The review of government export controls that gave rise to these amendments also examined this issue. The Government has affirmed that relaxing current controls is unlikely to be effective and is not in the best interest of the species concerned. The ANPWS has provided funding for research on methods of protecting crops from bird damage as this problem is central to the arguments of those advocating commercial export of live birds. It is considered that developing a better understanding of the birds' biology and behaviour, and using this knowledge to vary agricultural methods, is more likely to provide long-term solutions than merely exporting birds. I am pleased to note that this approach has been wholeheartedly supported by responsible animal welfare agencies, such as the RSPCA.

I would also highlight that the export of wild taken birds, such as our galah and sulphur crested cockatoo, is not an answer to the pest problem. As many of my honourable colleagues will be aware, the export ban on live native birds came into effect in 1960. This ban was implemented following a conference of State and Commonwealth conservation Ministers in 1959. The meeting examined a survey on the mortality ratio of birds that were being captured for legal export. This survey concluded that of all the birds trapped, only 25 percent survived to be actually exported.

We should also look at the potential market for exports of wild taken birds. It is not as great as one would imagine. There are only a few countries that can be considered as having a potential demand. The USA would be the prime market, with some European countries accepting limited quantities. For many years now, there has been international concern over the vast amounts of wild birds being traded for the pet market. It is generally recognised that wild taken birds make poor pets, and that the caging of a wild animal is not an acceptable practice. I should also point out that in the United States of America, two separate bills have recently been introduced into the US Congress that relate to the importation of wild birds. These bills call for a phase out of the importation of wild-caught birds for the pet trade. One version of the USA bill calls for a 5 year phase out, while the other version calls for an end to imports of wild caught birds for the pet market after one year. Although there is no indication as to the success of these bills, which are anticipated to be debated some time over the next few months, the implication is clear: there is to be a gradual elimination of trade in wild taken birds.

To that end, the Wildlife Amendment Bill also tightens controls on the export of birds as household pets by providing for an upper limit on the number of birds that may be taken out of Australia by a person leaving to take up permanent residence overseas.

Finally the Bill proposes a number of amendments to streamline administration. These include a definition of the meaning of `transhipment', which is tightened to prevent importers from using Australia as a holding area for wildlife products taken out of other countries while they arrange buyers and delivery. Another amendment will allow people in remote areas to export wildlife products without prior presentation of the original permit to a Customs Officer or inspector. Such exporters must, however, receive the permission of the ANPWS before doing so. A further amendment enables the Minister to delegate to the Designated Authority the power to grant an authority under section 44 in exceptional circumstances. The grant of such authorities is subject to public review. The other amendments concern cross referencing of terms within the Act.

Mr President, the continuing loss of global biological diversity, the depletion of the ozone layer, the pollution of our atmosphere and oceans and the associated greenhouse effect is wearing away the fabric of the intricate biological web that sustains-life on this planet. The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 is part of a global network of legislation, with the ultimate objective to ensure that our utilisation of wildlife and ecosystems is sustainable. The amendments proposed in this Bill support that objective, give the flexibility that is essential to its effective administration, and increase its strength in deterring illegal wildlife trafficking.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
