SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 can fairly be described as an omnibus Bill which seeks to amend various Acts concerned with crime, law enforcement and criminal justice. The Acts that this Bill seeks to amend are: the Australian Federal Police Act 1979; the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988; the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987; the Crimes Act 1914; the Passports Act 1938; the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Act 1989; the National Crime Authority Act 1984; and the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to deal briefly with some of the more high profile amendments which the Bill seeks to make. There is an extension of the witness protection scheme so that it includes persons other than witnesses who are in need of protection by reason of their association with the relevant witness. This is in relation to the amendments to the Australian Federal Police Act.

One amendment that deserves specific mention is the amendment which provides that, where a determination has not been made with respect to the compensation payable to a staff member upon early termination-that is, where that determination was not made at the time of appointment-the Commissioner may make such determination at the time of the termination as is essential. I draw attention to that particular amendment because it provides the opportunity for abuse in the form of retrospective golden handshakes. There is the additional point to make-that the Federal Police should be obliged to ensure that these determinations are made at the time of appointment.

In relation to the Cash Transaction Reports Act, the more substantive amendments deal with the protection given to cash dealers for incorrect reports of suspect transactions under section 16. Obviously, the proper functioning of the Cash Transaction Reports Act is essential in the network of legislation to get at organised crime, and it has always been the intention that cash dealers acting in good faith would be protected.

At this point it is worth raising a query which the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) may care to deal with. As I understand it, the phrase `mistaken belief' is wider than some people imagine, and this could cause some problems. The Bill seeks to impose on cash dealers an obligation of confidentiality, non-compliance with which will constitute a criminal offence. It will be an exception for a cash dealer to disclose such information, either pursuant to the terms of the Act or to a court by way of evidence. Perhaps this deserves to be queried. No provision is made, as I understand it, to allow cash dealers to make such disclosures to legal representatives in the preparation of court proceedings. At the moment only the Cash Transaction Reports Agency is allowed to make such disclosures.

There are alterations to the obligations of cash dealers for keeping records so that they can retain copies, including microfiche, rather than the original records. The coalition would appreciate a comment from the Minister in relation to this matter, and specifically as to how such a change will affect the best evidence rule in relation to the production of original documents for court proceedings.

Furthermore, the cash transaction reports information will be allowed to be passed to the Attorney-General for the purposes of transmitting that information to a foreign country-obviously not at the whim of the Attorney-General, but under the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987. The Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales and the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland are added as law enforcement bodies which may have access to CTR information. That is obviously an important amendment.

The Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency is to provide an annual report as soon as practicable after 30 June. That is a good thing, on the one hand; but, on the other, the Minister may care to give an explanation as to why the Director is not required to give a report at some nominated time. That does not seem too much to ask. There are plenty of other bodies that have a specific limitation put on them in that respect.

In relation to the amendments to the Crimes Act, a private member's Bill was put forward by Mr Peacock in December 1990 which vanished into thin air and which was moved as an amendment to part 4 when the Bill went through the House of Representatives, and the same will be happening in the committee stage here. That presented an opportunity for the Government to take up some of the amendments from the fourth interim report of the Criminal Law Review Committee, but they just were not acceded to by the Government. It seems now to be proceeding in somewhat of a piecemeal fashion. That is not to say that these things do not need to be done, but no adequate explanation was given for not adopting those proposals.

There are further amendments to the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Act, to the Customs Act and to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987. Then, in part 8 of the Bill, there are amendments to the National Crime Authority Act 1984. These amendments are designed to allow the ACT Government to participate in the Inter-governmental Committee, which is responsible, as the Minister obviously knows, for references to the Authority. This change will be a good thing.

It is probably appropriate to mention at this stage, though, that it is public knowledge that the Inter-governmental Committee has made the recommendation that the Joint Parliamentary Committee to oversee the National Crime Authority be abolished. In that respect, I am pleased to say that there has been some progress in that the Joint Parliamentary Committee to oversee the National Crime Authority has met informally with the Inter-governmental Committee, and I do not think it is inappropriate to say that some of the misunderstandings and misconceptions, in my view, held by the IGC have been alleviated, and there will be further meetings to see what possibility there is of getting some common ground. So, in that sense, I seek to make some positive remarks.

On the other hand, I cannot resist the opportunity of saying how extraordinary it is that a body of State Ministers should purport to suggest to this Parliament that a committee set up by this Parliament to oversee a body set up by this Parliament should be abolished because in some way it makes it difficult for the life of a State Minister to carry on. When one looks at the history of the National Crime Authority- I do not want to take up a lot of time on this matter, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I am sure that you understand- one cannot say that it has an unblemished history. If one were a member of the public looking to see just what it is that the Inter-governmental Committee has done by way of supervision of this Authority, one would be at a loss to see what accountability it has.

I can recall a specific instance in South Australia where a question was put to the State Attorney-General, Mr Sumner, who, incidentally, is a member of the IGC, and his response was to this effect: `Well, if one wanted to know something about the National Crime Authority, one could go to the Joint Parliamentary Committee and ask the question'. Yet here, in another forum, Mr Sumner feels no difficulty in saying that that Committee should be abolished, in part, I suppose, because he and others see that the lines of accountability are confused by that Committee.

I want to make it abundantly clear that is not the coalition's view. One needs only to turn back to the Hansard record at the time the National Crime Authority was established to see what role this Parliament saw for the Joint Parliamentary Committee, what role this Parliament saw for the IGC and how this Parliament saw that those two bodies were needed as separate bodies and how they could coexist.

It might be appropriate, other than to make a small reference to the amendments that we are going to make, to leave it at that. The coalition will be moving eight amendments when we get to the committee stage: amendments Nos 1 to 3 together as a group if it is the wish of the Committee of the Whole House to do so, since they all sensibly belong together. Those amendments deal primarily with section 16 of the Cash Transaction Reports Act to ensure that there is a clearer-and by that I mean narrower-definition of just what it is that an officer needs to report.

The situation at the moment is that cash dealers have to make reports when they form a view or suspect that the information available to them says that there may be a contravention of a law of the Commonwealth or a Territory. This requirement is obviously very broad. The obligation imposed by section 16, consequently, is very broad because there is such a wide range of offences. As my colleague Mr Peacock put it in a debate in the House of Representatives:
The obligations imposed by section 16 relate to a wide range of offences, from the most trivial to the most serious.
As he said:
The amendment seeks to confine those obligations to information which may be relevant to a serious offence as defined.

I note that the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, in responding to those amendments moved by Mr Peacock, indicated that the Government would not accept those amendments. The reason he gave was that it would require every cash dealer to be some sort of specialist in the law of the Commonwealth, in criminal law, to make some sort of assessment as to whether the information he had indicated that there may be contravention of this defined category of serious offence, but that is not an adequate argument to reject these amendments. The reason it is not adequate is this: if a cash dealer has the competence to recognise over the breadth of section 16 the range of offences that may be contravened, a cash dealer has the capacity to recognise a smaller range of offences. I think that is the point. The breadth of section 16 at the moment means that a cash dealer has to have some knowledge of a very broad range of offences, and the coalition is seeking to narrow down the range of offences that a cash dealer would need to have some knowledge of. On that basis I say that the Attorney-General's answer is inadequate.

The second group of amendments to be moved-that is, amendments Nos 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8-are somewhat more substantive than the first three. Amendment No. 4 seeks to amend section 3 of the Crimes Act by adding at the end of the definition of `Commonwealth officer' a reference to agents of the Commonwealth for the purpose of proposed new sections 54, 55 and 56. Those proposed sections are contained within amendment No. 5, which in turn can be divided into two parts.

Amendment No. 5 seeks to introduce into the Bill new clauses 21a and 21b. Clause 21a seeks to repeal sections 31 to 44 of the Crimes Act and to substitute new provisions relating to the administration of justice. Clause 21b seeks to insert into the Crimes Act a new part 4 dealing with bribery and corruption. Amendments Nos 6, 7, and 8 are consequential amendments.

In relation to bribery and corruption, it is a matter of particular note that the Government has expressed, through its support for a Bill to ban political advertising, the need to rid the political process of corruption. In relation to that, the coalition has said that there has been no evidence of the cost of advertising leading to the corruption of public officials and, on that ground, the Government's support for that particular Bill does not stand up. It has further said that, in any event, the limitation on political freedom of expression is unsatisfactory.

What the coalition has never said, however, is that it has no concern whatsoever about corruption of public officials. One simply could not contemplate any party in this chamber saying that it had no concern about that particular matter. My colleague Mr Peacock, in the other place, in December 1990 presented a Bill, the tenor of which these amendments reflect. His concern was to very much modernise the criminal laws of the Commonwealth relating to bribery and corruption of judicial officers, parliamentarians and public servants.

Mr Peacock raised a number of matters at the time, one of which I will leave and the other I will mention at this stage. He pointed out that the report of the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption exposed a mysterious network of financiers, developers, Australian Labor Party figures and Federal public servants operating with respect to land developments. He went on to say that one former senior adviser to a Federal Minister, riddled with conflicts of interest, formed the subject of a secret and separate report for his abuse of office.

It should not need more than a simple explanation as to why the Government purports to be interested in ridding the system of any corruption that may exist and purports to say that that is one of its priorities, yet offers as an explanation for not accepting these amendments simply that the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, when responding to these amendments in May-not responding to the original private member's Bill put forward by Mr Peacock-gave a whole lot of reasons why the Government had not got around to a number of things and said:
Once certain principles are reformed and formulated, the recommendations in the fourth interim report, including those concerning bribery and corruption, may need further review.

It does seem somewhat inconsistent to have a government saying that it believes corruption is so much at risk of tainting the political process that it is justified in looking at banning the freedom of political expression, and that it is justified in suggesting to Australian voters that they should go to an election and get their unedited political information only from the print media, and be satisfied with the editing by the electronic media-that is, not be able to hear unedited political views over the electronic air waves.

The Government is so determined to do something about corruption of public officials-or, at least, of parliamentarians-that it feels justified in taking that course of action but, when it comes to looking at implementing some of the recommendations of the Gibbs Committee, all the Government can say is, `When we get around to it, some of the recommendations in that report, including those concerning bribery and corruption, may need further review'. It somewhat drains the Government's interest in getting at bribery and corruption, not only in terms of where it may exist in the political process relating to parliamentarians, but also in relation to public officers and members of the judiciary.

That was the evil that Mr Peacock sought to get at in his private member's Bill. It is the evil that the coalition seeks to do something about by moving these amendments. On that basis, I believe both groups of amendments should be supported, namely, the first group to narrow the offences which cash dealers need to deal with in reporting suspect transactions and, secondly, the whole package of amendments put forward by Mr Peacock in the other place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). This is an omnibus Bill encompassing amendments to various Acts concerned with crime, law enforcement and criminal justice. There are technical and policy amendments which the Australian Democrats do not oppose. However, as indicated in the past, the Australian Democrats will continue to monitor the operation of certain pieces of legislation amended by this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Part 2 of the Bill seeks to amend the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 to extend the scope of the witness protection scheme. We are supportive of that. Part 2 also seeks to make improvements to a provision concerning management initiated retirement. On this point, the Opposition raised the concern that if any arrangements are to be made for compensation, they should be made at the time of appointment. Certainly, that is the principle that should be followed. However, I am persuaded by the explanation given by Mr Duffy, the Attorney-General, suggesting that this amendment will cover the eventuality where the initial appointment has been invalidly made. I believe it is useful to plug that particular gap.

Part 3 and part 7 of the Bill amend the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 and the Mutual Assistance In Criminal Matters Act 1987 respectively. The amendments to the Cash Transaction Reports Act will clarify and improve the efficiency of the various statutory processes involved in the reporting of transactions under the Act. In particular, the amendments will permit access to information obtained under the Cash Transaction Reports Act to be granted to the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales, the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland and the Attorney-General, for the purpose of responding to a request for assistance from the foreign country to which the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 applies.

As the Senate is aware, the Australian Democrats did not support this Act originally because of concerns about privacy protection and the likely effectiveness of the Act. Those concerns remain a high priority in our ongoing review of the operation of the Cash Transaction Reports Act. The requirement under these amendments for the Director of the Agency to furnish an annual report on the operations of the Agency to the Minister is a useful step in this regard. The review of the Act recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and mentioned by the Attorney-General in the second reading speech will also be helpful.

Some of the other amendments are in part 4 and part 9 which will amend the Crimes Act and the Passports Act 1938 respectively. These amendments will introduce a procedure to ensure the effective operation of the existing power of the Minister to cancel or refuse passports to persons charged with or convicted of serious offences, particularly drug offences. These parts, as well as amendments in parts 5 and 6 relating to the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Act and the Customs Act, are supported by the Democrats without comment.

Part 8 of the Bill proposes amendments to the National Crime Authority Act 1984 to allow participation in the IGC by the ACT Government. I would like to take this opportunity, as Senator Vanstone has, to comment briefly on the matter that has arisen in discussions between the IGC, the NCA and the Joint Committee on the NCA. I note in passing how extraordinary it is that the IGC should suggest that the Joint Committee should be abolished when this is the very mechanism that has been provided by parliament to ensure proper supervision of the NCA. Like Senator Vanstone, I point to the fact that the record of the NCA has not been without blemish in the past. We look forward to a decisive improvement under the chairmanship of Mr Justice Phillips.

Clearly the task of supervising the activities of the NCA remains for the Joint Committee. It is on the record that this work has been considerably hampered in the past by the secrecy provisions which have been used on occasion to withhold information which I believe the Committee required to carry out its work effectively. In this context, I welcome in particular the comments made in the other House by the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peacock. He acknowledges Mr Justice Phillips's support for the principle that section 51 of the Act-in other words, the secrecy provisions-should not apply to the Joint Committee.

This Bill is the subject of a private member's Bill introduced by Senator Crichton-Browne. I am pleased to express support for the principle expressed; in fact, my own Bill repeats that provision and takes it considerably further by suggesting that there are necessary amendments to section 55(2), but beyond that it accepts the principle, which is also mentioned in the shadow Attorney-General's speech, that, if Committee members are to be given access to confidential information from the NCA, in turn they must accept a certain obligation to keep confidential information which has been divulged to them.

In this situation the difficulty arises where there is a difference of opinion between the NCA and the Joint Committee on the NCA as to whether a particular piece of legislation should be divulged, should be used in public or whether it should, on the basis of certain principles such as the assistance it might give to criminal elements, be kept confidential and not divulged. The contrary argument is that the Joint Committee on the NCA is charged with the duty to press for remedial action, not only to monitor the work of the Committee but also to suggest to the Attorney-General any remedial action that is needed. His Honour Mr Justice Phillips suggests that a judicial arbiter might be used here should such a conflict arise.

I note these suggestions with a great deal of satisfaction. In substance at least they appear to mirror fairly closely the provisions I put down in my private member's Bill dealing with these matters. The comments made by Mr Justice Phillips and the comments of the shadow Attorney-General in the other place, including his submission to the Committee's inquiry, augur well for agreement to be reached. I trust that appropriate legislation will not be too far away.

Part 10 makes several other minor amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act. The Australian Democrats have no further comment to make on that. The Opposition amendments are not supported by the Australian Democrats. While some of the contents, which basically arise from the Gibbs review, may be acceptable, this is a quite inappropriate context in which to adopt virtually a whole new Bill, a whole new direction for criminal law in Australia. As I said, the Australian Democrats will not be supporting these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —With your indulgence, Madam Acting Deputy President, I briefly want to touch upon a couple of matters which you canvassed during your speech. I also want to comment on something Senator Spindler referred to. Madam Acting Deputy President, I will take up the point you made in respect of the submission of the Inter-governmental Committee; that is, the Joint Committee monitoring the National Crime Authority be abolished. With respect, I find that to be breathtaking in its audacity. The NCA does not have a healthy history since its formation; it does not have an unchequered past. The fact that it is subject to an audit by our Committee, and has been subject to other audits, reflects upon the general unhappiness that has prevailed during its existence. That is not meant as a criticism but, I trust, as an objective analysis.

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect we all understand that one of the problems with the NCA from the outset was that whatever our side of politics promised in respect of law and order, the ante was upped by the Government, which caused us, in a political sense, to up it also. The level of expectation as to its pursuit of criminality in Australia was much higher than that which could be achieved in the short term. I suspect the community imagined that with the setting up of the NCA we would see all these `Mr Bigs' brought to justice. Of course, the NCA was never, I hope, intended to deal in the short term with corruption and criminality in Australia, but was to deal with a long term endemic problem.

Having said that, in many respects the IGC has been the supervisory body of the NCA. The fact that the NCA has had many problems in many respects is a reflection upon the competence of the IGC. Again, I trust that to be an objective judgment and not a subjective criticism.

I am reminded that the IGC is made up of State police Ministers. I will not go into the effectiveness of the various police Ministers' supervision of their own portfolios and their own police forces in great length, but I will dwell for a moment upon the performance of the various State police forces. My own State immediately comes to mind. It was not that long ago when the Commissioner of Police, Mr Bull, bugged the Deputy Commissioner, Mr Peters. I have never been certain why, but when the most senior law enforcement man in the police force is surreptitiously having his second in command under surveillance, one wonders whether all is well in Camelot. Without retracing all the problems of the WA Police Force over the years--

TALK.START.PARA: —I never thought of Western Australia as Camelot!

—Perhaps that is symptomatic. The record shows that the Queensland Police Commissioner has been put in gaol for 14 years for receiving bribes. He is not the only one. There is a long list of police officers in Queensland who have failed to discharge their duties and responsibilities honestly and honourably. It may not be a reflection upon the police Minister, but it is a statement of fact as to the state of the police force. New South Wales has had more than its share of problems with the police force. The greatest problem there was to find a police commissioner who was honest and, having found one, the State Government was terrified he would retire as another one could not be found. Yet these various State police Ministers have the impertinence to suggest that the Federal Parliament does not have a role in examining and supervising, in even a very superficial way, the conduct of the National Crime Authority-a creature of Federal legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: We can go to the other States. There seem to be a few problems in Tasmania at the moment, if my memory serves me correctly. I seem to recall that a very senior police officer in South Australia was gaoled for trafficking in prohibited substances. There have been more than a few problems in Victoria. I find it amazing that these police Ministers collectively suggest that they have some greater ability or capacity to supervise the NCA, given the history of their own States and the history thus far of the NCA. I hope that they will desist from that absurd proposition.

There is a suggestion that part of their motive was tied to what they described as the release of some in camera evidence. It is not a complaint made by the NCA itself; it is not an objection that Justice Phillips, the new Chairman, has expressed. Frankly, although they are not members of parliament, I am staggered that their understanding of the workings and the processes of the Federal Senate are so barren that they made that observation-not, I hope, in prejudice, but simply in stupid ignorance. If they can find something in the in camera evidence which was tabled that compromises the conduct, activities or responsibilities of the NCA, it is best they put up or shut up. As I say, I hope it was said without having an understanding of, or a capacity to understand, the workings of this Parliament.

Another matter I want to refer to is the question of the secrecy provisions. Before doing so, I should say that I do not reflect upon the NCA in a contemporary way. I think the new directions and the way in which Justice Phillips has assumed his responsibilities, with his understanding of the steps that are required to be taken, have led us all to observe that we will see-and we are already seeing-a vastly different National Crime Authority which has a relationship with the Joint Standing Committee totally different from that which has thus far been demonstrated.

The point of having reviews is to learn from the past and assist the NCA in its own considerations. To that extent, I believe that, without exception, the manner in which Justice Phillips has dealt with the Joint Parliamentary Committee in respect of disclosures and the providing of information has been very helpful, very free and very frank. As I understand it, it is a very comfortable relationship which has not required a compromise by either us or the NCA. In fact, I think that relationship has led to a much greater understanding and sensitivity on the part of both bodies.

Senator Spindler is right: these sorts of structures and relationships have to be formalised and not based on individual goodwill. Senator Spindler knows that he has my support for the general direction which he is proposing in respect formalising the disclosure of certain information. Frankly, in my view the secrecy provisions of the Act have not been used in the spirit that was intended; rather, the Act has been used as a bar to deny the Committee proper and legitimate information.

I am sure that if the proposals which I have reflected upon and which Senator Spindler has refined are dealt with, they will guarantee a much better supervision and understanding of the NCA. Also, the effectiveness of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority should be enhanced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Madam Acting Deputy President, I thank you and Senator Spindler for indicating the support of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats for the passage of this important Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. I would like to comment on one or two of the main features of this legislation before we put the second reading motion to the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: A very important part of the necessary armoury for any society combating organised crime is, of course, to be able to offer protection to those witnesses who are courageous enough to bring forth information and good intelligence for law enforcement agencies and, perhaps, to take the role of a witness in a trial, thereby exposing themselves to considerable danger. In that situation, it is incumbent on this Government, with the support of the Parliament, to provide the maximum protection possible to such courageous persons. I believe that allowing for an extension of that offer of protection-for example, to those who are related to a witness and who themselves might be in danger-is a very sound amendment; it is one which will ensure that the detection, investigation and prosecution of major crime figures in Australia can continue in a way which does not leave in real jeopardy the families of those who offer to assist.

Secondly, the Bill in a main way deals with the Cash Transaction Reports Act. That Act requires cash dealers to report to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency those transactions where the dealer has reasonable grounds to suspect that the cash transaction has relevance to tax evasion, a Commonwealth offence or the enforcement of the Proceeds of Crime Act. This is extremely important in terms of pursuing the money trail.

The old type of policing meant waiting for a crime to occur and trying to gather evidence to find out who did it. The new method, in relation to the huge flows of money that are generated by drug trafficking and some forms of major fraud and tax evasion, is to look for unexplained large amounts of money in banks, credit unions, building societies, casino accounts and so on. If there is not an apparent legitimate business generation of those moneys, perhaps one may point in the direction of an organised crime figure.

So, following the money trail is extremely important. It is very important that cash dealers report when they form a reasonable suspicion that a cash deposit might be relevant to a Commonwealth offence, a proceeds of crime offence or tax evasion. In that situation it is important to protect, for example, the bank teller. This was mentioned by Senator Vanstone. Section 16(5) of the Act provides protection against legal proceedings for cash dealers in relation to any action they take to fulfil this reporting requirement that the Parliament imposes on them. A leading firm of solicitors has raised a question as to whether, if all the pre-conditions set out in section 16(1) are not absolutely meticulously fulfilled, the cash dealer may not be able to claim the protection against legal action contained in section 16(5). This may be relevant where a teller is mistaken as to whether the transaction is relevant to tax evasion, a law of the Commonwealth or a State offence. It would be most unfortunate if the teller were placed in a difficult position in that regard.

The Director of the Agency has written to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) concerning the matter. Whilst the solicitor's advice does not accord with the best advice available to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency, it is thought that, because of the concern it is causing in some banks, it may be well to put the matter beyond doubt by putting forward this amendment. That is what we are attempting to do.

Mr Acting Deputy President, in relation to the following of the money trail by the Cash Transaction Reports Agency, which is so important, we have to recognise that that money trail may extend beyond the Australian jurisdiction. You would be well aware from sitting on the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority of the fact that money laundering, such an important facet and underpinning activity of organised criminal activity, knows no national boundaries.

Under the amendment proposed in this Bill, if the Attorney-General is satisfied that a foreign country has given appropriate undertakings as to confidentiality and control of the information, he can communicate certain information relating to the money trail to that foreign country. This would depend upon the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 which has already been well canvassed in this Parliament and is part of that international framework now which is emerging and greatly strengthening the hand of governments determined to wipe out organised criminal activity when it spills over from one national territory to another.

The Bill also amends the Act to enable the Agency to give access to information to a wider range of domestic law enforcement agencies; namely, the Criminal Justice Commission of Queensland, and the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales. They need also to have the ability to investigate financial information and to conduct financial investigations particularly in relation to corruption. It is is a very real concern of all of us, and the Opposition has expressed that concern forcibly today. The investigative functions of those bodies will be greatly assisted by access to CTR information. I understand Mr Goss and Mr Greiner have written to the Government requesting that extension be undertaken; that will be done in this Bill.

Finally, in relation to this Agency, the Bill contains a provision requiring the Director to provide the Attorney-General with an annual report on the operations of the Agency. I did not quite understand Senator Vanstone's point in so far as it is clear that the Director of the Agency, as soon as practicable after 30 June each year, must make a report. That has to be then tabled within 15 parliamentary sitting days of the reception by the Attorney-General of the report. I think that might satisfy Senator Vanstone. I think she wanted a more rigid timetable in relation to reporting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not see why there should not be a time set in which it has to be done.
—In effect, it will be because obviously it will be about 15 sitting days into the Budget session of each parliament--
—A time set by which time the Director should have completed his report, rather than `as soon as practicable'.

—The Director is required, as soon as practicable, after 30 June in each year-which would probably be during the winter recess, admittedly-to prepare and furnish to the Minister a report of the operations of the Agency during the previous year. Under section 34c of the Acts Interpretation Act the Minister is required to table the report in Parliament within 15 sitting days after the report is received by him.
—He might not receive it for three months.

—I take Senator Vanstone's point, but one can expect, generally speaking, that within 15 sitting days of the Budget session that will occur, and it should occur. It is very proper that the Parliament should review and be in a position to review this important Agency.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also amends provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act which allow for certain matters to be undertaken there. It amends the National Crime Authority Act to give the ACT Government the same status as the State and Northern Territory governments. This will allow it to participate in the activities of the Inter-governmental Committee. In relation to that, Mr Acting Deputy President, you left the chair to make a well-modulated intervention in the debate. But you were, unfortunately, because of electorate duties, unable to attend the discussions held on 25 July between the Inter-governmental Committee and the Joint Committee on the issues raised in the submission of the IGC to the PJC.

I can assure you they were held in extremely good spirit and were very constructive. Further discussions, I understand, will be held on 24 October in Melbourne between the two committees. From my observation of the conduct of that consultation between the two important committees, we are in a situation where Australian democratic values in relation to this extraordinarily powerful agency can be asserted. It is very important that, where we have a body such as the National Crime Authority vested with powers to compel answers and the production of documents, which conducts its hearings in private in order to assemble admissible evidence for legal proceedings to be conducted by the Directors of Public Prosecution, and exercising those sorts of powers, it does not get out of the control of the elected representatives of the Australian people.

I believe that between the Inter-governmental Committee, where we have those Ministers responsible in all the jurisdictions of Australia meeting, and the Parliamentary Joint Committee, one has a sufficient array of such protection on behalf of the people. The question of the demarcation between the proper role of each of those committees is of course the very substance of those discussions which are being conducted in a very good spirit.

Finally, I mention the amendments. As a result of the initiatives of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, the Bill contains amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act and the Passports Act which are designed to render more effective the existing power of the Minister under the Passports Act to cancel or refuse to issue a passport to persons charged with or convicted of a serious narcotics offence or other prescribed offence against a Commonwealth or Territory law. That is most important also.
I believe I have outlined sufficiently the purpose of the Bill. I hope that it will have a reasonably speedy passage. I commend the second reading to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the second reading debate I indicated that the Opposition had eight amendments to move in relation to this Bill which could conveniently be lumped into two groups, the first group being amendments one to three and the second group being amendments four to eight. As it is now clear that the Democrats do not wish to support any of those amendments there seems little purpose in dividing them into those two groups so as to give the Democrats that opportunity. Given the time constraint on us and the desire of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) and of all honourable senators to get this legislation passed and to move on to the next piece of legislation and possibly get that done before lunchtime, the coalition would be happy to move its amendments in one block. I seek leave to move the eight amendments together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 2, page 1, after subclause (1), insert the following subclause:
``(1a) Section 11a and paragraph 12(aa) commence 4 months after the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent.''.
2. After clause 11, page 4, insert the following clause:
Interpretation

``21a. Sections 31 to 44 of the Principal Act are repealed and the following sections are substituted:
Interpretation
`31. In this Part, unless the contrary intention appears:

Corruption relating to offences
`33.(1) A person who is:

must not ask for or receive or obtain a benefit for himself or herself or for another person on account of an act done or to be done by the person in relation to that exercise or performance or that capacity, as the case may be, with a view to:

a benefit for any person on account of an act of the kind referred to in paragraph (l) (c), (d) or (e) on the part of a person referred to in paragraph (l) (a) or (b).

False evidence etc.
`34.(1) A person must not, in evidence given in a judicial proceeding:

intending to induce the other person or a third person:

`38.(1) A person must not cause or procure, or threaten to cause or procure, any violence, injury or damage (whether to a person or to property) on account of anything said or done by:

in the course of, or in relation to, the proceeding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to indicate very briefly the Government's opposition to these amendments. In relation to the amendments proposed by the Opposition to the Cash Transaction Reports Act we do not believe that they will have the desired effect of limiting the scope of what is required to be reported because it still leaves the large area of tax evasion and the Proceeds of Crime Act matters which a cash dealer has to be concerned with.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's main opposition to these amendments is that the Opposition's amendments specify a large number of State offences, for example, murder and kidnapping, which are beyond the reach of Commonwealth criminal law, and I am not quite certain of the capacity of the dealers to deal with those matters.

The Director of the Agency has refined the guidelines for cash dealers to assist them in reporting suspect transactions. These guidelines now emphasise major corporate offences, money laundering and drug trafficking. It is a more appropriate response to focus suspect reporting on major crime than I believe the Opposition amendment, if it were carried, would achieve.

In relation to matters arising from the private member's Bill of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) on crimes, bribery and corruption matters, it is substantially based on the fourth interim report of the Gibbs Committee of Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law. It should be noted that the Gibbs Committee found existing laws adequate to deal with the offering and acceptance of bribes in circumstances involving a corrupt discharge of official duties or a corrupt failure to perform official duties under the existing applicable principles of criminal responsibility.

Once these principles are reformed and reformulated, the recommendations in the fourth interim report, including those as to bribery and corruption, may need further review. However, in so far as what is proposed to be done relies on the criminal responsibility recommendations contained in the third report, quite frankly the Government is not yet in a position, given the way in which matters of criminal responsibility are being discussed between the Commonwealth and the States-and very fruitfully, I may say-to support the implementation of the matters in the fourth report at the moment.

In other words, the Opposition's Bill is drafted on the premise of a set of principles of criminal responsibility that not only differ from the present scheme of Commonwealth criminal law, but also may not be enacted, at least in their current form. It is mainly on those grounds that the Government is unable to support these particular amendments. However, I may say that the Government looks forward to the continued work of various inter-jurisdictional conferences. I spoke at a dinner in Brisbane in relation to one in April, focusing on the principles of criminal responsibility. I believe there is a real possibility-and it is a great challenge to this Federation-that the basis for a uniform Australian criminal code could be emerging. I believe that is worth pursuing and that such a major reform ought not be tackled piecemeal and indirectly, as would be the case were this set of Opposition amendments to be carried.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF PROCESS AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 June 1991, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition supports the Service and Execution of Process Amendment Bill 1991, which is about the service of subpoenas and warrants. However, this legislation involves an extraordinary saga for which I hope the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) can offer some explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister will well know that back in 1982 the then Acting Attorney-General, the Hon. Neil Brown, QC, gave the Australian Law Reform Commission a reference to examine the operation of the principal Act. The Commission was asked specifically to consider whether the Act should be extended to cover administrative tribunals. That was back in 1982; in 1987 the Law Reform Commission report No. 40 on the service and execution of process was released.

We find that on 24 August 1990-a little under a year ago-the Attorney-General, Mr Michael Duffy, announced that new procedures were to be introduced for the conduct of interstate implementation of that particular report. He said that the Government had agreed to repeal and replace the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901, and that it had agreed to do so following consideration of recommendations made by the Australian Law Reform Commission in its report on the service and execution of process. So the situation is that in 1982 the then Acting Attorney-General of a coalition government referred this matter to the Law Reform Commission; in 1987 the Law Reform Commission reported and a little less than a year ago the present Attorney-General, the Hon. Michael Duffy, said, `Yes, we have considered what the Law Reform Commission had to say; we are going to repeal the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901 and we are going to replace it'. He went on to outline some of the significant reforms that he thought would be undertaken as a consequence of picking up the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission reporting on a reference given to it in 1982 by a coalition government.

Now we find that irrespective of what was said last year and irrespective of the fact that this Government on many occasions-as honourable senators who serve on delegated legislation committees or who serve, as I do, on the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills will know-expects people to rely on government by press release. Frequently we find that press releases are put out saying that as of tomorrow or next week a law is going to change in this or that particular way, and members of the public should be on notice from that time that is what the law will be. It may take months for the Government to produce that legislation and if, when it does produce it, anyone says, `Oh, this is retrospective legislation because you are purporting to change people's rights and responsibilities by changing the law back to the date of the press release', the Government says, `Oh no, you can't say that because no-one is disadvantaged; they were all put on notice by virtue of the press release that the law was going to change'. So while the law may not have changed at day one, the public knew it was going to change and so they were not disadvantaged. Therefore, it is acceptable and satisfactory-as the Government has frequently said in its nine and a bit years of office, as it dwindles into its last year-for the Government to issue a press release saying it is going to do something and we should all rely on it.

Had we relied on the Attorney-General's press release of 24 August last year, today we would be expecting to deal with the total repeal of the Service and Execution of Process Act and its replacement, and we are not dealing with that. Quite simply we are dealing with an amendment. The Government has decided that it is all too hard to do what it bravely announced 12 months ago it was going to do and what it supposedly got some credit for among those who would like to see law reform proceeding; now the Government is saying, `It is all a bit hard and difficult, and we have a bit too much to do so we will just do a bit of it'. That is typical of the piecemeal fashion in which this Government approaches so many matters. That is why the coalition supports this Bill, because at least what it is doing is not a bad thing. The coalition is saying that it feels the legislation does not go far enough.

I now take the opportunity to foreshadow that on behalf of the Opposition a large number of amendments will be moved en bloc, which are designed to supplement the provisions of this Bill. Pursuant to paragraph 51(xxiv) of the Constitution, the Commonwealth has the power to make laws with respect to the service and execution throughout the Commonwealth of civil and criminal process and the judgments of the courts of the States. Under this power, the first Commonwealth Government passed the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901, which applies only to courts. This Bill amends that Act to provide for interstate service of subpoenas issued by investigative tribunals. These are defined in the Bill to be a person appointed by the Governor of a State or under State law or a body established under State law for the purpose of inquiring into and reporting on any matter but do not include a court or a judge, magistrate, coroner or court officer.

Under this Bill, the Supreme Court of a State or Territory will be able to give leave to serve interstate a subpoena requiring attendance at, or provision of documents or things to, an investigative tribunal. A Supreme Court will also be able to authorise the interstate apprehension of a person who has failed to comply with such a subpoena. Pursuant to proposed section 19e, it will be permissible to produce or serve a copy of a document. Before a court can give leave for a subpoena to be served interstate it must be satisfied that the evidence sought is relevant and cannot reasonably be obtained from a person within the State.

The Service and Execution of Process Act provides for the service of initiating process for civil and criminal proceedings in State or Territory courts outside the State or Territory concerned; the service of other process in proceedings throughout Australia; the execution of other warrants for the apprehension of persons throughout Australia; and the recognition and enforcement of judgments, given by a court of one State or Territory, in another. The Act applies only to courts.

Madam Acting Deputy President, as I said before you took the chair, this matter was referred to the Law Reform Commission in 1982, whose report was issued in June 1987. The Commission expressed the view that the Act should be modernised and that its reach should be extended to investigative and adjudicative tribunals. It also made recommendations about the manner in which interstate process should be served and about appropriate safeguards in relation to such service.

As I have pointed out previously, in August last year the Attorney-General announced his intention to implement the Commission's recommendations. But this Bill simply does not do that. It deals only with the recommendations relating to interstate service of process for investigative tribunals. These new procedures would be available for inquiries such as royal commissions in Western Australia, South Australia, Tasmania and Victoria; for the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales; and the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland.

It is interesting to note that of all the Law Reform Commission's recommendations the Government has chosen to implement only those which are somewhat controversial. They are controversial because it is arguable whether the Commonwealth has the power to make a law about service and execution of process in relation to investigative tribunals under section 51(xxiv) of the Constitution, given that this placitum refers specifically to courts.

The Opposition is of the view that it would be preferable to introduce the entirety of the Law Reform Commission's recommendations. We are therefore proposing amendments to achieve that aim. Our amendments provide for the provisions relating to investigative tribunals to commence immediately, and for the remaining provisions to commence one year later in order to allow sufficient time for community consultation.

I would appreciate it if, in the speeches of the Australian Democrats and the Minister in responding, they could give an explanation as to why this matter ought to be proceeded with now, but not the other matters put forward by the Law Reform Commission. A little less than a year ago, the Government took the opportunity to get itself some publicity and announced that it was going to go ahead with these recommendations, and now it purports to proceed with only part of them.

The reason given by the Attorney-General-if I am correct-is that because of the Government's heavy legislative program the replacement Bill will not be ready for introduction until the next sitting. The Minister knew about this in August last year. We still cannot go ahead with the whole thing so we are going to do it bit by bit. What is the Government's explanation for not being ready with the whole thing and what is the Democrat's explanation for not supporting the changes that would implement the Law Reform Commission's recommendations?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is debating the Service and Execution of Process Amendment Bill 1991 which provides for interstate service of subpoenas issued by investigative tribunals. The Bill, which the Australian Democrats support, originated from the Australian Law Reform Commission report of 1987 entitled Service and Execution of Process which dealt with the adequacy of the law relating to the service and execution of the civil and criminal process throughout the Commonwealth, and the judgments in the current courts of the States and Territories. A perceived need for streamlining the interstate process was also part of the basis for inquiry and consideration of the desirability of extending the provisions of the Act to cover tribunals which carry out adjudicative or investigative functions.

SPEECH.PARA: I share Senator Vanstone's concern that the Government is not ready to introduce a Bill to implement all of the ALRC recommendations. However, this is a factual situation. I believe it would be premature to support now the amendments proposed by the Opposition. We have had advice that there would be some difficulties with the implementation of those amendments as they stand, so the Australian Democrats prefer to wait until the next session of Parliament when the Government will be ready to replace the present Bill with one which is thought through and carefully drafted to meet its requirements. We also accept that this amendment is an urgent one and we believe it should be supported.

The Bill proposes to insert a new part 3a into the Act to enable royal commissions and other investigative tribunals to serve subpoenas on persons interstate and to force such persons to give evidence at investigative tribunals. As I said, the Australian Democrats support this purpose which we see as being a useful step in the consolidation of a national legal system even if it is, as Senator Vanstone has said, to some extent piecemeal.

However, there is one major concern, and that is with clause 5 of the Bill which proposes to insert a new part 3a into the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901. Division 4 of the proposed new part 3a deals with the execution of warrants issued by, or out of, a court or investigative tribunals. The proposed new section 19z sets out the procedure to be followed after a person has been apprehended pursuant to such a warrant. The section provides that, as soon as practicable after being apprehended, a person is to be brought before a magistrate.

Proposed new subsection (2) provides that a copy of a warrant, if it is available, must be produced to the magistrate. Proposed new subsection (3) provides that, if a copy of the warrant is not produced the magistrate may, under subsection (b):
(b) adjourn the proceedings for such reasonable time, not exceeding seven days, as the magistrate specifies and remand the person on bail or in such custody as the magistrate specifies.

This means that, for whatever reason, if the warrant for the apprehension of the person is not produced at the initial appearance, a person may be remanded on bail or in custody for up to seven days in order to allow the arresting officers time to produce the warrant. I believe this matter was dealt with by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills which expressed considerable concern that a person, through no fault of his or her own, should be kept in custody possibly for up to seven days-and this is in the age when fax machines and other means of communication have been updated and are generally available to the community.

The Australian Democrats believe this time period is excessive. I am told by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate)-and I would like him to address this point-that it would not be convenient to accede to the amendment which I am proposing, which aims to reduce the time from seven days to four days, because this Bill should be processed quickly through the Parliament.

I find it somewhat extraordinary that we should disregard what is essentially a very important civil liberties issue on the basis of the convenience of parliamentary procedures and a delay of only several days. I draw the comparison that the delay that the Minister is trying to avoid is equal to the time that a person might be kept in gaol pending the production of a warrant. I believe that the Minister should reconsider and that the Government should support the amendment that I will move on behalf of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank those honourable senators who have indicated support for the Service and Execution of Process Amendment Bill. I understand that the Opposition would have liked to have a more comprehensive amendment or a substitution of the new Bill dealing with service and execution of process in this federation. The reason why the Government wanted to bring forward this matter relating to the relatively restricted area to do with tribunals is that initially Mr Justice Kennedy, the Chairman of the Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters, requested an urgent amendment to enable the interstate service of subpoenas requiring people to give evidence before investigative tribunals, such as royal commissions.

SPEECH.PARA: As late as this morning I was informed by Mr D. F. Wicks, the principal solicitor assisting the Western Australian Royal Commission, that the Commission wishes to call several interstate witnesses, including major players, who have queried the Commission's capacity to require them to give evidence. The Commission has informed them that it does not have that power at present but that a Bill to confer that power is before the Commonwealth Parliament. Mr Wicks believes that if the Bill is not passed these persons will not give evidence. That is the basis for the concern that has been expressed by the Government, although it does not meet all the points that Senator Spindler has raised in relation to the particular matter which is the subject of his amendment.

I need to emphasise that the seven-day period is an absolute limit. It is an absolute maximum. Under the Bill, where the warrant or a copy of it is not produced, the proceeding must be adjourned for a reasonable time, not exceeding seven days. What is a reasonable time will depend upon the circumstances of each case. In particular, it would depend upon what would be a reasonable time to send the warrant or a copy of it to the place at which the proceedings are being heard. In order to minimise the time that an apprehended person may possibly be remanded, proposed new sections 19e and 19z permit production of a facsimile copy of the warrant. In most cases this will both minimise the likelihood that a copy of the warrant will not be available when a person is taken before the magistrate and, where a copy is not available, be a strong factor in determining what is a reasonable period for the adjournment.

The seven-day upper limit, which was recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission in its report Service and Execution of Process, takes account of the possibility that a person may be apprehended in a remote location. I believe that that gives an indication that it would be an extremely rare event for the seven-day limit to be reached, because it is an upper limit within which we have a reasonable time requirement. Given the existence of facsimiles and so on, it is very unlikely that that seven-day upper limit will be reached.

Given that fact, which I think we can fairly predict, and the urgency as perceived by the Western Australian Royal Commission, rather than accepting the amendment put forward by the Australian Democrats, which I agree has some merit, which would require sending the Bill back to the House of Representatives for passage some time next week-if we were fortunate, given the constraints of the Budget presentation and other matters that are pressing in that chamber-I think we would do better as a chamber to accept the present clause as drafted and understand the concerns of Senator Spindler but not accede to them on this occasion.

The Bill deals with the most important matter of the interstate service and interstate enforcement of tribunal subpoenas. There are many such tribunals, royal commissions and standing commissions of inquiry operating throughout Australia. They will all be greatly aided by this provision, which will help to do what the Premiers Conference did-it did not actually deal with it specifically but did so in spirit-and simply act as Australians in the Federal system. After all, this is a chamber which reflects that Federal system. We are attempting to ensure that the legacy of colonial boundaries which divide jurisdictions in such an artificial way when it comes to the proper functioning of our courts, tribunals and royal commissions should not impede or frustrate proper evidence being required to be given to assist, in this case, royal commissions and tribunals of inquiry.

I wish the Bill, as drafted, a speedy passage. In relation to the larger matter moved by the Opposition, quite clearly, the Opposition amendments, in taking up the Law Reform Commission report, represent an attempt to implement a very major law reform initiative. I can assure Senator Vanstone that, with the extensive consultations with the States and Territories on the ALRC's report, the Government is well advanced. I hope that it will be possible by the end of this session to have a Bill presented to the Parliament dealing with the larger context of this matter of such concern in our federation. On the basis of the urgency of this Bill, I commend its speedy passage to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

Clause 5, page 11, proposed paragraph 19z(3) (b), line 5, omit ``7'', substitute ``4''.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reasons indicated, the Government will not be supporting that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is perhaps appropriate to indicate why the coalition will not be supporting this amendment. The Australian Democrats are in a peculiar position of being able to know in advance what both parties are going to move as amendments to pieces of legislation by looking at the House of Representatives Hansard. Of course, neither the Government nor the Opposition is in a position to have any advance notice of what the Democrats intend to move by way of amendment. I do not say on my Party's behalf that four days is an unsuitable time as opposed to seven. I have not sought consultation on that. The reason for that is that, while this piece of paper has wafted in front of me, I do not know whether consultation has been had with the Government. It has certainly not been had, as I understand it, with the Opposition. It is simply not the appropriate way to make a change, albeit one that may be a good one.

SPEECH.PARA: My Party may believe that it is a bad one. The Democrats, who say that they want a proper consultation and review and the legislative process to work as it ought to work-that is, with each clause being scrutinised properly-have the advantage of being able to see in the House of Representatives what is going to be debated in this chamber, save and except for other occasions when new amendments are brought in.

Where either the Government or the coalition wishes to bring in new amendments, that is, ones that have not been flagged in the House of Representatives, we-and I am speaking for the coalition; I am not purporting to speak on this matter on the Government's behalf as well, but I think that the Government is in the same position-have Buckley's of getting some agreement to those if we have not given advance notice of them. This is the situation this morning. It is for that reason that the coalition will not be supporting this amendment at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note Senator Vanstone's comments. I am sympathetic to their content because quite often we find that adequate consultation has not happened. The reason for the amendment being submitted at such a late stage without prior consultation is that we are still awaiting a report from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has put out a report raising this particular concern and has written to the Minister. I understand that the Minister has provided a reply, but the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has not as yet been able to address the Minister's reply. Neither this chamber nor the Australian Democrats has a report from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this unseemly haste on the part of the Government is almost in contempt of parliament. If a committee is charged with a duty to investigate, peruse and report on legislation, then to proceed with that legislation in the chamber without awaiting the report of that important Committee is a breach of parliamentary convention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee I would like briefly to add some comments. Do I take it from Senator Spindler's remarks that the Australian Democrats in future will decide their voting practices in relation to matters that have been before the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in accordance with what the Scrutiny of Bills Committee says? He appears to be saying that the matter has been raised, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has not yet issued a report with a response from the Minister, therefore, this matter should be put forward. I assume that the Democrats will, therefore, use that explanation for every other Scrutiny of Bills Committee matter that is raised, and not exercise some independent discretion.

SPEECH.PARA: I am gratified that the Democrats take so much notice of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I just wish that on every other occasion they did the same-they do not appear to be agreeing to do that on all other occasions. I do not think that is an adequate explanation at all. In fact, if the matter is being raised because the Scrutiny of Bills Committee first raised this matter, why was the amendment not floated at that time, pending withdrawal if the Scrutiny of Bills Committee decided it was acceptable?

There is no embarrassment here for Senator Spindler. All of us face situations where amendments come to mind at the last minute and we have to seek the indulgence of each other. However, the risk is that those of us who have not had time to consult with our parties cannot support the amendments. My remarks are not meant as any attack, but as an explanation as to why the Democrats cannot ask other parties to support them without having flagged the amendment which, by Senator Spindler's own mouth, he was aware of as soon as the first report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee came out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand Senator Vanstone's remarks. However, I must reject them to the extent that they try to tell us a method of considering legislation. I believe that the deliberations and the function of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee are an important component of the parliamentary procedure. I simply state that it is logical, and within the principles of parliamentary procedures, to give due consideration to the report of the Committee that has been established for that very purpose. Of course, we will exercise independent judgment, but I would submit that this Parliament should not ignore the advice of a committee which has been established for the purpose of providing that particular advice.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now my turn to seek support for a matter, the details of which, as I understand it, are not before all parties. That is why I was quick to say that we all have embarrassing moments. We have one coming up. I am not sure whether it is the fault of the coalition or whether there has been some administrative tinkering in the works and a muck-up. The situation is that the coalition wishes to move a batch of amendments which are not available for distribution. I do have a clean copy-save and except for my signature being on it-of the amendments as moved in the House of Representatives which, fortunately, therefore, the Australian Democrats and the Government will have had clear and extensive notice of our intention to move.

—It is rather unusual for us to proceed to amendments if the amendments have not been distributed. If it is the wish of the Committee that we do proceed, I shall do so. Is it the wish of the Committee that we do proceed? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 2, page 1, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Commencement
``2.(1) Except as provided in subsection (2), this Act commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.
``(2) Subject to subsection, (3) sections 2A, 2B, 2C and 5A commence on a day or days to be fixed by Proclamation.

``(3) If a provision referred to in subsection (2) does not commence within the period of one year starting on the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent, it commences on the first day after the end of that period.''.
(2) After clause 2, page 1, insert the following clause:
``2a. Section 3 of the Principal Act is repealed and the following section substituted:
Interpretation
``3. In this Act-

``adjudicative function'', in relation to a tribunal, means the function of determining the rights or liabilities of a person, including the function of making a determination altering those rights or liabilities;
``Australia'', when used in a geographical sense, includes each external Territory;
``authority'' means a judge, magistrate, coroner or officer of a court appointed or holding office under a law of a State or Territory;
``civil proceedings'' means a proceeding other than a criminal proceeding;
``court'' means a court of a State or Territory and includes an authority exercising the powers of a court;
``court of issue'', in relation to a process, means the court by or out of which the process was issued and ``authority of issue'' has a corresponding meaning;
``criminal proceeding'' means-
(a) a prosecution for an offence;
(b) a procedure, other than a prosecution, that, under a law of a State or Territory, may be used to determine liability for an offence or to impose a penalty for an offence;
(c) a proceeding that is related to or associated with a prosecution for an offence or a procedure referred to in paragraph (b); or
(d) a proceeding for relief the right to which arises from the conviction or charging of, or an intention to charge, a person in relation to an offence,
but does not include a claim for compensation;
``initiating process'' means a process by which a proceeding is commenced or by reference to which a person becomes a party to a proceeding;
``investigative function'', in relation to a tribunal, means the function of conducting an inquiry other than an inquiry conducted in connection with the exercise of an adjudicative function;
``judgment'' means-

(a) a judgment, decree or order given, entered or made in a civil proceeding under which a sum of money is made payable or a person is required to do or not to do an act or thing other than the payment of money;

(b) an order made in a criminal proceeding under which a sum of money is made payable as a debt due to the Crown in right of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory or a person is required to do or not to do an act or thing other than the payment of money; or
(c) an order of a tribunal that is enforceable without an order of a court,
whether or not the judgment or order is final, but does not include-
(d) a judgment or order of a court or tribunal of a foreign country that has been registered in a court in Australia; or
(e) an order, however described, imposing a fine;
``magistrate'' includes a justice of the peace who has the power, under a law of the State or Territory in which the justice holds the office, to issue warrants;
``order for production'' means an order made under subsection 41(1) or paragraph 60(1) (c) or 62(1) (c);
``person under lawful restraint'' means a person who-
(a) is in lawful custody;
(b) by law is not allowed to leave a State or Territory without permission; or

(c) must comply with a condition imposed by, or by authority of, a law that makes provision for imposing conditions as to the conduct of persons charged with, convicted of or sentenced for an offence,
and ``lawful restraint'' has a corresponding meaning;
``place of issue'', in relation to a process, means the State or Territory in which the process was issued;
``proceeding'', except in Part IV, means a civil proceeding or a criminal proceeding in a court or before an authority and includes-

(b) to produce a document or thing to a court, authority or person;
``tribunal'' means a person, or a body established by or under a law of a State or Territory, authorised by or under such a law to take evidence on oath or affirmation, but does not include-
(a) a court; or
(b) a person exercising a power conferred on the person as a judge, magistrate, coroner or officer of a court;
``warrant'' means a process issued in accordance with-
(a) a law of a State or Territory; or

that authorises the apprehension of a person.'.''.
(3) After clause 2, page 1, insert the following clause:
``2b. After section 3 of the Principal Act the following sections are inserted:
Act to bind Crown
`3a. This Act binds the Crown in all its capacities.
Application of State and Territory Laws
`3b. (1) This Act does not affect a power of a court or tribunal to allow substituted service of a process.

`(2) This Act does not affect the operation of the Transfer of Prisoners Act 1983 or a law of a State or the Northern Territory that, in an instrument published pursuant to section 5 of that Act, is declared to be a State transfer law of the State.

Custodians

`3c. (1) In relation to a person referred to in paragraph (a) of the definition of ``person under lawful restraint'' in section 3, ``custodian'' means a person who has the actual custody of the person.

`(2) In relation to a person referred to in paragraph (b) of the definition of ``person under lawful restraint'' in section 3, ``custodian'' means a person who may lawfully give permission for the person to leave the State or Territory.

`(3) In relation to a person referred to in paragraph (c) of the definition of ``person under lawful restraint'' in section 3, ``custodian'' means a person who by law is responsible for supervising compliance with the condition.

`(2) For the purposes of this Act, a document produced as mentioned in subsection (1) that is identical to a process, order or document in all material respects may be taken to be a copy of the process, order or document.
Personal service on natural persons
`3e. (1) For the purposes of this Act, personal service of a process, order or document may be effected on a natural person-
(a) by giving the process, order or document, or a copy of the process, order or document, to the person; or

(b) if the person refuses to accept service by putting the process, order or document, or a copy of the process, order or document, down in the person's presence and telling the person, in general terms, the nature of the process, order or document.
`(2) In addition to subsection (1), where-
(a) a process, order or document, or a copy of the process, order or document, has been sent in a postal article by pre-paid post to a person; and

`3g. (1) In addition to sections 3e and 3f, personal service of a process, order or document may, for the purposes of this Act, be effected in accordance with an agreement between a person by or on whose behalf a process, order or document is to be served and the person to be served with the process, order or document.

Service by post

`3h. (1) For the purposes of this Act, service of a process, order or document by post on a person or body corporate that has given an address for service may be effected by sending the process, order or document, or a copy of the process, order or document, by pre-paid post to the person or body corporate at that address.

`(2) For the purposes of this Act, service of a process, order or document by post on a person who has not given an address for service may be effected by sending the process, order or document, or a copy of the process, order or document, by pre-paid post to the person at the address of the place of residence or business of the person last known to the person by or on whose behalf the process or document is to be served.

`(3) For the purposes of this Act, service of a process, order or document by post on a body corporate that has not given an address for service may be effected by sending the process, order or document, or a copy of the process, order or document, by pre-paid post to the body corporate at the address of the office that is the local office of the body corporate for the purposes of subsection 3f(1).
