The former Leader of the Australian Democrats, Janine Haines, is consistently on the record as holding very firm views about the need to contain, regulate and probably ban electoral advertising, but that was before recent events.

It is good to see that both major contenders to the throne of the Democrats are here. From my discussions with Democrats in this place, I think there has been a recognition by all of them. Senator Coulter and the rest of the Democrats come into this place as great Green candidates. But the real issue confronting them now is whether they leave this process as the Green party or as the greenback dollar party. What are the Democrats trying to protect if they do not do something about containing electoral costs?

One wonders why the Democrats have not come up with the goods in the last few months. Of course, there is leadership paralysis and there is no cohesive approach. They would acknowledge that. No comprehensive model has been put up by them. But I would hate to think that it was because of the influence of, say, Mr Goldsworthy in his correspondence to Heather Southcott in South Australia imploring the Democrats not to support the Government; and I would hate to think that it was the Liberals' intellectually and politically dishonest campaign in recent weeks-a campaign that did not ignite public opinion and public support but which seems to have ignited those closet Liberals and Democrats in Queensland. I would hate even more to suggest or even think that it has been because of the foresters' campaign. For example, yesterday we saw the great headline, `Democrats urged to reject ban'. The article reads:
The forest industry has urged the Australian Democrats to reject the Federal Government's proposed limited ban on political advertising on radio and television-
because-
it was opposed to any ban that could affect its ability to promote the industry.

They should go back to their Green mates if they cannot grapple with this issue fully and properly. The Democrats have got to ask themselves what sort of interests they are protecting and what they will be subjecting the Australian political process to if they do not come across on this particular issue.

It is now our turn to keep the Australian Democrats honest and that is why we are taking the approach of sending the whole Bill to the parliamentary committee. Our approach maintains the pressure and keeps both aspects alive. But in particular let me say one thing with respect to keeping the Liberals honest. In recent days I have been concerned about disclosure-and I know that Senator Powell has as well. The real motive behind the Liberals wanting to defer this matter to a never-ending committee-as does the Olsen proposal-is that they want time. They want time because the reports are wide and they are running. In fact, Senator Olsen, in the business community the cat is out of the bag. The Liberals are in the process of setting up a nationally, if not internationally, based slush fund-a trust account-to pre-empt, to beat this disclosure provision.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an absolute fabrication.

—It is no fabrication. They would not tell Senator Parer. As I say, the cat is out of the bag and that is precisely one of the main reasons why I would like to see both parts of this legislation go to a Senate committee. This would expose the dishonest approach by those opposite to disclosure. It would also reinforce the Government's very clear position which is that one cannot just have disclosure because, for so long as there is a need to raise money, they will find other ways around it.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have had in recent days originating from the Liberal headquarters here is the state-of-the-art version of the brown paper bag. The electronic brown paper bag is being pursued through the setting up of a trust account before this legislation is put in place. From the start, our objective has been to have measures to contain costs and to ensure that political parties are subject to public scrutiny.

This need has been recognised by commission after commission. It has been highlighted by the recent action of the Liberal Party in this country-a dishonest approach to disclosure which lets the cat out of the bag in terms of their need to have this inquiry run forever. We have already had one inquiry; the issues have been canvassed. The Committee will now have to focus on the Bill and two months or so is long enough. As I say, our approach to contend and grapple with both issues is highlighted by what I have just said-we need to do both.

The experience internationally is that one cannot act effectively until one does both. As I say, that has been acknowledged even by a former leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Howard. I say to Senator Powell and Senator Coulter-I will not talk to the Opposition: this is Australia's last chance to keep the political agenda free from the corruptive influence of the corporate dollar. If they are true to their interests and stated desires, I am sure that they will cooperate fully on this committee.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, will be absent from the chamber this week. Senator Button is overseas on government business. Any questions which would normally be directed to him in relation to his portfolio should be directed to Senator Cook, and questions in relation to those portfolios Senator Button represents should be directed to me.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask whether he agrees with the discredited former Treasurer, Mr Keating, in today's Sydney Morning Herald that `the single-minded pursuit by the new Treasurer of lower inflation by enforcing high interest rates is outmoded and wrong'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The former Treasurer has the same rights as any other member of Caucus to discuss issues of interest to the community, provided, of course, that he does not attack the Government. His comments in the Sydney Morning Herald today do not constitute an attack on the Government or any member of it. I would rather describe them as a kind of wistful, wish-I-was-there contribution to the debate.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not propose to address any of the substantive issues raised by the comments. The heart of them really describes what is the essence of good government-that is to say, Ministers take quality decisions after receiving quality advice and after consultations with appropriate groups and individuals. That is the way Mr Keating conducted himself when he was Treasurer and that is the way the business of this Government is being conducted now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. In light of the Minister's answer, that he quite obviously does not agree with the discredited former Treasurer, would he agree that the only possible reason for Mr Keating's extraordinary attack on Mr Kerin in today's press is his desire to destabilise the Hawke Government and usurp the reins of power for himself?

—I have already given a response on that point. I have said that Mr Keating no doubt desires to make a constructive contribution to the debate-and he is entitled to do that from the back bench. His comments should be given only that degree of attention.

—I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to the recent Kirki incident off the Western Australian coast, an incident which continues to cause concern to all Western Australians, and to the consequent media and community concern about substandard foreign vessels plying Australian waters. I ask the Minister: what action is the Government taking to reduce the risk of a future mishap from such vessels and resultant pollution of our waters, coast, shores and wildlife?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the moment, the Kirki and a tanker into which the remaining oil from the Kirki will be transferred are off the Western Australian coast, about 30 nautical miles north of Dampier. The vessels are currently being berthed alongside each other. The authorities expect the transfer of the oil to commence this afternoon. The operation will take some four to five days.

ANSWER.PARA: The salvors have done a superlative job in averting a catastrophe. I take the opportunity to say that there is no question, particularly if anyone has actually seen the footage of the incident, that it was the quite extraordinary courage and skill of the crew of the Lady Kathleen that did substantially avert a major disaster in the ship coming ashore and breaking up. It has been their continuing professionalism in improving the buoyancy of the vessel and adjusting the trim over the last week or so that is now making the transfer of the oil possible.

The Australian Maritime Safety Authority has based oil pollution equipment at Karratha, aircraft are on stand-by during the operation should any difficulties occur, and of course the authorities will not hesitate to take action if it appears that the transfer cannot be completed safely.

Australia is a signatory to a number of international conventions dealing with both ship safety and pollution, the Geneva convention on the high seas being just one of them. This incident, of course, did occur on the high seas, outside Australia's legal jurisdiction, but it has given rise to a number of concerns that are currently being pursued.

Prior to the Kirki incident-from memory, it was about a week before-I wrote to all of my State and Territory colleagues asking for a major review to be undertaken of the national plan to combat oil pollution. I will be pursuing that request through the forum of ATAC, and I understand that in fact the next meeting of those Ministers will take place later this year in Darwin. AMSA is also investigating the possibility, which will have to be done by consultation and agreement, of having a two-stage inspection of ships that visit Australian ports. I might point out that Australia is one of only a handful of countries that carry out port inspections of ships and, of course, the safety record of our fleet is exemplary. We will also be examining whatever methods can be brought to bear to support the moves that are currently being made by the International Maritime Organisation to increase the surveillance and scrutiny of the certification of these vessels.

In addition, a very heavy responsibility, in my view, rests with the oil companies which actually own the cargoes that are carried in these ships. Since the Kirki incident I have written not just to BP but to all oil companies in Australia that use tankers, reminding them of their obligations in this regard and asking them to consider whether their policies in relation to the carriage of oil and tankers need to be reviewed. I await their response.

Australia, being largely self-sufficient in oil, is not pre-eminent in both the use of tankers or indeed the construction of tankers, but we are doing everything possible in the international forums that are available to us to increase the surveillance and certification of these ships.

When the marine investigation into the Kirki is complete, I have no doubt, from the information that has already been made available to me, that it will yield valuable information in terms of assisting Australia to make sure that an incident such as the Kirki incident does not occur again.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the July labour force figures showing that the unemployment rate for young Australians aged from 15 to 19 years looking for full time work rose to a 60-year record of 28.5 per cent seasonally adjusted, which is three times the adult rate, as more than 121,000 teenage full time jobs disappeared over the last 12 months, chopping the number of 15- to 19-year-olds in full time work in Australia from 415,000 in July last year to only 294,000. As the Government is now paying more than $350m a year to keep 170,000 year 11 and year 12 students at school, instead of them flooding into dole queues, what levels of youth unemployment does the Government expect when this dammed-up volume of school leavers spills over into the labour market next December, January and February? How long will young Australians have to put up with these record unemployment levels from the recession Mr Keating said `we had to have'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not quite correct to say, as has been widely reported, that a quarter of all those aged 15 to 19 are unemployed. It is true that 28.5 per cent of those in the full time labour force are unemployed, but they represent only just under 9 per cent of all those aged 15 to 19. A very large proportion of those aged 15 to 19 are engaged in full time education.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of the school retention rate raised by Senator Baume is a matter about which I believe the Government can feel genuinely proud, having achieved in 1990 a school retention rate of 64 per cent compared with 36 per cent when we came to office. That means that those entering the work force after that longer time in school are better educated, better trained and better equipped to find jobs in what is obviously a very difficult labour market.

We do recognise that here, as is typically the case in an economic downturn, the young people have been those hardest hit. What we have done about dealing with that is to establish active labour market programs which, together with a number of new initiatives announced in the March economic statement, ensure that education, training and employment opportunities are available for young people.

At a time of unemployment and recession, such as we are going through at the moment, it is particularly crucial that we maintain opportunities for young men and women to develop skills through apprenticeships and traineeships. We are providing about $16m extra over two years for measures to keep apprentices and trainees in employment or to help them continue training while they are unemployed. We have also allocated, it should be recalled, almost $60m over two years for extra pre-vocational training places at TAFE colleges to help young people prepare for work.

In the March economic statement, we also announced enhancements to other labour market and training programs available to young unemployed people, such as Jobtrain, Jobstart and Skillshare. Obviously, this is going to continue to be a problem and will be exacerbated when young people spill onto the employment market at the end of the school year. Our hope, and our expectation, is that we have in place policies which will now ensure a sustainable growth in activity and, with the usual lags, sustainable growth in jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I did ask the Minister how long young Australians will have to put up with these record unemployment levels, and his response was that he is putting policies in place that he hopes may, perhaps, do something about it. Can he give us any indication of how long young Australians are going to have to put up with a 28.5 per cent full time unemployment rate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The spectacularly successful exercise in bringing the inflation rate down has demonstrated that we are now in a situation of a reasonable expectation of a sustained growth of activity in the job situation.
—At what price?

—I am not going to put a figure on it; I am not going to make a prediction about what the time frame will be before the unemployment situation does turn around. We have been anticipating unhappy figures continuing for some time, but the truth of the matter is that policies are in place and they are bearing fruit.

ANSWER.PARA: Again I remind those who say, as Senator Alston did by way of interjection, `At what price?', that after the last recession we had in this country, back in the early 1980s, when the unemployment rate was higher than it is now-10.3 per cent-we had an inflation rate of 11.2 per cent, as compared with the inflation rate we now have of 3.4 per cent.

There is no necessary magical connection between recessions and lowering of the inflation rate. The only way we get a lowering of the inflation rate is by a deliberately and carefully tailored policy of the kind that we have been putting in place over a period of time. Recession may have made a contribution to that, but it is not the sole explanation for it. The reality of its existence-sustainably low inflation, markedly less than the OECD average of 6.2 per cent and markedly less than the average of our major trading partners at 4.3 per cent-has created the conditions for an economic recovery.

I remind the Opposition further that these conditions have been achieved in an environment where the participation rate, so far as employment is concerned, was very much lower back in the early 1980s than is the case now. From no point of view is it possible to argue that there is any necessary connection between the recession and inflation. It has been a very different state of affairs this time around as compared with the last time, for the reasons that are self-evident when one looks at the figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Can the Minister advise the House what progress has been made on the computer systems integration panel that was announced in the March industry statement? Can the Minister say how many companies have sought information on the proposed panel and, of these, how many are Australian companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It just so happens that I have a document here which enables me authoritatively to answer this penetrating question from Senator Maguire. In the March industry statement my colleague Senator John Button announced plans to set up a panel of systems integration companies to service major public sector information technology projects. `Systems integration' is a somewhat nebulous term to those outside the computer industry. Basically, it refers to the service of integrating the various components of a modern computer system. That might involve sourcing hardware and off-the-shelf software, developing customised software and getting systems up and running. It is a complex task, but one in which Australian companies have shown considerable skills in the past.

ANSWER.PARA: The panel will apply to all IT contracts over $1m involving systems integration, unless grounds for exemption are established. When the request for information process closed on 31 July, over 180 companies had asked for details of the panel and 80 had responded. The respondents include software, hardware and services suppliers, consultants, personnel agencies, and even universities and computer magazines. This level of interest clearly shows that the Government's policy is right for the times. I am pleased that all the major Australian companies involved in systems integration have responded to the request.

The requests for information are being analysed and will assist in providing the basis for tender specifications. The Government will issue a draft request for tender later this month, soliciting public comment on the terms of the tender by 25 September. The final request for tender will be issued in October and close on 16 October. The size and structure of the systems integration panel as well as the companies chosen for the panel will be announced by the end of the year. The panel will be reviewed every 12 to 18 months to monitor its effectiveness, to monitor the performance of companies on the panel, and perhaps to change its membership from time to time as circumstances require.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I preface my question by noting today's call by the Over 50s Friendly Society for next week's Budget to contain prudential standards for superannuation funds. I ask the Minister: does he agree that the current regulatory system applying to superannuation funds does not adequately protect members' interests? Does the Government intend to safeguard the interests of members of superannuation funds by regulating investment activity now, or will it wait for a crisis such as the unlisted property trusts fiasco before it acts? Does the Minister consider that the amount of development capital available for Australian industry is adequate? If not, why has he abandoned his attempt to establish a development capital fund to assist Australian industry to develop Australian inventions in Australia and to create jobs? Does this mean that the Government believes that deregulation is the best basis on which to manage the economy?

—As to the first two parts of that question, about whether the current regulatory system is adequate and about our intentions relating to the safeguarding of members' funds, all I can really say is that the Government has had these matters under consideration for some time and we propose to announce the results of that review shortly. As to the third part of the question, about the amount of development capital available for Australian industry, that is really a matter for Senator Button in his own ministerial capacity, and I will refer that question to him on his return.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer the Minister to his undertaking to the Senate to ask the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy to review cases of notorious bankrupts to ensure that they were not living off their assets transferred to others. Can the Minister indicate the result of that review and whether the Government is proposing to take any action in relation to high living bankrupts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that on the last day of the autumn sittings I gave an indication to the Senate that I would be asking the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy, Mr Richard Moss, to review those cases which had caused concerns and misgivings and, indeed, some anger in the Australian community in relation to certain notorious bankrupts.

ANSWER.PARA: I have received his report in respect of all of those notorious bankrupts. I do not intend to name them for the reason I will give in a moment. It can be expected that the administration of those particular estates will be particularly lengthy. He has found, from the point of view of bankruptcy administration generally, that the administrations are proceeding satisfactorily and that creditors' interests are being protected. In the case of one particular bankrupt, of course, one hopes that the new trustees recently appointed will be able to progress the administration. I have asked the Inspector-General to continue to monitor the progress of those administrations.

I believe it is important, when one is reacting to that real concern and anger out in the community at the spectacle of certain high living bankrupts appearing to live very well at a time when many Australian households are battling and their creditors are in straitened circumstances, that one does not smear or stigmatise the whole range of bankrupts who have found that conditions are such that they have had to enter into that particular arrangement provided for by our laws.

Nevertheless, the fact is that the Government has responded very firmly to the spectacle which, as I say, has angered many Australians. It has indicated, for example, in relation to travel overseas by bankrupts, that trustees will not be able to give permission for a bankrupt to travel abroad unless all the creditors have been paid in full every brass razoo that they are owed. The court may, on an application, be able to give permission for a bankrupt to travel overseas if there are compassionate grounds, for example, or if an undertaking is given in relation to employment overseas which will see creditors paid, with cast-iron guarantees as to the flow of income being available in part for the creditors. That is the second major reform.

In Australia we have extremely stringent and effective laws dealing with identifying and tracing assets that a bankrupt may, in anticipation, have transferred to a member of the family or to some other arrangement like a company, a trust or a partnership to disguise the fact that there are assets available to creditors. Whilst we have very good laws to trace those assets and make them available for creditors, we have had a very cumbersome process relating to the income which might be earned by a bankrupt. It is the Government's intention to move away from the cumbersome court process to an administrative process to enable an arrangement to be made whereby a certain level of income can remain in the hands of a bankrupt-certainly above the social security benefit, to encourage the bankrupt to enter the work force-but that a portion of the earnings ought to be available to creditors over the period of the bankruptcy. I hope to be introducing this legislation later this session. I look forward to the support of the chamber for its speedy passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Social Security to his constant protestations that there is not `one other way now that I can shave money off the social security budget', that further cuts would be cruel and unconscionable and that he has delved into the bottom of the barrel and the bottom is well and truly scraped. In the light of such bluster, can the Minister now explain why last month's dole figures suddenly show, despite there being no discernible shift in male part time employment, that the number of males on the dole nationally actually exceeds the official ABS number of unemployed males by over 21,000, implying that his Department is paying unemployment benefits to thousands of people who simply are not unemployed? Is he aware that, based on average dole payments, the full year cost of these apparent overpayments can be conservatively put at over $600m a year, or $12m per week? Is this a recent occurrence? Is it indicative of a high level of welfare fraud or simply further evidence of a total disinclination to enforce the work test? Finally, when did the Minister first become aware of this problem and what does he intend to do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The basis for ABS surveys and the basis for my own Department agreeing to claims for unemployment benefits are, of course, different. I do not think the fact that there can be a different figure out of one month is implying anything. It certainly does not imply that the Department of Social Security has stopped applying the work test, or even ceased applying it with vigour. It does not imply there have been any overpayments whatsoever. It does suggest, of course, that the numbers of those who are receiving unemployment benefits have gone up. That is a self-evident truth. Fortunately, I think, it is starting to level out, although there will be a lag with labour force figures and with the recovery generally.

ANSWER.PARA: In the course of this year, particularly since the introduction of Newstart, the Department has diligently and vigilantly applied social security law and the work test. The new arrangements for Newstart are being applied with vigour; at the same time, of course, they involve discussion and cooperation with clients, and that has gone on as well. I reject the implication that Senator Alston has made, as he sees the results of the survey, and I repeat that social security law is being applied diligently and with vigour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I asked: when did the Minister first become aware of this problem? Do I take it from his answer that he has been aware for some days or weeks? If so, does he have any explanation to offer the Senate or is he simply not interested in understanding what is causing an apparent, very significant financial difficulty for the Government?

—There is obviously a financial difficulty, as Senator Alston puts it. There is certainly an increase in expenditure when dole numbers go up. Dole numbers have gone up very substantially. I do not believe that Newstart numbers will go up substantially over the next year, but they may continue to rise for some little time. I hope it will not be by very much, but any rise will mean more expenditure. All I said was that we cannot take one survey over one period and attempt to extrapolate results from it as a truth over time. I never do that. I look at the ABS surveys as they come out and I receive reports on social security Newstart numbers as they come out, but I do not try to take a long term view from one ABS survey. I think that would be a mistake.

—Is the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs aware of many complaints about insurance across the whole of the insurance industry. I am advised, for example, that one third of complaints to State ombudsmen are about insurance. Further, some insurance companies now refer to homes in certain areas as `uninsurable'. These changes are not the responsibility of the home owners or occupiers, yet they are the ones who pay, because insurance companies say they cannot afford to continue to cover all areas. Will the Minister support a Senate inquiry through the relevant Senate standing committee into the housing, building and contents insurance industry, in particular to check consumer protection?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been aware for some time, as I am sure all honourable senators would be from matters brought to their attention in their electorate offices, of concern in the community about the insurance industry. Many complaints to do with the settlement of claims have been dealt with either by us informally or, as Senator Crowley indicates, by State ombudsmen's offices. But I believe that there has been an important development; that is, the setting up by the insurance industry of a dispute resolution process which allows for complaints about claims to be dealt with in a way which is now being very well publicised amongst policyholders, either as they take out a new policy or as they renew their policy.

ANSWER.PARA: This complaints resolution process is under the general supervision of a council headed by the former Attorney-General and Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Lionel Bowen. I hope that when it reports, after the first 12 months of operation of the various levels of this complaints resolution process, we will be in a very good position to make sure that complaints concerning the insurance industry-not only general insurance but life insurance-can be dealt with speedily, fairly, decisively and in a way which does not cost the policyholder the sorts of legal costs which are such an impediment to pursuing these complaints through the traditional legal process.

As to Senator Crowley's second question about the wisdom of setting up a Senate committee, or referring the matter to a standing committee of the Senate to do with premiums relating to household insurance-in some instances, either a dramatic increase in those premiums or a refusal to insure because of a connection with crime, perhaps a breaking and entering in a particular area-I will have to give that some consideration. I have not had time to think about it and, in any case, it would require consultation with the Treasurer. When that consultation is completed, I will be able to give a fuller answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. The Minister would be aware of yesterday's incident at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport involving a Thai International aircraft and an Ansett domestic flight. Would he care to comment on the incident in light of repeated calls to start the construction of Mascot's third runway? Is he yet able to give us a starting date for the construction of that third runway?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I received a full briefing this morning on the incident from the manager of the air traffic control section of the CAA, and the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. Although I do not intend to comment in any detail on the incident-because the investigation is proceeding apace; the investigating unit will have the flight data recorders from the aircraft available tomorrow; and I expect that this is going to be very speedily dealt with-it needs to be said at this point in time that this incident that occurred at Sydney Airport yesterday, and it was a serious one, is not in any way related to the presence or absence of the third runway, or the fourth, fifth or sixth.

—It does the serious examination of these very serious incidents no justice to simply hang these tags on them. The facts are that simultaneous operations are in operation at many, many major airports around the world. There is absolutely no reason whatever why simultaneous operations, if conducted efficiently and professionally, cannot be used-as they are used in Adelaide, as well as Sydney-with perfect safety.

ANSWER.PARA: The incident that occurred yesterday at Sydney Airport resulted from two aircraft, under simultaneous operations, landing at the airport. The Thai Airways aircraft which landed on the north-south runway was told quite clearly by the air traffic controller concerned-I have read the voice tapes from the control tower at the airport-to pull up short of the intersecting runway. This was acknowledged by the pilot.

I also point out that from the point of touch-down to the point of that intersect there is 8,000 feet of runway-significantly more than a DC10, fully loaded and operating normally, needs to land safely. The incident is being investigated currently. I will provide the Senate with a full report of that investigation when it is completed and is available to me.

So far as the third runway is concerned-and I know there are no essential differences at all between Senator Brownhill and me on this issue-the EIS process is proceeding. The supplement is in the process of being prepared. Under the Act, it has to address some 14,000 matters that were raised in the thousands of submissions received in that EIS process. Currently, about half the chapters of the supplement have been completed and circulated to the necessary agencies. It is expected that the remaining chapters will be delivered in the next two to three weeks. As a result of that, it is expected that Cabinet will consider that final result later this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the March industry statement which proposed, among other initiatives, that an Australian best practice demonstration program be set up to accelerate the spread of best practice and promote a new workplace culture throughout Australian industry. Can the Minister advise the Senate what progress has been made in implementing this proposal? What is the impact of the program expected to be in the Australian workplace?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that Senator Loosley has had an avid interest in the subject of trying to raise in Australian workplaces world best practice as the guiding model for industry level reform in this country, and this question is consistent with his abiding interest in that regard.

ANSWER.PARA: On 20 June I launched a $25m program to raise the efficiency of Australian workplaces through the Australian best practice reform program. That program asks Australian industry to identify where in the world industrial practices are performed best, their characteristics and how much of those principles can be imported into Australian workplaces to change the workplace culture in this country to a more productive one, and to recognise the need to follow the cooperative approach of the Hawke Government to industrial relations and not the old Fraser Government conflict model of industrial relations.

In addition, on 19 July at a major conference attended by over 250 leaders of business, trade unions, government and academia, Mr John Prescott, the Managing Director of BHP, and I released the guidelines for this program. The theme of that conference-`Lifting Australia's game'-was one in which we concentrated, as Australian unions and employers, on identifying what happens in workplaces that have a productive culture, and on that basis we launched the program properly for Australia. We now have over 220 applications from companies of varying sizes and types of industry, such as the metal industry, the meat industry, the building industry, the clothing and textile industry, the food industry, the tourism and hospitality industry and the vehicle industry. That is, a whole range of companies across-the-board have exhibited interest in wanting to be part of this program and have put their workplaces on the line as laboratories for experiments in turning them into vastly more productive workplaces. The bids for funds through the program will close at the end of September and I will then be in a position to announce the opening round of successful companies.
The purpose of this program is to provide some funds to encourage this type of workplace experimentation and to see what works best in Australia, based on world best principles, and to enable--

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you have to hold their hands?

—I will respond to that interjection because it is very interesting that some stimulus and catalyst is necessary to encourage Australian industry to move more quickly down this course. One would have thought it would have moved more rapidly when one looks at examples such as Australia Post, the ICI Australia Ltd plant at Botany and the BHP plant at Newcastle, where a more human approach to industrial relations has been taken and where workers are regarded not as simply extensions of machines but as important elements in the productive culture of those companies, and that one can achieve higher levels of production, higher wages and a greater degree of job satisfaction as well. One would have thought those examples would have stood out, but unfortunately Australian industry has been slow to try to emulate such practices and it is necessary to encourage that in a limited sort of way. That is what this program does; I think it will lead the way in helping Australia establish a new and more productive workplace culture and it will encourage a more human dimension in industrial relations. It is a significant program and I am pleased to announce that so many Australian companies are now interested in participating in it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Can the Minister inform the Senate what stage has been reached in the Government's negotiations with a consortium to buy the Ravenshoe timber mill as a going concern? Is the Federal Government at fault for the fact that the sale has not taken place? If that is not the case, what is the hold up? Finally, can the Minister tell the chamber the current position of the Attorney-General's investigation into the disappearance of the $7m of taxpayers' money intended for Ravenshoe, an investigation that by this Friday will have been going on for 10 months?

—I understand that the negotiations on the purchase of the APS mill at Ravenshoe-and government assistance for that purchase-are at a very delicate stage. I believe the Minister is quite hopeful that a positive announcement can be made on that matter in the near future. It certainly looks good, but beyond that I cannot comment until negotiations are finalised. However, in terms of the honourable senator's other question about the status of government legal action on the question, the Australian Securities Commission--
—Give him some more bits of paper.
—The honourable senator might notice that I rejected it. I am battling on my own here.
—You are doing very well.

—I thank the honourable senator; I appreciate that. The Australian Securities Commission has in fact commenced a section 597 examination of this matter and it may well be that at the end of it there will be more evidence available upon which the Government might seek to take civil action or criminal action, or both. I think the problem has been the lack of access to documents and hence an inability to collect evidence that would result in such action. The Australian Securities Commission investigation may well solve that problem. I do not believe-the decision to begin the examination having been taken-that a timetable has yet been laid out. But when it is, and subject to the agreement of the ASC that it can be made public, I shall inform the Senate.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that advice-long though it has been in coming. Can the Minister indicate to us what sort of guarantee this Government will give the people of Maryborough and Hervey Bay that the $16m compensation package announced for that area-following the World Heritage listing of the Fraser Island forests and the jobs that have been lost as a consequence-will actually get to that area and create jobs, in view of the very sad experience we have had in Ravenshoe?

—As I have said before, one cannot legislate to prevent dishonesty. But on the assumption that there is more honesty in Maryborough than there was in one particular company which operated a business in Ravenshoe, it ought to be somewhat easier. Having said that, I will check on the details of not only the guidelines as to how that money is to be spent-if the honourable senator's figure is right; I have not checked it-but also how it will be monitored. I will present that information to the Senate as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications and it concerns the setting up of a House of Representatives committee to inquire into aspects of media ownership in Australia. I ask the Minister: what is the real reason for excluding senators from this committee by not making it a joint parliamentary committee? Is it not true that a joint committee usually has 10 members, including five senators-two of whom would be government members? Is it not true that Senators Childs and Schacht are keen to serve on this committee and obviously do not consider themselves to be too overloaded? Did the Minister notice that this same overloaded Senate today set up another committee? What has happened in the time between Mr Beazley's announcement and today? Finally, can the Minister tell me, with a straight face and in his usual honest way, that there was no underlying political motive to exclude the Australian Democrats from this committee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that I cannot personally advise Senator Kernot in respect of the questions that she has personally addressed to me relating to my knowledge of the political reasons for the decision for the simple reason that I actually know nothing about it. I am not a Cabinet Minister. I was not involved in the Cabinet deliberations on this matter. As a result of that, I cannot give any personal comment on it. I am confined, therefore, to responding to Senator Kernot's question with advice that has been given to me by the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, as follows.

ANSWER.PARA: Cabinet has decided, `subject to the support of Caucus'-that is actually written in in pencil in brackets-that a House of Representatives select committee be established to inquire into press ownership. Its duties will be to inquire into structural practice of the print media; industry inhibiting competition between publications, including ownership; protection, including paper and supply; and distribution arrangements. It will review the print media's distribution information gathering arrangements and it will review the adequacy of current Commonwealth legislation and practice to foster competition and diversity of ownership in the print media.

The Government believes that there is a requirement for a rapid report. If the Government is going to legislate on this, the Government believes it will need the report to be completed by the end of this parliamentary year.

That is one of the reasons for the Government deciding on the House of Representatives select committee rather than the Senate, given the current massive workload that the Senate faces in relation to its committee work.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I accept that the Minister is not a member of Cabinet, but he knows how Caucus works. Is it possible that the matter could be reconsidered?

—After 15 years I still do not know how Caucus works. The one thing I am extremely grateful for is that at least we do not have a leadership spill every time someone can get 100 signatures on a piece of paper. That would be a nightmare for our Party. I will communicate Senator Kernot's question to Mr Beazley and provide her with a response.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. It follows the question Senator Alston asked on unemployment figures and the Minister's answer. Is it a fact that if an unemployed person works only one hour a week, whether for money or perhaps just to help a friend, then that person is not included in the unemployment figures, even though he or she receives unemployment benefits? If so, what is the present real unemployment figure in Australia? I am sure that the Minister would not accept that someone working for an hour a week to help a friend would be considered employed.
—Senator Richardson, I am not sure whether that question comes within your portfolio.
—I am not responsible for the Australian Bureau of Statistics or how it conducts its surveys. I do not administer that body and I do not consider that I should answer the question.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does the Minister expect the media, the people listening and honourable senators to believe that he is completely unaware of how unemployment figures are put together by the Bureau of Statistics? If he is telling us that, what use are the Bureau of Statistics figures to this Government? If the Government is not prepared to use them and to know how those figures are constructed, I ask the Minister: what is his Department on about?
—The question should really be: what is Senator Walters on about? I have said that I am not responsible for the administration of the ABS and I do not intend to answer questions on it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Is he aware of the report in the August 1991 issue of Choice magazine which refers to evidence that some unscrupulous producers are labelling produce as organic and charging a premium price for it when in fact that produce has been grown conventionally, including the use of pesticides and fungicides? Does the Minister agree that consumers who are concerned to avoid these substances in their food should be able to have confidence that a product that is labelled organic has been organically grown? Can the Minister advise the Senate on what action the Government has taken, or intends to take, to protect consumers from this unscrupulous practice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Devereux did draw my attention to this article in Choice, and I know that he has taken an interest in it quite independently of Choice magazine's review of the fact that organic produce is on sale at various markets and other places. Of course, it is very difficult to determine whether produce deserves that particular description. Organic produce is generally regarded as produce grown without the use of pesticides or chemical fertilisers, although different grades are apparently recognised.

ANSWER.PARA: I have to tell Senator Devereux that currently there are no specific legal requirements which organic produce is required to meet under the food standards code. An organic produce advisory committee established by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is developing standards for the production of organic food, primarily for export purposes. I see that Senator Panizza is well aware of this. I was not, but no doubt Senator Panizza keeps on eye on these matters in relation to the very important foreign earnings that can be gained from the export of Australian produce. However, Federal and State consumer protection legislation which prohibits false or misleading representations about goods could apply. I would hope that State and Territory consumer affairs bureaus rigorously pursue any alleged breach of these provisions as all Australian consumers, as Senator Bolkus says, have every right to receive what they pay for in the way in which it is described.

The Government has recently created the National Food Authority, which will commence operations on 19 August 1991. The National Food Authority will be responsible for developing food standards to be adopted by the States and Territories and will be taking particular interest in food labelling issues. I know that there is a lot of interest in the community about organic food and accuracy in labelling, and I would expect the National Food Authority to take a strong lead in responding to these concerns. The new Authority may wish to look at the Department of Primary Industries and Energy standards for export trade as a basis for domestic regulation of the use of the term `organic', and I will be encouraging it to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Will the Minister advise the Senate whether he endorses the direction given by Comcar to its drivers to refuse to cross picket lines at Parliament House today? Was this direction in breach of the agreement which Comcar has with this Parliament to transport senators and members in the exercise of their parliamentary responsibilities? What are the terms of the agreement with the Parliament for the service, and will the Minister table the agreement? What penalties, if any, apply for a deliberate breach under the agreement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not anticipated that Senator Newman would be raising this question. As the Senate knows, the Trades and Labour Council of the ACT has established a picket line at each access road to Parliament House in support of catering staff. It is industrial action, and action that unions involved with the ACT Trades and Labour Council are adhering to. Comcar drivers, as a consequence of that, have been directed by the Transport Workers Union not to cross the picket line. However, as we found this morning, passengers are being dropped at the closest point to their destination without the vehicle crossing the picket line. I must admit, from my end, that I appreciated the short walk up to the entrance, although my colleague Senator Ray seems to have suffered because of it.

ANSWER.PARA: Comcar management has not issued any contrary direction to drivers. The parliamentary transport officers, I must say, did receive complaints from a number of members who obviously share Senator Newman's reaction to this industrial action. Complaints have come from Senator Newman herself, Ian McLachlan, Peter Reith and Peter Nugent. The three members each complained of having to walk some distance from the picket line to Parliament House.

I think it is fair to say that in Senator Newman's case it is probably indicative of the sort of industrial relations negotiation process that we will have if the Liberals ever take over power in this country. The confrontationist position that was taken by those members this morning is in no way helpful to the resolution of the dispute.

I am informed that Senator Newman insisted that the Comcar driver should cross the picket line. When police officers arrived at the scene, in a spirit of negotiation, of course, she asserted that the driver had no excuse not to proceed because he had a police escort. The driver, in conformity with the industrial action of his union and the ACT Labour Council, still refused to cross the picket line and Senator Newman was subsequently transported to the Senate entrance by the parliamentary transport officer.

As I say, that is indicative of the sort of industrial relations practices that we should expect and have, in fact, seen from the Opposition. Negotiation to settle the dispute is not part of the Opposition's agenda. It is not part of its agenda to the extent that one or more of the abovementioned members or senators is alleged to have threatened those drivers that they would lose their jobs if they did not cross the picket line. That is not the sort of industrial negotiation process that we are on about. I must take this opportunity to warn the Australian people that that sort of confrontationist approach to industrial relations is in no way conducive to the sort of economic direction that this country needs to take.

I will get a copy of the terms of the agreement between my Department, Comcar and the parliamentary officers. But I can tell Senator Newman that I am sure that any agreement between the parties would take into account legitimate industrial action.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. I asked the Minister a series of questions that related to his endorsement of the position taken by his Department today. He has not seen fit to even advert to that in any way. I think, in the noise, he said that Comcar did direct the driver. I am not sure. Perhaps he would confirm whether that is what he said.
—I am sorry, I cannot hear you.
—Order! Senator Newman, ask the supplementary question.

—I am asking the Minister to confirm whether he did just now tell us that Comcar directed the drivers not to cross the picket line. I am also asking, once again, whether he endorses the action taken by Comcar in so directing. Is he aware of an agreement-he apparently is not even aware whether he has an agreement-with the Parliament as to the transport of senators and members in the exercise of their duties?
—It is so important because it is the Parliament, isn't it?
—Yes, it is. It is very important that it is the Parliament because it is not us as individuals, it is us as representatives of the people.
—On a point of order, Mr President: I would like you to get Senator Newman to ask the question.
—Order! Senator Newman has asked three supplementary questions. I will ask her to conclude.

—The final part of my supplementary question is: does the Minister acknowledge that in such circumstances we are not here as individuals-as private citizens-but as representatives of the people of Australia exercising our duties?

—Senator Newman has had a real big week. She started off this week making comments about ministerial council meetings. What sort of reaction did she get? She is the most unwelcome person in Hobart because of it, and so she should be. Mr Rae, a former local Minister for education, has ripped right into her because of, as he quotes-

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The ultimate in hypocrisy is for a Minister to rise to his feet and insist that a question be asked and, when it is asked, then start to rabbit on about matters which are only directed to abusing the questioner. I ask you to direct him to provide an answer in the best manner that he can.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, you were asked four supplementary questions and I think you should answer them.
—As I have already indicated in my first answer--
—You mumble so much that we never know.

—I should have taken up that offer to have mango and champagne with Senator Bishop one night-since then, life has been hell. I have already answered the question. The Comcar drivers have been directed by the Transport Workers Union. Comcar management has not issued any contrary--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I thought that Senator Alston made an extremely good point of order. I would like to carry it through by simply pointing out that when the Minister rises to answer a question, he is meant to do just that and not use it as an excuse to try to make some snide, untruthful remark which he may think is advantageous to him. Anyone with any taste would realise that is not true.
—Order! There is no point of order. I did not hear the interjection. I ask Senator Bolkus to answer the supplementary question he was asked by Senator Newman.

—In short, Comcar drivers have been directed by the TWU. Comcar management has not issued any contrary direction to drivers. I support legitimate industrial action such as this. Finally, if Senator Newman had been so concerned about costs to the Commonwealth, she probably would not have held that Commonwealth driver for the best part of an hour out there this morning. What would that have cost the Commonwealth? That is the sort of issue she has got to look at when taking this penny-pinching approach to politics. As Mr Rae, the former education Minister in Tasmania has said, she is making cheapskate remarks unworthy of a Liberal or a senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 10 August 1991 entitled `Bank says it is to blame for loans pain', which states:

QUESTION.PARA: Senior management of the Commonwealth Bank have admitted privately that the bank was at fault in the foreign currency loan fiasco which has led many of its customers to financial ruin.
In the light of the foregoing, I ask the Minister: will the Government implement a top level inquiry into this serious admission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bank customer relations are not a matter for the Government. They are commercial-in-confidence matters and are best left to the courts to resolve. On the subject of an inquiry, I will take that on notice and give Senator Panizza an answer the next time round.

ANSWER.PARA: I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Ministers are again walking out of the chamber before the end of Question Time. You have drawn that to their attention before.
—Many times.
—I understand that you have received certain undertakings from them. They clearly disregard and disrespect you. I ask you again: will you do something about it?
—Yes, I will, Senator Hill.

—Order! Earlier today I promised to make a statement about the current industrial dispute. I received a copy of the Industrial Relations Commission's ruling at a quarter to three this afternoon. It is being studied at the moment and I should be in a position to make a statement as soon as the matter of urgency is over.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 13 August, from Senator Alston:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

The need to condemn the Government for deliberately creating massive job losses and unemployment through its disastrous economic policies which have made a mockery of its professed concern for social justice.
Yours sincerely,
(RICHARD ALSTON)
Senator for Victoria
Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

The need to condemn the Government for deliberately creating massive job losses and unemployment through its disastrous economic policies which have made a mockery of its professed concern for social justice.
In politics words can be cheap.

TALK.START.PARA: —The gallery voted with their feet!

—When they saw Senator Richardson, they realised that there would not be much integrity in the debate. Who can forget the sort of pre-election promises that we used to have about how interest rates would fall as soon as the election was over. There were regular predictions of soft landings, of bringing home the bacon--
—No capital gains tax.

—No capital gains tax, to quote my colleague Senator Walters, no increase in the Medicare levy and, the mother of all cynicisms, no child would live in poverty by 1990. That litany of broken promises has clearly meant nothing to this Government. Quite undeterred, it continues to make promises.

SPEECH.PARA: When we left here in June we were told that the recovery was just around the corner; that the light on the hill had moved to the end of the tunnel; and that it would not be very long before Australia was back on track and the economy would be coming out of the current recession. As we all know, that was just another political lie. Mr Kelty said the other day that reality has to be measured by performance. I think that is a pretty fair test because surely the only way to judge a political party is over time and on its record.

We have a government that has been in office for more than eight years. We are entitled to examine just what a performance it has put up in that time. Apart from just looking at the statistics and measuring the enormity of its economic failures, it might be best to look at what this Government regarded as its priorities when it came to office. If any outfit has claimed a mortgage on social justice it is the Australian Labor Party. We are constantly berated by the fact that we are lacking in compassion, not concerned about addressing Australia's economic problems and not concerned about the impact on individuals. On the current figures of unemployment we have a disaster of massive proportions. Even the stark statistics hide the level of human misery.

I am sure that Senator Richardson will get up and blather on about how the Government is very concerned and how it hopes that it will be able to deliver in due course. I think the words that ought to haunt Senator Richardson and, indeed, haunt the Labor Party were those uttered by him in May 1983 and again in October 1983. This is the architect of the Keating ascendancy. This is the man who is going to be the chief adviser on all things important to a new Labor Government. This is the man who is presumably going to tell us what social justice is all about, what its real agenda ought to be, what its priorities have always been, and how they ought to remain the same. Let us just look at what Senator Richardson said in May 1983:

The last election was won by the Australian Labor Party on the issue of unemployment. This Government will sink or swim on its performance in providing jobs. It is worth examining why the Fraser Government's record in unemployment finally proved its undoing.

Senator Richardson is nailing his colours to the wall, setting up the Government's own high jump bar, deciding what its priorities ought to be and spelling out as clearly as possible the standard by which it ought to be judged. That was not a trite off the cuff comment in the glow of victory after eight years in the wilderness because again, in October of that year, Senator Richardson stated:

I might say that the Labor Government was elected primarily on the issue of unemployment. It recognises its responsibilities in this area and if it fails over the years to meet the problem of unemployment it will not be elected again, and it will not deserve to be.

One could not get truer words than those. If ever a government stands condemned out of its own mouth, this Government does. I do not think there is anyone in Australia who is not aware of the enormity of the problems that have been caused by unemployment. The figures themselves quite often tell only half the story. The current unemployment rate is marginally below 10 per cent, although every State, except New South Wales, has unemployment figures over that magical number. If we add to the 9.8 per cent rate the ABS underemployment rate-in other words, those with jobs but who would prefer to work more hours; this was the question that the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, was not only abysmally unable to answer but was also apparently so terrified that he lost control of the whole debate and tried to make some stupid distinction between ABS figures and DSS figures--

TALK.START.PARA: —There are pages and pages of why there are differences.
—Exactly, but Senator Richardson was quite unable even to spell out the difference or to comment on the proposition put to him.
—It is not my job to.

—I see. That is the narrow way the Minister defines it. He is not interested in the number of people said to be unemployed by the Government but is interested only in the number of people paid benefits. If that is the level of his interest in the subject, it is pretty narrow stuff. If we add the ABS underemployment rate of 6.2 per cent and the proportion of the work force who have left in the last 12 months-they have given up the ghost or thrown in the towel-we find that the labour force, consisting of either discouraged workers, underemployed or simply unemployed, is about 16.7 per cent or over 1.4 million workers.

SPEECH.PARA: That was really the sort of figure that Senator Walters was inviting the Minister to proffer. Of course, he is not only acutely aware of it, but also acutely sensitive to it, because that in itself destroys any claim that this Government could have to understand social justice, let alone deliver it to the Australian population.

The numbers on the dole are now in excess of 700,000. Employment in the month of July fell by 83,000, the biggest monthly fall since the ABS labour force survey-in which the Minister is not interested-began in 1978. Had the participation rate not fallen in July, the unemployment rate would have been 10.3 per cent.

We have all these basket cases around Australia, with the shining exception of New South Wales, which are just managing to keep the level under the 10 per cent figure officially, but in reality, of course, those out there at the coalface know precisely what is happening: they know that they cannot get jobs, they cannot get the jobs of their choice and, to the extent that they do have jobs, they are very worried indeed about their job security.

Probably about the worst fate that could be inflicted on anyone in a democratic society is to have a government which in the one breath says-as the Prime Minister said in March of last year-that `there is no need to fear a recession in any sense', and then in the same month to have the Treasurer saying, `A slower year of growth, but there will not be a recession ahead. We will not let there be a recession'. Then, of course, eight months later, he was saying, `This was the recession Australia had to have' and `I knew there had to be one but I did not want to tell you'.

That is the level of morality that drives this Government: someone who pretends to the highest office in the land is quite unrepentant about those sorts of misstatements and misleading comments but, of course, is quite oblivious to his own inept performance, even to the point where yesterday he was actually boasting about his own achievements in office. It seems an extraordinary proposition that he can be so unaware of the level of foreign debt, which is of the order of $160 billion compared to about $35 billion when the Government came to office. We have a current account deficit of about $16.5 billion-all sorts of catastrophic figures-and a Budget outcome that is something like $13 billion worse than it was predicted to be two years ago. The last Budget surplus was predicted to be $8.1 billion. The outcome was $1.9 billion. These are the credentials of someone who claims to be able to lead the country and, presumably, is proud of what he has achieved to date.

If that is the sort of commitment to delivering prosperity and the concomitant social improvements, then we are all entitled to be scared stiff. I will be very interested in the campaign manager's contribution to this debate because, unless he has some very good advice that he has been withholding from Mr Keating, it is quite clear that there is not going to be any significant improvement in the figures or, indeed, even in the rhetoric. I would have thought that was the very least that we could have expected to date.

All the evidence indicates that the employment regime in this country is going to remain very depressed for months and perhaps years ahead. As Mr Will Bailey said the other day, unemployment could stay above 10 per cent for at least 18 months. Treasury says that it will exceed 10 per cent through 1991-92. So, of course, does the parrot, Mr Kerin. The putative Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, agrees with that proposition. Of course, Mr Dawkins, in releasing a report the other day about employment prospects through to the year 2000, had to concede that the people most at risk from Labor's current economic policies are the young, the unskilled, Aboriginals and migrants; in other words, the very sort of people that social justice is supposed to be all about-the disadvantaged, the marginalised, the economically vulnerable, the ones who are bearing the brunt of this recession.

Long term unemployed are a relatively recent phenomenon. When unemployment benefits were introduced they were meant to be a transition payment of about six months duration. Now, of course, there are something like 180,000 long term unemployed, a higher figure by far than in 1983, despite Mr Dawkins's protestations to the contrary. Indeed, what Mr Dawkins had to say on AM the other day was:
All of our effort these days is placed into trying to get the longer term unemployed back into the labour market.

He is being spectacularly unsuccessful, to use an Evansism, and, indeed, the Auditor-General has made it clear in his recent criticisms that some of the major labour market programs have been particularly unsuccessful in achieving that aim. In fact, Jobtrain, which is supposed to be targeted at the long term unemployed, has seen a program of something like $121m; and more than half the recipients of that program have been unemployed for less than six months. So it is very poorly targeted. We can understand the reasons why, but it simply demonstrates that this Government is not able to offer any hope to those people who are not only the victims of this recession but who, to all intents and purposes, are still languishing from the last one, back in the early 1980s.

We have probably the worst employment record of any government in this country over such a period of time. It has been in office now for 8 1/4 years. There is no way in which one could say that it is premature to judge it on its record. One could not ask for more than four terms in office to deliver the goods. Indeed, all we have got to show for it at the end of that very long period are record levels of unemployment-and not just in a global sense. The unemployment rate for males is now higher than when Labor came to office, at 10.1 per cent. The full time unemployment rate for teenagers is now 28.5 per cent-a 1.8 percentage increase over 1983. The male participation rate has fallen by 2.9 percentage points. The full time participation rate for males has fallen by a massive 4.9 percentage points. The unemployment rate is now higher in Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania than in April 1983.

There are all sorts of reasons why these figures disguise the enormity of the problem. We constantly hear this empty boast about 1.6 million new jobs. I am sure that that number has been scaled down a bit, but even so, when one analyses who these people are, one finds that they are largely second income earners. They are married women getting into the work force. They are part time, overwhelmingly, rather than full time. They are simply not the breadwinners, not the people that one would have thought were entitled to expect 1.6 million jobs to boost family incomes and to raise the standard of living generally. We know to what extent that has fallen: something of the order of $60 per week in real terms.

The people who have really gained from the supposed growth in employment are not the ones about which Labor has always professed to be mostly concerned-the breadwinners. The number, of course, has been even more inflated by the fact that we have had very high school retention rates. That is a very good thing in itself. It hopefully suggests that there will be a higher level of quality output and that we will have better educated students coming into the labour market. They have not got much to look forward to. One can well understand why they would be terrified about leaving school prematurely. In many respects, that is a good thing: they ought to stay there as long as possible and have themselves as well qualified as possible. But it is not much consolation when one tries to analyse why the figures are as they are. If those people were treated on the same basis as they were in the early 1980s, then of course the unemployment figures would be even higher than the 16.7 per cent figure that I have cited.

What we really have is a social problem of tragic proportions, playing with people's lives and futures in many respects. The Government has clearly got to accept the responsibility for this despairing outcome because of its failure to bite the bullet and because it knows in its heart of hearts what ought to be done, yet lacks the intestinal fortitude to deliver.

Senator Richardson is not really very strong on policy but I think even he knows what micro-economic reform is all about. He knows that the rest of the world has had growth rates that have, by recent standards, been very impressive because it has been prepared to undertake fundamental reform, particularly fundamental reform of the labour market. That is where we will come to terms with these problems.

If the Government is serious about wanting to get the unskilled, the marginalised and the disadvantaged back into the work force, it will do it by freeing up the labour market. It will do it in a way that makes it attractive and rewarding for employers to be able to afford to take those people on. It certainly will not do it by adding another $6 billion to payroll tax in the form of compulsory superannuation at 3 per cent over the next few years. That will simply drive up the unemployment figures.

Max Walsh said recently that he regarded such a proposal as little short of economic lunacy. He could not understand why the former Treasurer had completely lost touch with economic responsibilities since relinquishing his role. I do not know whether this reflects the advice he has been getting but I suppose that his silence since he got that bucketing is evidence of the fact that he knows that a compulsory superannuation scheme of that magnitude is a recipe for employment disaster.

We have a very sorry tale. I will be fascinated to hear Senator Richardson's justification. I am sure that he will not be claiming any credit. In many respects, the other side of the Senate is littered with those who have never had to work for a living, who have always been able to operate in the sheltered workshop environment of the Labor Party secretariats. We have something like nine or 10 ex-Labor Party secretaries and apparatchiks.

Senator Richardson's definition of social justice presumably involves the sorts of recent escapades we have seen where $1,000 is chalked up a night in a hotel in London. When he was asked what his excuse was, the best he could say was, `Well, that's amazing. The last time I stayed there it cost only $500 a night'. A mere $130,000 was spent during three trips over nine months, and all this in the middle of the greatest recession since the Depression! If that is his definition of social justice, I would have thought that he would desperately need some professional advice.

If we are serious about social justice, if we are serious about getting employment levels up again, we must make a new start-not the sort of false dawn that the Government is proposing by way of its compulsion which will boost the numbers of CES bureaucrats and the like but a truly flexible labour market, one that will provide significant long term opportunities for people who desperately want to get into the work force but simply cannot.

I can assure Senator Richardson and the Senate that we are committed to fundamental reforms, to a workplace environment where people will be able to compete effectively and where those who are not prepared to work or to look hard enough will find their benefits being cut off. But the vast majority who are interested in work and who do want access to labour market programs will be able to have it. I hope, at the very least, that we will get an admission that the last 8 1/2 years have been a tragic failure, that they have been the very opposite of a delivery of the concept of social justice and that, indeed, it is time for a new start.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —The concept of social justice is oft debated in parliaments. But the understanding of it sometimes lags a long way behind debate and that, sadly, has always been the case with this Opposition and remains so today. When we are having this kind of debate, it is particularly disappointing that Senator Alston should allude to `the sheltered workshops of Labor Party offices'; I certainly will not. The last time a politician-he was a friend of mine-used an analogy of that kind, he was very rightly criticised by disabled groups all around the country.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston ought to know better. I am surprised, given that he has had over 12 months in the shadow portfolio, that he would be silly enough to make that kind of analogy. But we will let disabled groups make up their own minds about him; of course, many of them have-and I shall refer to that a little later.

First off, in looking at the unemployment statistics to which Senator Alston and Senator Walters referred during the course of Question Time, I declined to read out the eight dot points that the ABS used to explain the difference between its statistics and the statistics of the Department of Social Security. I have always been under the impression that the honourable senators to whom I referred would be literate enough to manage them on their own. But clearly the statistics show a number of unemployed in Australia that is very high, indeed. This is something of regret to us all.

It is worth while noting that even during the course of a recession-an admittedly tough recession-Australia has been spending something like $1 billion a month more than the value of what it produces. That is a sobering figure, I would have thought, for us all. Clearly, a way to get around that can only come with the establishment of a real manufacturing base in Australia and policies that will lead to proper international competition. What that all means in the end is that Australia will have to earn its future. It will not come as easily as it did in past decades. Reliance on commodities and agriculture is never going to be good enough again.
