While I would hate to be branded a heretic for departing from some Labor orthodoxy, I do not blame the Fraser and Howard regimes for that problem. They did not do anything about it; they did not try to fix it. But I do not blame them for the problem; that problem goes back some decades. Attempting to sort out the real problems of the 1950s and 1960s caused by McEwen and Menzies will take Australia a long time indeed, irrespective of who governs. But someone has to sit down and actually start that ball rolling and that is what this Government has done.

What is really up for debate is the kind of safety net that is put in place by the Government for those people who are unemployed. We heard Senator Alston make some references to a safety net but those references have been characteristically vague. On 5 July this year, at least he came a little closer to being specific. He said:
You've got to understand that our approach to unemployment is quite different from the Government. We take the view that you shouldn't be on benefits indefinitely.

That, of course, is the nub of the problem. Senator Alston pretended for a while that those who were going off unemployment benefit, after whatever period he decided they were not serious about work, would be getting special benefits. That pretence is gradually being dropped. Mr Reith, of course, never even maintained it. He was happy to drop it straight away. We have never been given an explanation of where the $3 billion in cuts in welfare are going to come from and how those cuts will be made. We have waited a long time for a policy to come out of the Opposition on this question. We have not got one; we are still waiting.

I was staggered by Senator Alston's reference to being strong on policy. He has not yet been able to come up with one. I would challenge Senator Alston to tell us exactly where these cuts are to come from. I challenge him to tell us how social justice in Australia would be advanced by a $3 billion cut in the welfare budget. I wonder who will suffer from the $3 billion cut. One thing is for sure: it will not be those who attend Liberal Party conferences. Those well-heeled people will not be the ones under attack.

For a party that professes today a commitment to social justice, one wonders how many social security beneficiaries ever attend Liberal Party conferences. I suspect that the answer to that is very few indeed. When they turn up at our conferences, they come as delegates because we are of them and they are among us. So we do tend to know a little more than Senator Alston about what affects them and the kinds of solutions that they would seek.

I want to turn to some of the matters that Senator Alston has raised today. While I would have to confess to some depression about unemployment figures, I think really two questions have to be asked as we head out of the recession. They are: firstly, what sort of economy will we have when we recover and, secondly, what sort of commitment does the Government have to the needs of those who have suffered during the recession and who will continue to suffer for some time yet?

The answer to the first question is that we will have an economy which is to a far greater degree driven by an improved manufacturing base and by international competitiveness. That is also underscored by the fact that we will have one of the lowest inflation rates in the OECD. That gives Australia a very real opportunity over the next few years, provided that it is not spoilt by the introduction of a consumption tax and an immediate jump in our inflation rate so that we lose that competitive edge. This economy has become more and more open to international markets. It is no longer governed by that conservative dogma of protection and reliance on commodity prices. We can give Australia a real chance, provided some of the necessary decisions can be taken.

The second question is: what sort of commitment will the Government have, or would any government have, to those who are coming out of the recession and who have suffered during it? I have to say that the record of the Government on this question is one of which I am justifiably proud. We have taken positive and definite steps to try to help those who have been hurt by this recession and we continue to do so. Not for us the nostalgic look, the gaze through rose coloured glasses to the Thatcherite or Reaganite models of welfare of those opposite. Those opposite have a superior view which seeks to blame the poor for their predicament and punish them with a system which will only further condemn them to poverty.

In looking back with rose coloured glasses on Mrs Thatcher's rule in Britain, it should be noted that between the years of 1985 and 1989 there was a jump of 53 per cent in the numbers of those living in poverty. There are vast ghettos of poverty in the great cities of Britain. In some areas of Glasgow, Britons live in Third World conditions. Britain is one of the G7 nations, one of the top economies of the world. What happened to social welfare and what happened to the safety net are questions that the Opposition will not seek to answer.

In terms of Reaganite models, the idea that individual States would control welfare has meant that in the US the States are actually pulling out-reducing welfare payments-so that they do not get people moving into their States. That strikes me as a pretty sad situation. Those sorts of solutions are not for this Government.

At this point I will mention Senator Alston's continual reference to the need to hand over some aspects of social security to welfare agencies. Quite recently, Senator Alston attended a conference in Sydney organised by the Social Policy Research Centre at which he put some of these views. Fortunately, I have listened to a tape of those proceedings taken by one of the participants. The reception that Senator Alston received should have given him some inkling of just how tough it was for him.

The welfare agencies totally reject the line that these functions can be handed over to them. In fact, they rejected that very strongly and quite vocally at the conference. When it came to a discussion of the special benefit and what happens with the income test, Senator Alston was in real strife because he simply did not know the answers. In fact, he got laughed at, not with. That was in front of the creme de la creme of those who will be participating in discussions with him during the course of his shadow ministry-however long that might last. That suggests a rocky road indeed for Senator Alston. However, it will be no rockier than that which he has so far endured.

I will mention some of the advances that have been made during the eight years of the Hawke Labor Government for those who are on social security benefits and pensions, because they are the ones who have to be caught by this safety net. They are the ones who know the real meaning of social justice. For them, it is worth noting that there has been a 13.7 per cent increase for married pensioners and beneficiaries without children; a 17 per cent increase for married pensioners and beneficiaries with two children aged six to 12; a 25.7 per cent increase for married pensioners and beneficiaries with children aged 13 to 15; a 19.3 per cent increase for sole parent pensioners with two children aged six to 12; and a 31.5 per cent increase for sole parent pensioners with children aged between 13 and 15. Those increases are all real increases; they all take inflation into account. These are massive gains for those on fixed incomes at the bottom end of the income scale. They are the gains that this Government has delivered and will continue to deliver.

Low income workers have also benefited from very significant real increases in their disposable incomes. These have been delivered by a combination of taxation reform and social security policy changes. A single person with no children and earning 75 per cent of total average weekly earnings for all persons has experienced a 3.2 per cent rise in real disposable income.

There has been a 9.3 per cent real increase for single income couples with two children under the age of 13, again if they are earning 75 per cent of average weekly earnings. There has been a 5.1 per cent real increase for a dual income couple with two children under the age of 13 and earning that same percentage of average weekly earnings. These are very significant increases for low income families and they have been achieved over a long period of time.

The increases for low income families with children are overwhelmingly due to very large real increases in the family allowance supplement, previously the family income supplement. Those increases amount to 54.3 per cent for children under the age of 13, and 125 per cent for children aged 13 to 15. Again, those are real increases, inflation having being taken into account. These are extraordinary rises.

When one goes right through the benefit levels and takes into account the increases we have had in rent assistance, which again in some places reaches 100 per cent, these extraordinary increases demonstrate a commitment to social justice year after year by this Government for those who are in need of a social security net.

Now, in the course of a recession, with the Newstart program beginning on 1 July, we have very real opportunities for training for the unemployed. They can use the time during the recession to make sure that while they are unemployed their skills are improving so that they can benefit as soon as the recession is over. They are the ones who will reap the gains when the recession is over; they are the ones who will get the jobs. That situation benefits individuals and, of course, it also benefits the nation.

One of the problems we have had is the level of skill in the work force. The skilling of our work force needs upgrading urgently. The Newstart program will guarantee that that occurs. There are hundreds of millions of dollars now being spent on training programs as a result of what was announced in the March statement and next week there will be further announcements of increases. Obviously, I cannot announce those; however, I think that they will be received very well indeed next week.

The increases that I have referred to and the establishment of the Newstart program for those who are unfortunate enough to be out of a job demonstrate the Government's type of social justice. When we contrast that with the type of social justice that the Opposition would have, we see that there really is still a stark difference between the Government and the Opposition-a huge gulf, a gap that is growing.

I have already referred to the Opposition's proposed $3 billion saving from cuts in welfare expenditure. There is no doubt about who will suffer when people try to rip that out of welfare and out of the hands of those who can least afford it. Even after 15 months, the Opposition has not had the guts-the courage-to come out and tell us which areas will be cut, who will suffer the knife. No-one yet knows. Those opposite talk about the figure of $3 billion. It is easy to get the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, to say the figure, but it is very hard to get him to put down on paper any areas that are due for the chop.

If I were an unemployed person, a sole parent pensioner or one of the millions of battlers in this country, I would know that, if the Opposition were to form a government, those cuts would be falling on me. That knife would be going right through my standard of living. Sadly for the Opposition, that will be the problem during the lead-up to the next election, because not only will it have to explain what it has had to--

TALK.START.PARA: —How many people have you made unemployed?
—It is a question of what the Opposition is going to do to them. I want Senator Alston to come clean and tell us where the cuts are-that is all I want.
—In due course.
—Due course has taken 15 months. How much longer will it take? This due course is taking a long, long time.
—We are still waiting for your 1983 tax policy.

—Senator Knowles really has not been around for the last eight years. The tax system has been altered substantially. We brought in measures concerning such things as capital gains and fringe benefits. I would have thought that even Senator Knowles would be aware of some of those changes. She might be aware that the Opposition is still saying that it will try to abolish the capital gains tax. That is an extraordinary statement from those who claim social justice. If one is well-heeled, if one is doing well in this community and can get capital gains, the Liberal Party says, `No tax-you are fixed'.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Liberal Party says to anyone who is unemployed, to any social welfare beneficiary, is, `You will be cut, and you will be cut savagely'. That is the contrast the Liberal Party can never get over. When it comes to a consumption tax it gets much worse. Over the course of the next two years it will be fascinating. We will probably hear the phrase `in due course' again because we have had no details of the consumption tax either. How the Opposition compensates all of those pensioners, all of those unemployed, is something we want to know. The problem for the Opposition will not be simply about social welfare beneficiaries. It will be a big problem for the National Party to try to explain to the 140,000 farmers, and a big problem for the Liberal Party to try to explain to the 400,000 self-employed persons who have been identified by the Social Policy Research Centre as having incomes above that which would be compensated, how they can be compensated for this tax. There are half a million taxpayers in Australia-mind you, overwhelmingly part of the Liberal-National Party base vote-who cannot be compensated under a consumption tax. I will be fascinated to see the squirming of the National Party over the next few months on that issue. It will hear a lot about it. I will also be fascinated to see the champions of small business on the Opposition benches explain to the self-employed why they cannot be compensated. It will be interesting to see how long the courageous lot on the other side can hang on!

TALK.START.PARA: —Indefinitely.

—I hope they hang on indefinitely. I hope for once they do, because this is no longer Labor's secret weapon. This is out in the open. This is an issue that the Australian public will hear a lot about over the next 12 months. Whether we hear any detail from the Opposition or not, Labor will make this an issue. Once again those opposite will demonstrate that those at the bottom end of the income pile get nothing. The only thing they could expect to get out of a government of those opposite, if they ever formed one, is more and more trouble. But one cannot expect people not to notice. When that policy is spread to the self-employed and the farmers that is political death, and that is the fate the Opposition will suffer. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise firstly to support the motion moved by Senator Alston which is before us today. The only small question the Australian Democrats had was whether this Government had deliberately created the massive job losses. On looking at its present reaction to the incredibly large numbers now on unemployment benefits-the very large numbers who have lost their jobs and the way in which it has reacted to that-one sees that it basically has not reacted. There seems to be no inclination on the part of the Government to move directly to assist those people by creating jobs. We have therefore come to the conclusion that, yes, it must have been deliberate. We will therefore be supporting this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I rise to speak with some cynicism. Whilst there is no doubt that the Government's economic policies are causing great hardship, the fact of the matter is that the Opposition has not put forward one single policy which would turn the situation around and reduce unemployment. In fact, other than hawking around its consumption tax and trying to convince everyone what a wonderful idea it is, there is not one thing the Opposition is offering the country that is substantially different from the medicine which the Government has now been dishing out for some years.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not right.

—It is more of the same rhetoric, I am afraid, Senator Vanstone, and the rhetoric hides the basic fact that, like this Government, the Opposition is happy to see ordinary working Australians paying the most for the cost of this recession. I refer in particular to those who are now not able to work, whether they have lost their jobs, whether their small businesses have folded or whether they have been forced off their farms. The Opposition has not shown the slightest concern for social justice issues as they affect the 900,000 to one million Australians who are now out of work.

SPEECH.PARA: It is pretty audacious of Senator Alston to come in here and talk of justice and people who are on the economic margins of society, the economically vulnerable, when in the last session we had to sit here and watch the Opposition vote with the Government to pass its Newstart legislation. We have not heard anything at all from the Opposition today that looks at the disastrous social justice consequences of the Government's proposed changes to invalid pensions and sickness benefits. That piece of legislation is due to be debated in this chamber any day now. Senator Alston needs to realise that it will be very difficult for Australians to take this sudden concern with social justice from the Opposition very seriously when it has colluded with the Government in recent years on a number of measures that have quite clearly done nothing to advance the cause of social justice in this country.

As I keep pointing out time and time again, I have watched the Opposition support the Government on such measures as the significant reduction in income support for young unemployed people and young homeless people; the introduction of the liquid assets test on unemployment and sickness beneficiaries; reductions in the rent allowance; the introduction of a $2.50 prescription charge for pensioners; the introduction of a new series of hurdles, plus the power of compulsion, in Newstart; the refusal to support exemptions for family farms and the family allowance supplement; and the refusal to support the disallowance of the Austudy regulations which would have led to the exemption of the family farm from the Austudy assets test and a better deal for all students. The list goes on and on.

I again stress that the Opposition has continually aided and abetted the Government through its social security program, putting into place its privatisation policies and its economic policies. Many of these measures have helped further entrench many Australian families in poverty. To look at what the Opposition is planning, I refer to the current issue of the Bulletin magazine published on 13 August. Senator Alston was interviewed on what the coalition would do if in government with regard to welfare policies. The article in the Bulletin states:

Despite the protests of a Hawke government that says it has cut back as far as human dignity will permit, shadow minister Richard Alston sees ``considerable scope to reduce the numbers of people who are needlessly on welfare''. He plans a profound crackdown that will see an unapologetic microscope pulled over most areas in the $24 billion portfolio. He says it is ``verging on a scandal'' that so many people who claim sickness benefits or the invalid pension get it when they are ``only marginally affected'' and claims reforms in this area could net ``several hundred millions of dollars'' in savings. Tougher new medical test rules will be introduced to assess cases.

I wonder whether Senator Alston has looked at the Bill currently before the Senate-the Government's Bill, which puts new tests and new tables in place which now will be the only criteria on which a person can get the disability support pension. The criteria are so strict that they will cut out thousands of people and prevent thousands of Australians from accessing this benefit. Indeed, in a couple of cases they are untried anywhere in the world. The article continues:

A Hewson government would make unemployment benefits available for nine months only, after which the recipient would have to satisfy an ``activity test'' that he or she was out trying to get work, in order to continue to receive ``special benefits''.

I ask Senator Alston whether he has seen how tight the activity test already is for those people who are trying to get unemployment benefits. And it does not end there. I ask Senator Alston: where is the justice in denying people in need access to fully qualified social workers? I refer here to his proposal that only volunteers working through welfare agencies would be giving the necessary support by way of counselling rather than, as is the case now, the Government providing counselling to disabled people looking for work, to teenagers and to single parents wanting to re-enter the work force.

Only today we read of another Liberal policy, this time specifically in South Australia, where it is planned that, under a Liberal Government, unemployed youths will be living in compulsory camps, weeding national parks, building railways and catching rabbits and feral cats. This plan has been proposed by Mr Peter Lewis, the Liberal member for Murray-Mallee. Where is the social justice in that? Yes, young people desperately want work, but not in a concentration camp-type situation. By all means, get these jobs done-they are desperately needed-but let us provide the money through the National Parks and Wildlife Service in various States and offer work to young people. They will be queuing up. I can assure the Senate that the jobs will be filled within a couple of days. The less well-off members of our society might be interested to know exactly what is Senator Alston's definition of social justice.

We have heard some comments from Senator Richardson about the Liberal Party's consumption tax proposals. I wish to comment briefly on this in the short time available to me today. The change proposed by the Opposition is a package which is even more regressive than merely an increase in the indirect tax base. As well as taxing food, funerals, car repairs, football matches, cinema attendance, health services and education, the Opposition plans to either abolish or severely reduce the capital gains tax and cut the maximum marginal income tax rate. It seems very likely that it will be lowering company tax and abolishing the training levy. From comments that Senator Alston made today, it seems that superannuation is also in the firing line.

With regard specifically to the goods and services tax, the poor consume all of their income-they spend it all on goods and services. Because they do, a goods and services tax is regressive, as proportionally it falls much harder on the low income group. The Opposition says, `Don't worry about that. We will compensate'. But, sensibly, very few Australians believe it. While it is possible to increase benefits for those who are in the system-and I stress again that under a Liberal government there would be far fewer people on benefits and within the system-how are those people who now, or who will, fall through the system going to be compensated? The public debate, as yet, has not covered the need to compensate students who receive Austudy or Abstudy. How can we become the clever country when our students are living below the poverty line?

We still do not know the coalition's policy on indexation of benefits and allowances. It may be prepared to provide a one-off increase, but if they are not indexed, those who are receiving them will be even harder hit. Those who are on low, fixed incomes which are not in any way Government benefits-for example, small business people who are struggling to make ends meet, farmers and superannuants-will be drastically disadvantaged by this consumption tax.

Let us look at superannuants. Firstly, all their savings, which are to supplement retirement income, will be instantly devalued. Secondly, their superannuation pensions or annuities will not be increased to take into account the increased prices. Low income earners who want to be home buyers will be further disadvantaged because all building materials will be subject to tax. I could go on and on.

Another reason-and there are many more-why the Democrats oppose a consumption tax is market preference for ecologically sustainable practices. The current system grants sales tax exemption for recycled paper. This has created a massive, growing, ecologically sound, export-oriented Australian industry. The elimination of the sales tax differential between recycled and ordinary paper would affect the relative position of recycled paper in the market. The same applies to solar hot water services and photovoltaic devices. We would like to increase the number of exemptions to include recycled plastics, electric motor vehicles and a large number of other items.

One final point on social justice is the rights and interests of disabled people. They also currently enjoy a large number of exemptions from sales tax for vital equipment to assist them in their daily lives. I could go on with regard to charities, nursing homes and educational institutions.

None of this is to let the Government off the hook-far from it. In the short time left to me I want to look briefly at one of the more scandalous things that this Government has done in the area of social security, and that is the reduction in income support for young people. Not only has it created a climate in which it is extremely difficult for young people to get a job or to hold on to a job, but also it has already reduced young people to a point well below the poverty line.

The average person may think it would make more sense to raise the education allowance than to bring all other allowances down to that very meagre, minimal level. As we read our papers and listen to the radio, we hear more and more of the increased crime rates amongst young people. We are being told by criminologists and psychologists that a large part of the reason is that young people who are out of work do not have enough to live on.

Not only that, but we also have the Government blithely sailing on with what can at best be called a highly dubious policy, and moving to cut back on the last remaining group of young people who still have a reasonable income, and that is the young, disabled people-those people who, by definition, cannot work. Under social security legislation now before this Parliament young, disabled people will have their incomes significantly reduced. What will this mean to them, to their families and to the care givers? It will mean even further disadvantages for these already disadvantaged young people. Where is the social justice in that?

I will briefly go through the figures: 9.8 per cent officially unemployed-some 830,000 Australians officially out of work, with the Government saying that we could well reach 900,000 people out of work by Christmas. These figures are only the tip of the iceberg. They fail to reveal the extent of misery and hardship that this recession is causing for Australian families.

We have heard virtually nothing from the Government that indicates that the message is getting through to it. As individual senators or members, backbenchers or Ministers, we hear more of the same about deregulation and the need for high interest rates. There are no new ideas about directly tackling record levels of unemployment. Actually to put up some alternatives is almost seen as heresy. We must keep talking, it seems, using all the jargon about free markets, deregulation, keeping interest rates up and lowering taxes. To be part of the economic debate in this country, one is expected not to mention those nasty words `full employment', and somehow to accept that we will always have to put up with a substantial level of unemployment.

The Democrats do not accept that this is where Australia should be heading. We are not talking just about statistics and arguing about which statistical table we should be looking at. We are talking about people whose lives are being directly affected and damaged by Government policies. It is about time that we heard some fresh ideas from the Government, and that the Government started showing a bit of leadership on these issues and actually allowed some debate to occur within its own ranks as well as in the wider community. I conclude by saying that this Government does stand condemned, but it could not have done the things for which it is being condemned without the assistance of Senator Alston.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thus far, this has been a particularly interesting debate because it shows the different perspectives of the major parties and of the Australian Democrats, about whom I wish to make some specific remarks. We are debating an urgency motion put forward by Senator Alston, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to condemn the Government for deliberately creating massive job losses and unemployment through its disastrous economic policies which have made a mockery of its professed concern for social justice.

In relation to this matter Senator Lees has said, `What are you going to do? I haven't heard anything from you'. That is what she has said to the coalition. She listed a number of Government policies on which we have supported the Government, and made a quantum leap to say we are equally culpable in this matter.

What I have to say to the Democrats and to other interested honourable senators is that social justice is a nice motherhood word. I think Labor invented it, and wants to jump behind it at every opportunity it can. `We have a social justice program'. Who could not be in favour of that? It is perceived to mean a fairer system. That is all it means.

There is no magic in social justice. It is just a highfalutin way of one saying that things should be fairer than they are now. No-one I know disagrees with that. The Opposition has a different approach to creating a fairer system for everybody. In these debates Senator Lees is always talking about giving more money. I might phrase it another way-she is complaining about cutting down on Government spending and says that we should not be so harsh in this respect. The Democrats' approach to these matters is that, if there is a problem, we should throw money at the people involved-through welfare benefits or whatever-and that problem will be solved.

The mistake the Democrats make is in believing that the problem will be solved. The problem may be alleviated, but it will not be solved. I suppose that is the luxury of a speech from a member of a party which will never be in government, will never be responsible for taking the reins of government, and will never be responsible for implementing its policies. Senator Lees was at pains to say that she had not heard any proposals from the coalition about what it was going to do. I did not hear any proposals from her about what the Democrats would do. If one is going to criticise, then one should have some idea of what one is going to do.

Senator Lees says that all we talk about is a goods and services tax. Before getting on to the substance of what I want to deal with, there are some remarks I would like to make to the Democrats in that respect. They say that a consumption tax is a bad thing. I remind them that we already have a consumption tax-we have a wholesale sales tax. The Democrats need to decide why they continue to support a hidden wholesale sales tax. When we go to the shops, unless we are familiar with a whole range of wholesale sales tax legislation, we do not know how much we are paying.

Why are the Democrats prepared to support a hidden tax with high and variable rates where some things are not taxed, some are taxed at 10 per cent, 20 per cent or 30 per cent, and there is no rhyme or reason between them? I think carbonated mineral water is taxed and uncarbonated mineral water is not; televisions are taxed but some other entertainment goods are not; caravans are taxed but travel to Broome is not. It seems quite irrational.

The Democrats need to explain why they support an irrational wholesale sales tax system. Why do they say that people who manufacture goods should have the extra price inbuilt into their product but people who deliver services and sell their services for a living should not be so disadvantaged? Let them say why they support that system and why, in principle, that is a better way to go. Let them say why they think it is a good thing that our business inputs are continually taxed. Despite some moves by the Government to allow some exemptions, our business inputs are, nonetheless, taxed. Let them explain why that is a good thing when jobs for Australians depend on our industries being competitive. Furthermore, Senator Lees should say why she makes the assumption that it is impossible to compensate or offset for such a policy.

I see that Senator Maguire is speaking later in this debate. I welcome an explanation from him about the newsletter he put out, which made outrageous allegations of what the coalition was going to do. If the Government ever introduces truth in advertising and extends it to electoral newsletters, Senator Maguire is in very deep, hot water. If he wants to come into this debate with clean hands, let him first answer for the veracity of the remarks he made in his newsletter to his-I imagine-ever decreasing bunch of Labor followers.

Returning to the theme of social justice, this Government is quick to claim as one of its policies that it believes in fairness. That does not distinguish it from anybody here. As far as I can tell, everybody in this chamber believes that we should be trying to develop a fairer system. It is interesting that Marc Lombard from Macquarie University made a study of what has happened to the so-called rich and poor under Labor. He discovered that under Labor the top 10 per cent of income earners are massively increasing their share of the cake. For example, the top 10 per cent of income earners in 1982-83-regrettably that is when the coalition lost government-had a 21.8 per cent share of the cake. In 1988-89, after a few years of Labor, their slice of the cake had shifted up to 26.63 per cent. On the other hand, the share of the cake for the bottom percentage had reduced.

What is the most telling of all is that in 1982-83 the top one per cent of income earners shared just under 4 per cent of our national income. In 1988-89 they had much closer to 8 per cent of the national income. Under Labor's social justice programs the rich get a lot richer.

But the story becomes even worse: not only did the share of the cake going to the top one per cent of income earners increase massively-nearly doublefold-but the percentage of their own income paid in tax decreased dramatically. When the coalition was in government, the top one per cent, who were then earning about 4 per cent of the cake, paid about a quarter of that in tax. Now, under Labor, they are earning nearly 8 per cent of the cake but paying only about 3.4 per cent of their portion in tax. If Senator Lees wants to say she thinks that is a delivery of social justice, well and good, but I do not think it is at all.

The points I want to make thus far are these: we have seen a different approach in this debate. The Democrats basically say, `If there is a problem, throw money at it. If you do not throw money at it, you must be mean, you cannot be in favour of fairness'. That is a very simplistic line which is easy to run on talkback radio, but it is not the way to run a country.

The Government says, `People really are better off under us'. We say that is absolute rubbish. The rising numbers of unemployed do not feel that they are better off under this Government. It has been said before and bears repeating that, irrespective of what the unemployment rate is, an unemployed person is 100 per cent unemployed, and the achievement of lower inflation at the price of unemployment is not acceptable.

Mr Deputy President, I remind you of what this Government said when it first came to office. In 1983, Ralph Willis, the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the man responsible for the Government's performance, stated:

There is an acceptance of high unemployment by no-one on this side. Unlike the previous Government, which could blithely go along tolerating continuously increasing levels of unemployment, we regard those kinds of policies as utterly and totally repugnant.

We are within one per cent of the highest point of unemployment in that 1982-83 recession; in other words, we are back to where we started in terms of unemployment. What does this Government say about it? What is it going to do about it? Nothing, as far as we can tell. Senator Lees says that all she has heard is the discussion on the goods and services tax. She has not been listening. There are a number of things we want to introduce and it has been described as a 12-point plan. This side of the chamber will not be going to the next election with whiz-bang, whistle policies promising that no child will be in poverty, promising that this particular sector will be looked after, and promising more grants for this little sector to buy them off and more grants for that little sector.

We will be going with a complete package and basically saying to the Australian community, `Look, it is not working at the moment. The whole system we have simply is not working'. To try to buy off different sectors with a few little packages of whiz-bang goodies is not going to solve the problem. There is a whole range of things that needs to be done, not the least of which is tax reform. The goods and services tax is just a part of that. We need lower income tax so people can decide more for themselves how they are going to spend their money. Rather than the Government keeping their money and giving it back to them in some form of benefit, it is much better that they keep their money and spend it as they choose.

Senator Lees seems to gloss over labour market reform; she seems to be saying there is nothing in it. When I first came to this Parliament John Howard was laughed at when he said that Australia needed to have enterprise-based bargaining; he was regarded as some voodoo doctor peddling a plan that would never work. Some six years later the Government has adopted his proposal. In fact, even within the existing legislation one can have a form of enterprise bargaining-something that five years ago was incomprehensible; people could not accept that it would happen. However, until we reform the labour market, until we get to the stage when people can negotiate for themselves and until we break out of the system where the big boys-big government, big unions and big business-decide what is happening in this country, until we break that nexus, there will not be an increase in opportunities for people to market their own goods and seize opportunities as they choose.

Senator Lees also referred to the Newstart program; she criticised the Government for it. I do not think it is unreasonable to say, `Yes, if you are genuinely unemployed, we will give you money'. Equally, I do not think it is unreasonable to say that after 12 months of being unemployed a new arrangement must be entered into. One cannot just announce to other taxpayers that one is unemployed and therefore put one's hand out. That is all that is being changed. People are being asked to do as they can for the first 12 months and then, because it is not an indefinite program, arrangements will have to be made after that.

The Opposition supports the Government's Newstart scheme and says that in part it does not go far enough. That does not mean the Government is cutting genuine welfare; it means it is making a sensible arrangement with the people who are getting welfare and is ensuring that none of the welfare dollar is spent on people who are not trying as hard as they can to get a job. In saying that, I do not mean that I believe that 90 per cent of the unemployed are in that position at all but, even if we find only 2 per cent of people collecting a benefit who should not be collecting it, we have to understand that those people are stealing from other taxpayers and are limiting our capacity to pay a decent benefit to genuinely unemployed people. If people are too chicken to come into this Parliament and say they want to weed out the people who are unfairly taking a benefit, in my view, they should not take a seat in this chamber.

I will turn quickly to the 12 things the Liberal Party of Australia thinks need to be done. The Opposition believes some price stability needs to be introduced into the Australian market; a reform of Commonwealth-State relations is long overdue; we need to look at the protection of industry, which has encouraged us to have such inefficient industries for so long; we need labour market reform; we need taxation reform; we need to look at our ever-dwindling infrastructure because this Government cannot be bothered spending any money on it; we need to cut government expenditure because taxpayers are sick of paying for government to do things that they believe private enterprise could do better; we need to offer more services to private enterprise in a way that will enable it to compete and to allow it, rather than the Government, to use the taxpayers' money; we need to streamline our development applications so that people who want to make a buck and progress in this country can get a decent and easy answer about whether they can go ahead with their projects rather than being strung out for months on end and then being told no; we need to review what we are going to do with immigration; we need to improve our education system, instead of locking people out as they have been under the elitist policies of this Government; and, lastly, we need to improve our international standing. If those 12 things are achieved, Australia will be a much better place. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the chamber is debating an urgency motion on unemployment moved by the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I oppose this motion because it is a very selective one which focuses on one aspect of the Australian economy at the present time. It certainly ignores the one million-plus new jobs created under the present Administration. The creation of those jobs under the Hawke Labor Government was perhaps the most important social justice measure seen in Australia in the 1980s.

This motion focuses on the jobless figures released last week and ignores the other economic news released by the official organisations in Australia at the same time. It ignores the healthy economic news and the good economic indicators that came out during last week. It ignores Australia's lower inflation figure and the fact that the lowest annual rate of price rises in Australia since 1970 was recorded up to June this year. That was a wonderful achievement and proves that the Government is getting the economic fundamentals right in the Australian economy.

The motion ignores the profound improvement in the Australian balance of payments; our overseas trading account has improved enormously and, most importantly, there has been an 8 per cent growth in exports. Those facts have been ignored in the motion moved here today by the Liberals. Members of the Liberal Party will not debate inflation or price rises in the Australian economy; they run away from debating those subjects on every possible occasion because they simply have no policies or answers on the questions of prices and price stability in the Australian economy.

We have only to look at the Liberals' record in government during those eight long years from 1975 to 1983 to see the Liberals' record on inflation. Time after time in that period the Liberals went to the Australian people during election campaigns saying, `If elected, our policy would be to fight inflation first'. That is what the Liberals said time and time again during the 1970s and the early 1980s- `We will fight inflation first'-but when they left office after eight years Australia had double digit inflation and price rises of 11.5 per cent up to the March quarter in 1983.

Today the previous speaker in the debate, Senator Vanstone from South Australia, had the nerve to say that one of the 12 points in the Liberal Party's so-called charter is price stability. The Liberals want to have price stability, yet by the time they left office in 1983 all they could bring inflation down to was 11.5 per cent. Under the Hawke Labor Government prices are now rising by only 3.4 per cent; in other words, less than one-third of the figure the Liberals were able to deliver. That is the sort of reality Australia is facing; all we have to do with conservative politicians is look at their record, because that exposes them.

I might say that the 3.4 per cent rise in prices to June this year is well below the average rise in costs for our trading partners and certainly compares very favourably with the average of 6.2 per cent of the industrialised countries of the world as measured by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. Australia's figures, by comparison, are very favourable indeed. It is important to note that recent falls in price increases in Australia have been linked carefully and closely to the falls in interest rates that have occurred in the economy. One good thing now happening is that inflation is bringing interest rates down and, because interest rates are now a component of the consumer price index, they in turn are bringing inflation down.

Of course we on this side of the Parliament are concerned about unemployment. We understand the community anxiety about the level of unemployment; we understand that many Australian employees have lost their livelihoods; we know that it is a very uncomfortable time for many Australian families and we can certainly see-from looking at reports on the Australian work force-that full time male employees, for example, have been hit very hard by the current recession. Last week's unemployment rate of 9.8 per cent is nearly up to the level of 1982-83, when Australia experienced its most severe recession since World War II.

It is important to note that what is actually happening in the economy at present does not reflect the policies now in place; because there are time-lags in economic systems, it reflects the policies of the past. Today's high unemployment figures reflect past, not current, policies; in fact, there are long time lags-months can go by-between a change in policy and the impact on the real economy and on jobs. In fact the unemployment figures of today stem from policies that were in place at the beginning of last year. At the beginning of 1990 Australia had high interest rates-the overnight cash rate was 18 per cent-and a very tight monetary policy was in place. Australia at that stage had a very restrictive fiscal policy, as measured by the difference between government revenue and government spending, and it had a very large Budget surplus in 1989-90 of $8 billion. The conjunction of tight fiscal and monetary policies had the objective of reducing demand for imports from overseas.

That is the problem that the Liberals are not talking about today. These policies were put in place to stem the tide of imports into this country because we did not have the wherewithal to pay for them. We tightened spending in the Australian community in order to cut off the excess demand for imports; we stopped the spill-over from the Australian economy to imports. Certainly, the policies that were in place last year did not have some arbitrary focus-as the Liberals and the National Party suggest today-of deliberately raising unemployment. They were designed to deal with this fundamental problem that existed with Australia's external account and the excess demand for imports which occurred because Australian production was not keeping up with the level of spending in the Australian community and the demand had to go overseas to be met.

The balance of payments situation is showing improvement. The balance of payments figure for the financial year 1990-91 was released last week. The Liberal's motion ignores totally the balance of payment figures released last week which showed a deficit on the current account of some $15.3 billion compared with the figure in the previous financial year of over $22 billion. So there has been a substantial improvement in Australia's external account as a result of the policies of this Government. Very importantly, there has been an 8 per cent rise in Australian exports during 1990-91 compared with the previous financial year.

We have seen substantial cuts in interest rates. I mentioned the 18 per cent cash interest rates at the beginning of last year; those rates have been reduced substantially on a number of occasions to the point where we now have official cash rates of 10 1/2 per cent. So there has been a 7 1/2-percentage point reduction in official interest rates over the last 15 to 18 months.

One of the sectors where reduced interest rates should have some impact in the coming months is the housing sector of the Australian economy. Last financial year there were 120,000 new dwelling commencements in Australia. I note that the Commonwealth Bank of Australia is forecasting 134,000 housing starts this year. Of course, housing is a very labour-intensive sector of the Australian economy and those extra housing starts should help to boost economic activity. They are some of the important things that are happening.

I also note that the 120,000 housing starts last year-and during the last financial year the Liberals kept saying that we were in the worst recession since World War II-compare with the Opposition's figure of only 105,000 new dwelling commencements in 1982-83. That puts the economic situation into some perspective.

The more relaxed monetary and fiscal policies have helped to lower price inflation in the Australian economy. That lower rate of cost increases is taking the pressure off many family budgets and it is certainly helping to keep living costs down for Australian families.

I will take up the wording of this motion and address the indignation that the Liberals appear to have concerning social justice by linking inflation to social justice. One of the findings of a very important royal commission conducted in the United Kingdom was that high inflation really does reduce social justice. High inflation benefits people who tend to have their wealth tied up in assets which increase in value. Low inflation benefits those persons-almost always lower and middle income earners-who have their assets tied up in bank and building society deposits which do not increase in value; they only earn interest on those deposits. So by lowering inflation-and one of the great achievements of this Government is 3.4 per cent inflation-we are in fact tackling this very question of social justice directly by focusing more explicitly on the distribution of income. It is quite clear that high inflation tends to boost the value of those assets which do not have a fixed price and that tends to benefit higher income earners-those who have substantial wealth.

I would now like to explore the policy differences between the Liberal Party and the Government on this question of the economy and jobs. Those opposite have moved this motion today condemning us for our role in the economy. What is different about their policies that would allow them to somehow wave their magic wand over the Australian economy and boost investment, production and jobs? What would they do about this economy that is different from what this Government has done?

I suppose we need to look at the Opposition's record in government; we need to look at what those opposite achieved the last time they were in government. I have already pointed to their double digit inflation-11 1/2 per cent price rises compared with 3.4 per cent now. Their record on unemployment was terrible: in 1982-83 unemployment was between 10 and 11 per cent of the available labour force. That is the record of those opposite. It is not a good base upon which to begin an analysis.

But the Opposition's major policy difference is in its proposal for a value added tax. Dr Hewson is hell-bent on taxing all expenditure in the Australian economy. Of course, we all know that the first thing a value added tax will do is kick-start inflation. We have gone through all of the pain and suffering of reducing inflation to 3 per cent; why on earth do we want a 15 per cent value added tax which will put 7 per cent on top of the consumer price index? Why do we want double digit inflation in the Australian economy again?

I ask those opposite: how would this tax proposal benefit the creation of jobs? After all, it is a tax on spending and we all know that spending creates investment, production and employment. So how do those opposite propose that a consumption tax-this value added tax-will improve employment in the Australian economy? It is very clear that, in some cases, the tax will encourage people to buy more imported products and it will create a spill-over of spending from the Australian economy to imported products.

I instance the case of luxury motor cars. Those opposite are proposing a Rolls Royce-led recovery. These are the people who want a limousine-led recovery. Let us look at this example: at the present time we tax luxury motor vehicles retailing for over $45,000 at a 30 per cent tax rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is your policy to reduce the import duty on Mercedes or not?

—But if the Liberals bring in a 15 per cent value added tax the price of luxury motor vehicles will fall. That is self-evident. For example, a Mercedes 4-door sedan SE model, which retails for $99,600 at the moment, will fall substantially in price under these policies. This is a question that the Liberals cannot answer: will we have a tax inspector-led recovery?

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that those opposite will need a massive number of inspectors in order to police this value added tax because it is a retail tax not a wholesale tax. At the present time there are only 75,000 taxpaying points in Australia under a wholesale tax. Those opposite want a retail tax and there are many more multiples of retailers than wholesalers in Australia. There are 750,000 retail outlets in Australia so there will be 10 times as much paperwork and 10 times as much red tape for small business. Those opposite are always going on about red tape for small business, yet they will have a tax inspector-led recovery. This is how they will do something about unemployment: they will have more tax inspectors in the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal very briefly with Senator Maguire's quaint contribution. It was incredible that when I interjected to ask, `Is it a fact that the Labor Party's new car plan will bring a massive reduction in import duties on Rolls Royces and Mercedes?' Senator Maguire had no answer. That is where the big cut in the price of luxury cars will come from: Senator Maguire's Party's policy on the car industry. So we hear more bunkum from Senator Maguire who refuses to face the facts when they are put to him.

SPEECH.PARA: However, one thing that fascinated me about Senator Maguire's contribution was his happy remark that today's unemployment figures relate to past policies-last year's policies. Guess whose they were? They were Mr Keating's policies; they are not the Government's policies. There is now a fall guy whom the Government can blame. Mr Keating's policies-last year's policies-are the reason for the present problem, not today's policies. Suddenly this Government has become pure by getting rid of Mr Keating. I suppose we could wonder where Senator Maguire lines up in the hold-Hawke or kick-Keating brigades.

I was also intrigued to see that Senator Maguire concentrated on the wonderful improvement in Australia's economy. That followed the line used by Senator Evans today in his reply to a question of mine during Question Time. He claimed responsibility for the policies that brought down inflation. By the way, he did not add that inflation was brought down at the cost of a recession and job losses. This was a deliberately engineered-to quote Mr Keating-recession which produced engineered job losses. That is what we are talking about today. Our motion reads:
That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

The need to condemn the Government for deliberately creating massive job losses and unemployment through its disastrous economic policies which have made a mockery of its professed concern for social justice.

For the first time in a long time I agree with Senator Lees from the Australian Democrats. She asked the rhetorical question: maybe it was not deliberate-by inference, maybe it was simply incompetence. She sided, quite properly, with the view that it was deliberate because, as Mr Keating said, this was an engineered recession. However, this recession brought with it an incredible level of engineered unemployment, particularly for young people.
Even worse than all this is the fact that Mr Keating is proud of his achievement. During the weekend he said:
I am very happy with the outcome of my period as Treasurer.

That outcome, as everyone knows, is the worst recession since the 1930s Depression. It is an outcome of record unemployment and record job losses, especially for young Australians; a record and still rising foreign debt, which requires more than $1 billion a month simply to service, so continuing Australia's disastrous balance of payments crisis with which Senator Maguire is quite happy.

Despite our incredible recession, we still have horrendous balance of payments figures. And Senator Maguire thinks that is wonderful. Like Mr Keating, he regards them as a lovely set of figures. The unemployment rate is a lovely set of figures; the massive youth job loss rate is a lovely set of figures.

It seems incredible to me that the former Treasurer can express happiness at the misery that he has imposed. I guess I should not just refer to him because these were Government decisions. It is not the case, as Senator Maguire says, that these were last year's decisions and Keating was responsible for them. These were Government decisions which have imposed misery on so many honest Australians.

Honourable senators will remember that during the 1990 election, a little less than a year and a half ago, the Government asked the people of Australia to have faith in it. In the 1990 Budget, this time last year, Mr Keating acknowledged the faith that Australians had in the Hawke-Keating Government by saying that that faith:

. . . is now being repaid as the economy adjusts to a sustainable rate of growth without a catastrophic collapse . . . employment will pick up . . . in short, the kind of outcome the government was seeking, delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.

It is not good enough for Senator Maguire to come in here and say, `Oh, they were last year's policies'. They were policies that this Government supported-policies which this Government said would bring about increased employment; policies which would not bring about a recession. In other words, either the Government was deliberately lying at the time or it was monumentally incompetent. I would have thought that Senator Maguire might have had the honesty to deal with what the Government said would happen as against the actual outcome, which is disastrous.

Honourable senators will remember that in 1983 Mr Hawke said that `no Australian government should ever be forgiven for creating the levels of youth unemployment of the last couple of years, which cannot and should not be tolerated'. He was, of course, referring to the Fraser Government. Yet now we have levels of youth unemployment, as measured by the number of young Australians aged 15 to 19 who cannot get a full time job, which are far greater than those that existed under the Fraser Government. I think this Government should be reminded of the way in which it played politics with youth unemployment at that time and its sudden submersing of any suggestion that somehow what is happening now is disgraceful.

This is an engineered recession. What happened in 1982-83, which has been exceeded now in terms of its extent, was certainly not engineered. It was a result of the worst drought for 50 years. Yet here we now have an engineered, a deliberately created, level of youth unemployment which exceeds the levels of 1983.

Just how bad are the facts? Those facts should be put on the record. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two tables, which I have referred to the Minister. One, which deals with the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate going back for the last 10 years, dramatises how horrific the present youth unemployment rate is. The other table, which relates to employed persons aged 15 to 19 in Australia, shows how jobs have been wiped out under this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. These figures reveal that 129,200 full time jobs in Australia have been wiped out over the last 12 months. That is the biggest 12-month loss ever recorded for young Australians. There are now only 301,100 15- to 19-year olds in full time work. Compared with 10 years ago under the Fraser Government, there are something like 236,000 fewer young Australians in full time work.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result, youth unemployment has risen, seasonally adjusted, to 28.5 per cent, which is three times as large as the adult employment rate. It is the worst level for youth unemployment since the 1930s Depression. It far exceeds the 1983 recession peak of 27.6 per cent which Mr Hawke said, as honourable senators will remember, is a level which no government should ever be forgiven for creating. I stress that this level was created; it was engineered.

I noted this morning- I will repeat it now-that the five Labor government States had the worst youth unemployment rates in Australia, while the Liberal-National Government in New South Wales managed to hold against the trend and had the lowest level of all States, which is still unacceptably high, of 25.5 per cent.

This disaster is not simply taking place in the area of youth unemployment. I might say that these figures do not reveal the full extent of the disaster. In the 12 months to July the total number of jobs lost in the Australian population was 337,000. At the same time, the population of those over 15 years of age increased by 227,000. When we combine the number of jobs lost with the increased population, we should theoretically have had an unemployment increase of 564,000. That is almost double what it was a year ago. In other words, it should have almost doubled to 1.1 million. That is the real unemployment level today.

As I said, we have had jobs wiped out and we have had an increase in the population. If the figures were fair dinkum we would have 1.1 million people out of work. Instead, most of these people have disappeared out of the statistics. The unemployment level rose by only 232,000 instead of 564,000. Where have the other 330,000 people disappeared to? They are not in the statistics. They are out of the work force.

Something like 5.1 million Australians are not registered by the Australian Bureau of Statistics as being in the work force. According to the Bureau of Statistics, almost 40 per cent of Australians are not in the work force. In other words, people have been discouraged, people have given up or people are not being counted as unemployed because of some very curious statistical requirements, which I think Senator Walters referred to earlier today.

For young Australians it is the same situation. For young Australians, wiping out 129,200 full time jobs over the past 12 months means that, after taking into account the fact that there are 37,700 fewer 15-to 19-year-olds in the population, teenage unemployment should have risen by about 91,500 in that time. Instead of showing that, the official figures show that the full time unemployment figure was up by only about 19,000. What happened to the remaining 72,000 young Australians? Did they just disappear, or did they just disappear out of the statistics?

If these 72,000 people who have just disappeared were added back to the unemployment figure, we would get a youth unemployment rate in Australia of 44 per cent. That is the real rate. Of course, the Government has hidden it. It has hidden it in some ways which may bring some benefit to some of these young people. To an extent it has hidden it by now paying Austudy to secondary school students. That means that many of them are going back to school. Those people who are going back to school will, to some extent, receive a benefit in the sense that their options will be increased, but by no means all of them will get that benefit. Many of them are, in effect, going into a school situation which is not bringing them specific benefits, which is not aimed at increasing their qualifications and which is becoming something of a teenager-sitting exercise aimed at reducing the evident level of youth unemployment. There is no disadvantage to young people in going back to school because Austudy is at the same level as the unemployment benefit.

We have seen what has happened. Compared with the situation in, say, 1983 there are now 157,500 young people looking for work, full time or part time. That is about 9,000 fewer than in 1983, but an extra 120,000 are being paid to stay on at school. There is no doubt that the Government's decision has helped to reduce the size of the unemployment queues, but the real rate of youth unemployment now is about 44 per cent. How long will young Australians be forced to carry the burden of the Government's deliberate recession policies?

It keeps getting worse. The Government says, and Senator Maguire says, `Things are getting better; look at the lovely sets of figures'. We will believe that there are lovely sets of figures when we see youth unemployment actually falling, when we see total unemployment actually falling, when we see this economy actually picking up and moving forward. The way to get that is to have the basic reforms that we have been talking about and which this Government has been rejecting for years. We want basic labour market reform. We want basic tax reform to get rid of the chaos of the ludicrous tax system where an unreasonable burden is carried by the people who pay PAYE tax. That is one of the reasons we want to introduce a goods and services tax which is much fairer than the present hidden and discriminatory sales tax.

We want the economy to pick up. Nothing that this Government has done is directed at improving the basic economy of this nation. The Government has no policies other than recession driven policies. It has kicked this economy down. It has engineered the unemployment which at present is a disgrace, at a level which I believe is totally intolerable and must not be allowed to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in opposition to the urgency motion moved by Senator Alston. I must say that it has always been less than convincing to hear a conservative politician of any description or any stripe talk about unemployment. That is not only my experience but it is also the experience of generations of people in the Labor movement in this country. People look to a political party to provide some insight into problems that confront the nation. People look to a political party to provide an alternative when it resides in opposition. If we look at the proposition moved by Senator Alston this afternoon, it is immediately clear that the matter of urgency which he has outlined for the Senate's consideration lacks merit of any kind. There is no alternative policy prescription placed before the chamber this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I have been here, I have noticed that that can be said with equal force about all the urgency motions that arise from those opposite. The Opposition remains devoid of alternative policy prescriptions. As I listened to the debate this afternoon, to Senator Vanstone and to Senator Michael Baume, in particular, I waited for an alternative analysis, for an outline of policy, for a single initiative; aside from the goods and services tax-as my colleague Senator Maguire more accurately describes it, a value added tax-there is not one initiative apparent from those opposite. The sum total of what would be achieved by the passage of this motion by the Senate this afternoon would be precisely nought; the urgency motion means precisely nothing.

The urgency motion before the Senate this afternoon not only lacks a capacity to appreciate an economic circumstance, but also affords no capacity to the chamber to evaluate circumstances. That brings me to the Opposition parties generally. If we are to talk in terms of leadership I think it is fair to look with some degree of evaluation at the Liberal and National parties around the country. Just recently in Western Australia we saw the absolute catastrophe of the Floreat by-election at which I gather, and Senator Maguire may know better, some honourable senators from the Liberal Party in Western Australia had more than a passing hand-a very close and abiding interest in internal Liberal Party politics in that State.

We had a circumstance where an official Liberal Party candidate was rejected by the Liberals' own constituency in precisely the same manner in which the press gallery voted with its feet this afternoon when Senator Alston rose to speak. Members of the press gallery did not even need to look at the urgency motion in detail to tell that it meant nought and would achieve nought, to tell at a glance that it was simply ritualistic. I must say that it was with an almost unseemly haste that members of the fourth estate departed the gallery this afternoon. But who can blame them? Having endured enough of these urgency motions, more than a few honourable senators would be wanting to depart in precisely the same way.

We have seen the Liberal Party in utter chaos in the State of Western Australia. In the State of Tasmania we have seen the Opposition Leader, Mr Gray, spend more time before a royal commission than in the Parliament. The State of Victoria gives us a classic example of how the leadership of the Liberal Party is in absolute terminal deterioration. Only two or three months ago we had Mr Kennett re-elected to the Liberal Party leadership in Victoria, in the type of revolving door leadership displays in which the Liberals excel. Mr Brown departed; Mr Kennett re-entered-enter stage right!

One of Mr Kennett's first initiatives was to threaten the superannuation of Labor members in the Victorian Parliament. For about 60 minutes this appeared to be a clever idea. It then suddenly occurred to everyone that superannuation, as a hard won right within the Australian industrial work force, could be threatened not only at the parliamentary level but also at any other level by a Liberal government. As my colleague Senator Foreman knows from hard experience in the trade union movement, rights such as superannuation are won after a long struggle. They are not something people want to give up.

Mr Kennett's ploy backfired in the most demonstrable way possible. He was forced to withdraw. In the process of withdrawing, he plummeted a full 20 percentage points in terms of public estimation of his leadership capacity. We now see Mrs Kirner, the Victorian Premier, again heading him as the preferred Premier in that State.

I make these points because Senator Alston and other Opposition senators talk of leadership. Senator Baume is fond of talking about New South Wales and what a marvellous administration the Greiner-Murray Government is. `A marvellous administration', we hear from Federal Liberal senators. Of course, the public estimation is entirely different.

It is a contradiction in terms to talk about a Liberal Party election campaign-they are mutually exclusive terms. By Christmas we will see precisely what this second term of the Greiner-Murray Government is worth. We had a circumstance in which the Liberal and National parties could not lose the State election of 25 May. They kept telling us so. They told the electorate of New South Wales they could not lose. The very day that the Leader of the Liberal Party in New South Wales, Mr Greiner, announced the State election he was featured in one of the metropolitan newspapers in Sydney eating an ice cream. He had nothing else to do-nothing by way of a campaign. In just the same way as the Liberal Party threw away the Brisbane City Council because it is massively incompetent when it comes to a leadership circumstance, massively incompetent in a circumstance in which people have to make a judgment upon it-the Brisbane City Council is now long gone-we now have a minority government in New South Wales. It is now 49 plus one: the Greiner-Murray-Windsor Government. That is Liberal and National Party leadership.

I do not need to dwell on the state of the Liberal Party in Queensland. It can be dismissed utterly in the State Parliament and we know the manner in which the Brisbane City Council-the Liberal Party's one remaining political asset in that State-was lost, again in a fiasco of a campaign: smug and self-satisfied.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: what relevance does this have to the urgency motion before the chamber?
—You are asking me to rule on a point of order, Senator, and there is no point of order.

—This afternoon we have another ritual incantation from Opposition senators. The more they say these things, the more they actually come to believe them. So let us have a look not only at their chaotic organisation-because they are the ones who raised leadership-but also at their absolute policy chaos. Let us focus for a moment on the goods and services tax. The other morning I watched with some interest as the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party in the House of Representatives, Mr Reith, was interviewed by Laurie Oakes on the Sunday program. Again, I thought we might actually see a policy detail emerge through inadvertence- `It could not be deliberate but it will be through inadvertence'.
—But we decide, not you.

—I will take the interjection from Senator Baume because the question has to be asked rhetorically: when will the Opposition decide? The battle lines are clearly being drawn. We will have a circumstance where, if two days after John Kerin delivers the Budget in the House of Representatives Dr Hewson rises and says, `The consumption tax is something to which we are committed', we will fight the general election on it. What those opposite now know is that they cannot win an election on the basis of a consumption tax. That is the beauty of the circumstance. They will not win it. It is not a political argument which they can sustain and win. The battle lines will be drawn two days afterwards, when John Hewson rises in the House of Representatives, because members of the Opposition will not be able to walk away from it. If they stay with a consumption tax between now and the general election, they will not win the argument. It will be interesting to test opinion.

SPEECH.PARA: There is absolute chaos opposite. What figure will the consumption tax be? Will it be 15 per cent, 12 1/2 per cent or 10 per cent? To whom will it apply? As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made clear in an address to the Federated Ironworkers national conference a couple of weeks ago, every time a family goes to the football, to a cricket match or out for a meal at a fast food outlet; every time a family visits the doctor or the dentist; every time a taxpayer seeks advice from an accountant or has to complete a tax return; every time a family goes to the movies or the theatre, or parents take their kids to the circus-every time families are involved in any of the routine pursuits by which Australians pursue a reasonable, open standard of living, by which they pursue a certain degree of happiness-the tax man and woman will be present.

There is a circumstance in which, as Senator Maguire said earlier, we will have a Taxation Office led recovery. But a few things have to be said about the GST. I suddenly notice, Madam Acting Deputy President, the supreme reign of silence opposite when the GST is mentioned-the utter reign of silence, even from Senator Baume, and to render Senator Baume silent is no mean accomplishment.

We have a tax which is peculiarly regressive. There is a circumstance that confronts us now by which, when the battle lines are drawn, we will have a regressive tax as the centrepiece, the core, of Opposition economic policy. That is what the general election of 1993 will be fought upon because the Opposition will be committed to a regressive and inflationary tax. What will happen when that inflationary tax applies? It will apply with the greatest force to those who can least afford to pay. Obviously, that is of no concern to the Liberal and National parties. It never has been. The living standards of working people have never featured in anything those parties have ever said or done in any of their platforms or in any of their political commitments. We will have a circumstance in which a 15 per cent GST-presuming that is what the Liberal and National parties commit themselves to; we do not know because they are not saying-will apply with greatest force upon people who can least afford to pay it in all those everyday situations that I have outlined.

A few days ago we had Dr Hewson in New Zealand telling us that the Bolger Government was showing the way to go. That was a first class opportunity for anyone who wanted to look at present New Zealand economic and political circumstances and to draw the appropriate conclusions. It will be done. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has committed himself to applause on the Bolger Government. Senator Maguire nods in agreement because he understands at a stroke what utter chaos has occurred in New Zealand under the Bolger Government: the cutting of massive holes in the social security net; the explosion in unemployment; the massive protest marches; and the enormous disaffection that the Bolger Government's Budget has caused even in the ranks of Mr Bolger's own party.

That is the formula Dr Hewson wants to translate to an Australian political context. He has said so. We do not need to dwell on the Canadian experience with the GST; we have the New Zealand experience right before us, just across the Tasman. That will be instructive as we move again to a general election. So the focus after this Budget will be on Dr Hewson's reply. We will see how brave, committed and buoyant those opposite are when they go to the Australian people committed to the most regressive and inflationary form of taxation imaginable. That will be a fight for us, worth fighting and worth winning.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
