DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Report to the Minister for Transport and Communications

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

In speaking to this Report to the Minister for Transport and Communications entitled Film and Television Co-Productions, I would like to address my remarks not so much to the matter of communications policy but rather to trade and industry policy. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal would have to be one of the most ideological arms of government. Mr Peter Westerway has been the general secretary of the New South Wales branch of the ALP, the party's campaign director in that State, the chairman of the economics and trade committee of the ALP Federal Executive and Treasurer of the Federal Executive. This is the man to whom the Government is entrusting the enforcement of the proposed ban on electronic political broadcasting.

The ABT wallows in philosophical squalor. One could even say that broadcasting in this country is somehow incapable of standing on its own two feet and should be propped up with industry protection in the form of local content requirement and the various ownership laws which seem to be a perpetual and movable feast. But this is no different from the impact of trade protection that we have in other areas of industry. Take the Australian music quota on radio, for instance. The quota has led to the most absurd outcomes.

I am aware of an ethnic public radio station in Adelaide which broadcasts in 48 different languages but found that it was playing Waltzing Matilda during Turkish programs just to meet the quota. In Sydney, an easy listening station has been forced to make its own substandard records because there was insufficient new Australian music available in the format in which it, particularly, broadcasts. Stations also face competition with the ABC whose stations are totally immune to the Tribunal's requirements-quite relevant when it comes to the ratings.

This report, which adds precious little to the debate on the opening up of broadcasting to international competition, is now before us. I have an immediate interest in a section of the report relating to the Australia-New Zealand closer economic relations agreement. The Tribunal rejected a joint submission from two New Zealand independent television production companies complaining of the Tribunal's television program standard No. 14 entitled `Australian content of television programs'. The Tribunal concluded that the only barrier to New Zealand competition lies in limits on foreign ownership as set out in the Broadcasting Act. The report states:
. . . it should be noted that New Zealand productions are currently allowed free access to the Australian broadcast media.
I find this to be an extraordinary statement.

The coalition now offers a genuine alternative in this area. Last week, my colleague the shadow Minister for trade negotiations, Mr Alexander Downer, released the Opposition's policy on closer economic relations with New Zealand. That policy committed the coalition to removing local content regulations for television and broadcasting as far as New Zealand is concerned and, most importantly, to allowing New Zealand interests to invest on the same terms as Australian interests in television and broadcasting in this country.

If we are serious about seeing that closer economic relations mean that we will allow a single market to operate between Australia and New Zealand so that we take the benefits of an enlarged population base, then surely the area of telecommunications is one of the most important that must be opened up. There is no problem in Australia's being able to put programs to air in New Zealand, and yet we seem to be full of fear that New Zealand may be able to put something into Australian television which somehow would not fit with the way that we consider broadcasts should be made. In looking at this report, I would say that one could describe it with one word-disappointing.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I rise to speak on Report No. 11 of the Industry Commission to indicate yet again the totally unsatisfactory nature of the way in which the Industry Commission is now operating. Honourable senators will recall that when we dealt with the legislation for the creation of this Industry Commission, amendments were successfully moved by the Australian Democrats-and accepted by the Government-that the Industry Commission would take as a constant reference consideration of the environmental consequences of whatever it was that was before it at the time. No industry affects the environment in this country more than the electricity generating industry. The Industry Commission has again failed to address properly the environmental impact of electricity generation.

It is about time that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, as the Minister responsible, began to properly discharge his duty in directing the Industry Commission to carry out its function properly under its Act and so far Senator Button has failed to do that. I indicated that the last time I spoke on one of these reports-the IC report on the motor vehicle industry in this country. As I recall it, in that report of some 250 pages, about three-quarters of a page was devoted to the environmental impact of the motor vehicle industry. That is again a totally unsatisfactory doffing of the Commission's hat to its responsibility to address the environmental question.

The IC has one commissioner appointed to its commissioners and it has totally inadequate staff to properly discharge its function in relation to considering environmental matters. Again, I point to the Minister responsible, Senator Button, who is not properly discharging his responsibility as the Minister and not seeing that the IC is properly discharging its responsibility under its Act.

We only have a few brief moments to look at the summary and recommendations of this report before us. The summary and recommendations, which are in volume I of the report, cover 28 pages of which less than a page deals with the environmental consequences. For instance, we find on page 13, in the section dealing with load management energy conservation-which is the only part of the summary dealing with these matters-these words:
Corporatised utilities should not be required to pursue energy conservation initiatives that are contrary to their commercial interests.

There one sees clearly the distortion by the IC of its responsibility, in that it is taking the commercial interests of the electricity generating authorities and subsuming their environmental and conservation responsibilities to those commercial interests. In other words, if they can sell more electricity and make more money by selling more electricity, then irrespective of the consequences in terms of resource usage, irrespective of the consequences in terms of greenhouse gas emissions and irrespective of the consequences in terms of other pollution and social environmental consequences, that is the course that they should follow, according to the Industry Commission.
Further on in the same section dealing with conservation the report mentions a number of conservation measures that might be taken, and then goes on to say:

These latter measures severely curtail consumer choice. It is not clear whether such actions are warranted. It needs to be established that these programs can provide net benefits to society, taking into account both direct and indirect costs.
That entirely leaves out considerations of the environmental consequences, which the Industry Commission, under its Act, is charged to investigate and to report upon.

The final summary has six schedules dealing with these matters in detail, and then only three brief points at the end, the first one of which is to `remove government requirements that electricity and gas utilities pursue noncommercial demand side management activities'-in other words, the precise things that the electricity authorities should be required to do in a properly managed industry. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was getting a little excited there because Senator Coulter was speaking about energy conservation and alternative environmental type power sources. The last point in the recommendations says:

SPEECH.PARA: . provided that appropriate environmental and other safeguards are in place, allow the development of nuclear electricity generation in Australia to be determined by commercial considerations.
It will be very interesting to see, when those safeguards are in place, where Senator Coulter stands as far as that alternative energy source is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad you said `when safeguards are in place'. You have identified the problem.

—No, I have not identified the problem. I am just making the point about when everyone is happy about them being in place. As far as I am concerned, they are in place now, because they are being used around the world at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I take note of a few points in this report. The electricity and gas supply industries are among Australia's biggest, and their combined annual output was in the order of about $7 billion, or about 2.5 per cent of GDP. They are very big industries. Both industries are capital intensive in their production facilities and they require large expanding transmission and distribution networks, and the lives of major assets range from about 30 to 60 years in Australia at the moment. The industries supply vital inputs to a wide range of Australian industries. The electricity and gas supply industries have not been performing to their full potential. Participants in the inquiry acknowledge significant shortcomings in performance. That is, of course, where the coalition stands as far as this report is concerned.

We believe that the report is a good report. It makes some very good points about sharing electricity around Australia; about energy interchange on both an opportunity and contract basis; and about incentives to increase efficiency through increased competition and greater planning flexibility. That is what the coalition believes that we need when establishing an Australian electricity grid-which we call Auselgrid-because at the moment essentially all our electricity is generated on stand-alone State systems with limited interconnection. If we can get them all interconnected, if we can get them all working together, we will actually save a lot of power generation needs and we will make the whole of the generation distribution network in Australia much more cost effective. We believe that that is something that has to come. This report goes towards solving the problems with the power industries in Australia, and I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the Industry Commission's Report No. 11 on electricity generation and distribution. In a period of recession the most welcome news in this report is that there is easily realisable scope for improving efficiency in energy generation in Australia and that the potential gains are large-in the order of $2.4 billion a year. The report covers electricity and gas supplies, but today I will speak only on electricity.

SPEECH.PARA: The report notes that in the 1980s poor investment decisions led to excess capacity and gross overstaffing in the industry. In most overseas countries it is usual to have a 20 to 25 per cent reserve margin, whereas Australia, since the 1980s, has had a 40 to 70 per cent reserve plant margin, more than double the general requirement overseas. This was largely because one morning Neville Wran had to have a cold shower when the whole system in New South Wales failed. The resulting construction activity led to the present situation of too much generating capacity.

The Industry Commission has estimated that, if the electricity supply industry's performance was up to best international practice, national output could expand by $2.2 billion annually. In other words, $2.2 billion is the annual cost to the nation of the centralised planning system which has been imposed on this industry. Reform to the industry could increase household disposable income by $300 per year. As a result of this, the Industry Commission has estimated, up to 8,000 new jobs could be created.

How do we achieve these benefits? The Industry Commission urgently recommends action to increase competition by restructuring the electricity supply industry, and sets out very clearly in the report, step by step, how this can be done. First, ring fence or separate generation, transmission and distribution assets in all States. For transmission, the Commission advocates the establishment of a national grid for New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania. By separating transmission-which, because of the costs involved, is recognised as being a natural monopoly-it is possible to stimulate private sector interest in new generating capacity. To achieve this, the Commission proposes that existing government owned generating capacity be split into a number of independent generating units that would compete against each other, as well as against new private generators.

This report is well timed. Only two weeks ago the communique from the special Premiers Conference supported the establishment of the proposed National Grid Management Council to encourage open access to the eastern and southern Australian grid and free trade in bulk electricity for private and public electricity customers. Government representatives agreed that the interconnectives between New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and the ACT were feasible and justified. The New South Wales restructuring, which is already under way, is very much in line with the findings of this report. Elcom's generating plant in New South Wales will be split into regional units and they will compete to supply the grid.

New South Wales is in a superior position to sell power to other States, because it has the cleanest and most efficient coal and its Electricity Commission has already been restructured to maximise efficiency. This is expected to lead to a 5 per cent reduction in bills in the next two years.

In the Hunter Valley, where I reside, the proposed changes will have an enormous benefit. The Hunter produces 80 per cent of New South Wales electricity and 24 per cent of the nation's supply. The region is now able to compete with other States to supply electricity to the whole of eastern Australia, and with the recent completion of a number of new power stations will, because of its excess capacity, be able to supply other areas in the economy. I mention Victoria, in particular. I recommend this report to the Senate and urge support for its recommendations for a more competitive and efficient power industry by implementing the findings as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to mention briefly a few matters that are relevant to energy generation within Australia. In doing so, I note that the introductory paragraph of the summary and recommendations shows that electricity and gas supply industries are amongst Australia's biggest. In the 1986-87 year, their combined annual output was in the order of $7 billion. That figure sticks in my mind.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that it is the same amount that the Australian Democrats want to collect in additional taxes in their alternative budget, which was apparently released on the weekend. I suppose that the figure of $7 billion shows just what big industries the electricity and gas supply industries are when we compare that figure with the amount that the Democrats want to collect in additional taxes from Australians at this particular time.

As I mentioned, I want to speak briefly about three aspects of electricity and energy generation. One has been mentioned by Senator Brownhill; that is, uranium as a fuel. That seems to me to be a direction in which Australia must go in getting fuel which is clean, cheap and for which Australia has plenty of reserves and resources. It seems to me absolutely ridiculous that the Government should continue with its three-mine policy when there is this good resource of uranium available for electricity and energy generation. It amazes me that neither the Government nor the Democrats bother to pursue that very efficient use of fuel.

The other matter I want to mention briefly is the Tully Millstream hydro-electricity project, which is proposed in the area from where I hail. That project has won resounding support from many areas. All of the local authorities in the area support the scheme absolutely, as do the Queensland State Labor Government and most politicians of all parties in the north Queensland area. Most of them realise that at the moment north Queensland is very much at risk in the area of power generation and power supplies when cyclones and other natural calamities come our way. We need an additional source of energy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Excess capacity.

—Excess capacity is what the Democrats keep talking about, but in all of the reports issued there is an indication that more capacity is needed, even in spite of conservation programs being undertaken by the Queensland Electricity Commission at present. It is needed as we approach the turn of the century, and that extra generation must be provided. It is also needed in that in times of natural calamity north Queensland, in particular, needs a guaranteed source of supply.
—A lot of sun up there.

—Can Senator Kernot produce some figures that show that solar power is feasible? If she can, she is doing things that scientists and experts cannot do. But that is typical of the Democrats attitude to life. They tend to live in fairyland and think that if they wish these things would happen, therefore, they will happen. There has been quite a deal of research into solar power by the Queensland Electricity Commission, and it has proved to be inappropriate at present. Again, Tully Millstream will provide hydro-electric energy, which is the cleanest fuel that we can get. Why a party that prides itself on opposing fossil fuels and the greenhouse effect is opposed to something that will provide such clean and efficient energy is entirely beyond me.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I wish to mention briefly the coal bed methane projects that are being investigated in the Bowen basins. The way of extracting coal bed methane from the ground and harnessing it is a very new concept, one which the Americans have for some years, as I understand it, perfected. They are using that to--(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak on the Industry Commission report on energy generation and distribution until I heard Senator Macdonald recommending that we turn to nuclear energy. I thought I should share with Senator Macdonald and with other honourable senators my experience in Eastern Europe just a couple of weeks ago.

SPEECH.PARA: In Slovakia there are two atomic power stations and, in Hungary, there are four. The communities living in the shadow of those power stations are making every conceivable possible effort to be able to decommission them, to look for alternative sources of energy. They are living in the shadow of Chernobyl. I recommend that Senator Macdonald should travel to Chernobyl and perhaps even acquire a holiday home near Chernobyl so that he can experience first-hand the problems of living in the shadow of nuclear power.

In Austria two atomic power stations were almost complete when a referendum was held and the people of Austria had the good sense and foresight to vote against them. The Government is now, in response to a referendum, decommissioning those two nuclear power stations. I believe that we should learn from the experiences overseas. I do not think we should make the same mistakes again, and we should stop this babble about nuclear energy when the whole world is turning away from it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am advised by Senator Collins that the President will be making a report at 6 o'clock with respect to the industrial disputation which has been affecting and afflicting the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I want to say a few words about the Australian Federal Police. Three emblems appear on the outside of the National Common Police Services Annual Report: those of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, the Australian Police Staff College and the National Police Research Unit, all of which have close relationships with the Australian Federal Police. Their emblems appear on the cover of this pamphlet.

There has been a great turnabout in the Australian Federal Police. It is a most efficient organisation and a very happy one. That change has taken place since 1987. Three people deserve special mention for bringing about that situation. First, there is Mr McAulay, the Commissioner. Secondly, there is Mr Chris Eaton, who was Secretary of the Australian Federal Police Association, the union of the Federal Police. He retired from that position earlier this year, but was a most excellent Secretary of that Association. The third person is the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Michael Tate. On an occasion like this, I think it is proper to pay tribute to those three men.

While Senator Tate has been Minister, while Mr McAulay has been Commissioner and while Chris Eaton has been Secretary, there has been a restructuring of the Australian Federal Police force. That has been most successfully and most happily carried out. Indeed, the fame of the force has now travelled to the extent where a Deputy Commissioner, Mr John Johnson, has been appointed the Commissioner of the Tasmanian police force. This is an occasion where tribute can be paid to him, too, a person whom I have met and who has recently taken up his position. I take this opportunity to wish him and his wife, Pat, the very best now that they have gone down to Tasmania, a great State which has been the birthplace of some very great people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know where McAulay came from, don't you?
—May I say that he came from the Northern Territory. He most successfully served that Territory. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 13 February 1991, I lay on the table a report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration entitled List of Commonwealth Bodies which was presented to the Acting Deputy President, Senator Burns, on 27 June 1991. In accordance with the terms of the resolution, the Acting Deputy President has authorised the printing and circulation of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Mr Acting Deputy President, as you said, the report List of Commonwealth Bodies, which has now been tabled, was presented early in the winter recess and was released publicly around that time. I would like to comment briefly on its scope and purpose. The list aims to record all Commonwealth bodies and to provide basic information about their structure. It is the most comprehensive listing of bodies in the Commonwealth public sector.

The list shows that there are now 506 statutory authorities and offices and 450 non-statutory bodies in the Commonwealth administration. The Committee has also identified 494 companies and incorporated associations which are either owned by the Australian Government or in which the Government has a substantial interest.

The Committee has been concerned for many years that government agencies outside the mainstream Public Service departments may escape parliamentary accountability. The absence of a consolidated list of bodies kept up-to-date by the Government is an important gap in the accountability system. The Committee has recommended several times in the past that the Government itself should maintain an up-to-date list of government bodies. Successive governments have rejected that recommendation and the Committee has been forced to maintain its own list.

This report, the latest of 15 produced by the Committee since 1979 listing Commonwealth bodies of various types, is derived from a new computer database developed by the Committee. The Committee proposes to keep the database up to date and to extend its coverage progressively. Although it is the most comprehensive list so far produced, there are still the inevitable gaps and the usual problems which result when information becomes dated. One gap which the Committee proposes to examine in more detail over the next few months is the extent of Commonwealth involvement in unincorporated joint ventures and partnerships, unit trusts and funds, and holdings of preference shares in some companies.

It will be obvious from the size of the document that development and maintenance of the database and production of the report were substantial tasks. I place on record the Committee's thanks to those of its staff who worked on this project, particularly Chris James, who was seconded from the Department of Finance and who developed the database, and Michael Game and Mick McLean who collected and checked the data. I seek leave to continue my remarks on another occasion.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the referral of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 to a select committee. This Bill is the product of a discredited government and a discredited Minister. Certainly the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) must carry the odium of his handling of this outrageous Bill. But it must not be forgotten that it was endorsed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Cabinet. If my memory is correct, at the time this Bill was introduced the Prime Minister was quoted in the media as saying, in reference to Dr Hewson, `Let's teach this kid a lesson'. Those words have come back to haunt this Government, this Minister and this Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: From all the public statements on this atrocious Bill, it is interesting to note that there are only three people whom I know of who have supported it: Mr Bob Hogg, the Federal Secretary of the ALP; the ACTU itself; and Phillip Adams. What a wonderful list of people to support this Bill!

This Bill was first mooted by Bob Hogg in 1990. Following this rumour, I asked the Minister whether he was planning legislation. I also asked him, `Since when were non-elected party apparatchiks telling the Government what to do?'. The Minister, in replying, took high umbrage and said unequivocally that he was not planning this type of legislation. As subsequent events have shown, the Minister has an understanding and respect for the truth only matched by that of his own Prime Minister.

The question must be raised: why is this Bill so obnoxious? The Bill has some 26 clauses, of which 22 or 23 relate to a ban on advertising. The remaining clauses deal with disclosure. In its present form, the Bill covers all levels of government: Federal, State and local. It bans for 365 days of the year, year in year out, any advertisements on radio or television which criticise a present government, a past government, a present Opposition, a past Opposition, a member of parliament, and even a political party. It is a blanket ban Bill. The Bill makes it quite clear that this ban would apply to paid and unpaid advertising. This caused enormous concern within the community as a whole because it raised a lot of definitional problems.

When introducing this Bill, the Minister made a number of public statements-and he made them more than once. He said that the Bill would go through because he had the support of the Australian Democrats. This caused concern and suspicion on our side of the chamber that a deal had been made. Subsequent discussions with the Democrats on this issue did not make us feel any easier about the probability of a deal. The Bill was rushed through the House of Representatives. It was gagged; it was guillotined after a couple of hours of debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —They all are.

—Senator McLean says that they all are. Give him half a chance and he would do the same here, too, I suppose. The Bill was then introduced into the Senate. Our concern was such that we moved a motion two days before the Parliament rose to refer the whole Bill to a committee. Understandably, the Government opposed that motion. It did not want the Bill referred to a committee because it did not want the public at large to know what was in it. To its disgrace, it did not want the Bill to be publicly exposed during committee hearings. Only the Democrats can answer why they gave the Government the numbers to prevent the Bill from going to a committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has been totally consistent throughout this whole debate. We have not moved an inch. We have taken the view that under no circumstances could freedom of political expression, freedom of speech, be at all compromised. There was no room for discussion or negotiation. One either believes in freedom of expression or one does not. The Minister talked about there being no such thing as free speech. He is quite right. Even when one picks up the telephone, it is not free speech. But there is something called freedom of speech.

The only option open to us was to engage in our own committee hearings on this matter during the winter recess. This committee was ably chaired by my colleague Senator Olsen. I could not but notice the remarks made by the Minister on the program Ring the Bells last Saturday. He referred to the people who gave evidence to that committee as hired guns. Is he saying that the Salvation Army is a hired gun? Is he saying that all the other people who gave evidence in good faith were hired guns?

At the same time we ran a forum in Brisbane with leading legal people-the deans of law at the University of Queensland and the Queensland University of Technology, the professors of journalism from both universities and Mr Chris Griffith of the watchdog committee. Every one of those people expressed concern at the contents of this outrageous Bill. How did the Minister refer to the people who questioned the legalities of this Bill? His implication, again on the Ring the Bells program, was that those lawyers must have got their degrees from a cornflakes packet. I am sure that would go over well not only with the people I mentioned but also with Professor Zines, Professor Alston and Professor David Flint from the Press Council. I could go on and on. I am sure my colleagues will cover most of those aspects.

I mentioned that we are totally consistent in our absolute opposition to this outrageous and draconian piece of legislation. The Minister attempted to divert the issue to one of disclosure. Our parties, the Liberal and National parties, both took a decision to support full-blooded disclosure. We took the decision to support disclosure, provided there was protection in the legislation against intimidation and provided the legislation was fair and equitable in regard to the treatment of donors to all political parties. This was thrown up as being some sort of effort to get around the legislation because we really did not want it. That has been sunk once and for all. After the committee hearing we decided that we would again refer this Bill to a Senate committee.

Last week, because he could see the thing going out backwards, the Minister did a back-flip. He said, `We will compress the time. We won't have the ban for 365 days of the year; we will just have the ban during election time'. How he thought he would convince the Democrats of that furphy is beyond me. I know they are easily convinced, but not that easily convinced. The Minister was proposing something that some months ago he himself said was totally unworkable. Of course it is unworkable. The government of the day knows when an election will be held. The proposal means that the government can run up to the date the election is announced and then, from that date, there will be a blanket ban-a blackout-but all the other rules and regulations will remain intact. At no stage during an election campaign could anyone run a radio or television advertisement criticising a past or present government or commenting about a political party or a candidate. Nor could there be a paid or an unpaid advertisement.

It is not my intent to keep this chamber longer than I need to, but I will comment briefly on some of the remarks made by Senator Bolkus when speaking about the reference of the Bill to a committee. I notice that his own Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, who is in the other place, wrote to a constituent and said that all the Government was doing was following the recommendation of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters in its report Who pays the piper calls the tune. Whether intentional or not, that was a gross untruth. Senator Bolkus himself referred to Who pays the piper calls the tune. It is worth commenting again on that report. It was a unanimous report, I think, which said quite categorically that, whilst some viewers may support a complete ban on political advertising, such a ban would have a direct effect on freedom of speech by reducing opportunities for discussion during election periods. The Minister's fall-back position was to do exactly what the Committee said he should not do.

In speaking to this reference, Senator Bolkus dredged up some nefarious plan which he said the Liberal Party was engaging in to avoid disclosure. As I mentioned earlier, his looseness with the truth is matched only by that of his discredited Prime Minister. There is no basis for what Senator Bolkus said, no matter what his mate Mr Hogg might be saying or what stories Mr Hogg might be making up. He has exposed the hypocrisy of himself, his Government and the Labor Party through Mr Hogg. He is running furphies about the Liberal Party setting up some sort of trust, which is absolutely untrue, yet across my desk has come a letter of appeal from Gary Gray, Assistant National Secretary, Director of Fundraising, National Secretariat, Australian Labor Party. Across the top it is marked `Personal and Confidential'. Let us hear what this letter has to say. Mr Gray is making a plea for funds, and he says:

Many companies underwrite their commitment to good government and good public policy by making moderate contributions to both sides of Australian politics. We believe this policy is in the interests of democracy and contributes to maintaining an open and stable political system.
But that is only the lead-in. He also says:

For this reason, I ask you and your company to consider making a contribution to either our Administration Fund or our Centenary Building Appeal. Contributions to these funds are not used for electoral purposes.
Then he goes on:

While political contributions which are used for electoral purposes must be disclosed, it is accepted that administrative or non-electoral contributions are currently not disclosable under the Federal Electoral Act.

What hypocrites! What blatant hypocrites! Having said that people could contribute to the administration fund or the building appeal, and that these did not qualify for disclosure, he goes on further:

Our Centenary Building Appeal is directed to securing a major investment property for the Party. Through the income earning potential presented by investing in a new building, we hope to create a long term ``nest egg'' and an opportunity to broaden our financial base.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it will never be disclosable.
—It will never be disclosable. If one contributes to the Labor Party's centenary building appeal, that will not be used for electoral purposes but the income from it will be.
—Read the `PS' bit where it says, `Don't ask for a receipt'.

—That was written in invisible ink. I think this letter is so good that it should be incorporated in Hansard. I obtained permission from Senator Collins, when he was here, to have it incorporated in Hansard, and I seek leave to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
National Secretariat
Australian Labor Party....John Curtin House, 22 Brisbane Ave.,
Barton. A.C.T. 2600
P.O. Box El,
Queen Victoria Terrace. A.C.T. 2600
Facsimile: (06) 273 2031
PERSONAL AND CONFIDENTIAL
Dear Mr
As you are probably aware, 1991 is the centenary year of the Australian Labor Party.
Consequently, 1991 is a year of reflection and rebuilding.

Through the many public events surrounding our celebration, the labour movement has shown the depth of its support and commitment. This was clearly demonstrated in New South Wales, where Labor returned from the wilderness, reducing the Greiner/Murray Coalition to a minority government.

The National Secretariat of the Labor Party is Labor's head office and is central in this process. Through the provision of backup and support of our State Branches and by directing our Federal political agenda, the National Secretariat has an extensive and dynamic role in the day-to-day running of the Labor Party.

This has put the National Secretariat at the centre of our centenary celebrations. Financially, the National Secretariat has supported the writing of Labor's centenary history-a five year project. A 20 minute documentary video of the Party's history has also been produced. Many celebrations have taken place to mark our 100 years. The Centenary National Conference in Hobart last June was a part of this.
All of these activities are important but they do cost money!

Many companies underwrite their commitment to good government and good public policy by making moderate contributions to both sides of Australian politics. We believe this policy is in the interests of democracy and contributes to maintaining an open and stable political system.

For this reason, I ask you and your company to consider making a contribution to either our Administration Fund or our Centenary Building Appeal. Contributions to these funds are not used for electoral purposes.

While political contributions which are used for electoral purposes must be disclosed, it is accepted that administrative or non-electoral contributions are currently not disclosable under the Federal Electoral Act.

From time to time, some companies regard contributions to political parties as being in a different category to contributions made to other community organisations. This need not be the case. Most Australians agree that our democracy is valuable and should be protected and supported. This can only be achieved through contributions from both the public and private purse.
We hope you will take these arguments into consideration when determining your response to this appeal.
Our Administrative Fund is dedicated to finance research, education and public policy development. Good public policy benefits all Australians and is therefore the first objective of the Labor Party.

Our Centenary Building Appeal is directed to securing a major investment property for the Party. Through the income earning potential presented by investing in a new building, we hope to create a long term ``nest egg'' and an opportunity to broaden our financial base.
Please feel free to contact us at any time should you wish to have more details on our building project or to discuss any other matter.
Yours sincerely
Gary Gray
Assistant National Secretary
Director of Fundraising...18 July 1991

TALK.START.PARA: —This phoney Government and this phoney Minister, up on their puritanical high horses, are exposed for what they really are. It is worth reading today's papers to see what disarray this legislation is in. The headlines are: `Govt retreating further from advertising ban'; `Senate urged to block ad ban Bill'; `Government bows to inevitable on ad ban'; `Setback for ads ban bill'; `Labor's political ad Bill in limbo'; `Ad ban sent back for review in setback for Bolkus'; `Ad ban setback for Bolkus'; and `Advert ban looks set to be sunk'. I say, `RIP and thank goodness for that'. It is set to be sunk.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, we have had a Government and a Minister shown to be totally incompetent, not only in the handling of the Bill but in the introduction of it in the first place and in thinking they would get away with it. The arrogance of them in thinking the people of Australia would not in time find out what was in it! I must pay tribute again to my colleague Senator Alston for the work he did and also to the people in Tasmania who let it be known what happened. We hear about promotion and that sort of thing. The Minister did not get where he is on merit; he got there simply because it was his turn as leader of the Socialist Left faction-and it shows. In fact, there is nothing that this Minister has touched which has not backfired. We do not have to look too far behind the ad ban. We all remember the improper intervention in the computer consumables contract.

We support the reference of this matter to a committee. In fact, today I moved a motion to refer it to a committee. I had been told, or I had heard on the radio or somewhere, that the Minister was going to do it but, because of past experience with this man, I did not trust him. As a safeguard, this morning I moved a motion to refer the Bill to a committee, which would have been given priority tomorrow. When this goes through, of course, I can withdraw it. But that is the feeling in the community. I am only reflecting it. We cannot trust this Minister; we cannot trust this Government; and, quite clearly, we cannot trust the Prime Minister. They are all in the same boat together. As I indicated, we will be supporting the reference of this Bill to a committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, make no mistake, Senator Bolkus's backdown last night on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill was not the voice of reason at long last that he would like the public and the media to believe, but the pained cries of a defeated man and a cornered Government-a defeated Minister with the weight of public opinion against legislation that he had introduced into this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: From its conception, this Bill has been one of the most insidious pieces of legislation that this Parliament has been confronted with. It was put forward by a Government that is so on the boardroom and public nose and so in debt that it sought to ban electronic advertising because it could not afford it and was frightened it was going to be at a significant disadvantage in the next election campaign. That is why this legislation is on the table for us to consider. It is also because of Western Australia Inc. The Minister keeps talking about brown paper bags. A lot more can be put in a black briefcase than in a brown paper bag, but the Minister conveniently forgets that. The disclosure component is before this Parliament now because the Government thought it had to act publicly to dissipate the odium that was flowing into the Labor Party ranks as a result of Western Australia Inc.

They are the two specific reasons why this legislation is before the Parliament. It wrapped the ad ban Bill in with the political funding component of the legislation. There is no doubt that that is an arrogant, misplaced attempt to paint the coalition as opposing disclosure if it sought to oppose the ad ban. That was the object of the exercise.

Clearly, the Government did not research the proposal or draft it with even a degree of intelligence. The end result was a Bill which the top legal brains in this country said could not be defined. I refer to the Law Council of Australia and to a number of QC opinions which have been put on the public record over the last few weeks. It was a Bill which the Law Council said publicly had a definition of advertising as wide as one wanted it to be; a Bill which Professor David Flint of the Press Council said was so badly drafted that a plethora of other areas such as news, talkback and satire could be banned.

If we want affirmation of that, we can look at the 20 clauses of amendments put on the table by the Minister today. If there is any example of badly drafted legislation contained in the Bill, the Minister himself confirms it with the amendments tabled and the five-page explanatory memorandum. That clearly indicates that the legislation introduced by the Minister initially was badly drafted. This was a Bill which, in turn, using the corporations power, could be extended to embrace the print media relatively simply. The Government put before this Parliament a Bill which contravened the human rights agreement that Australia had signed. It was in breach of that. It was a Bill which contravened its own equal opportunity legislation. One million functionally illiterate Australians who rely on the electronic media for news and information were going to be denied access to it, and therefore one million Australians were going to be discriminated against by legislation introduced by this Government. The legislation not only contravened our international obligations but also the Government's own equal opportunity legislation before this Parliament. That is how ill-thought through the proposals were.

At every step it forgot what no government should ever forget-that government is there for the community, not itself or a political party. That is the basis behind the draft of the legislation that was introduced earlier this year. We have seen the people speak up and hit back. The Minister says, `Well, it didn't ignite public opinion'. If it did not ignite public opinion, why has the Minister taken two big steps back in the last week? Why has he responded to the public opinion that has been expressed by quite significant organisations and by well-thought of individuals of high standing who have credibility in the Australian community?

It was the coalition which provided the forum two weeks ago for the voice of the public to be heard by holding a public inquiry in both Sydney and Melbourne. The Australian Democrats refused to create that opportunity of community consultative process for people to express a view on this legislation. One might say, `Why was it only the coalition which had a committee of inquiry taking evidence?'. It was because Senator Powell, who calls herself a Democrat, had donned the mantle of a political Judas, betraying everything her Party stood for, by refusing to allow this to go to a Senate committee during the winter recess. Senator Powell sided with the Government and refused to agree to that public inquiry. She even issued a press release on 20 June against a Senate committee inquiry, which stated:

To waste time, energy and money in a futile attempt to turn back the clock by going over all the ground which has already been covered in debate after debate could achieve no sensible or useful purpose.

That was said in a press release from Senator Powell on 20 June. There was a press release from Senator Powell yesterday saying, `We now agree for this to go off to a Senate committee for further report and investigation'. Senator Powell exercised the duplicity and the audacity to write to Senator Parer at the end of last week and say, `We, the Democrats, now want to send it off to a committee. We want you, the Opposition, to support us'. What hypocrisy and audacity on the part of Senator Powell! She and the Democrats had opportunity after opportunity in the Senate, prior to its rising at the end of June, to have this matter referred to a Senate committee of inquiry during the winter recess. Where was Senator Powell then? She was siding with Minister Bolkus. Why was Minister Bolkus hanging in? It was because he knew he had Senator Powell in the hip-pocket and they were going to proceed. It was not until the leadership issue surfaced with Senator Powell that we saw this backtrack to a sensible position, where we ought to have been months ago, suggesting that a Senate tri-party committee ought to be looking at this legislation and reporting back to parliament in due course.

The action that we have had from the Democrats really refutes and rebuts everything they are supposed to stand for. They were not prepared to support the democratic process. The inquiry that we eventually ran certainly served a sensible and useful purpose. Useful, because those who were opposed to this legislation gave evidence at that inquiry-and it came from every quarter-which clearly led to last night's backdown and retreat by the Government. Sensible, because it was the only way that the public could have a forum to express a point of view-a forum denied the community by the Democrats, time and time again. They have got `democrat' in their name but they were not prepared to let the democratic process flow through for the community groups to express a point of view on this legislation.

Senator Powell has let down not just those who voted for her Party but all Australians because they have to deal with a political framework which gives the Democrats the balance of power, currently, in this chamber. It was Henry Adams who said many years ago that a friend in power is a friend lost. I wonder how many Democrats feel that way today about a leader who is no longer a friend to the democratic cause, based on her actions in leading her Party in this chamber over the course of recent months. The Democrats have much to be ashamed of in this debate. They, their leader, or whoever, ignored consistently-as did Senator Bolkus-well researched submissions against the Bill, such as the evidence that was put before that coalition committee of inquiry.

The Human Rights Commissioner did not appear before that inquiry but he did publicly release correspondence he had had with Senator Powell. Having read that, it would seem to indicate to me one of the reasons why Senator Powell did not want that inquiry during the winter recess-because that evidence would have been released at that time. That evidence clearly said that Senator Powell's proposals for a two-minute talking head still breached our international obligations. Therefore, it was not an option and did not absolve the Democrats or the Government for introducing the two-minute talking head in the legislation via amendments.

The Human Rights Commissioner expressed a point of view in relation to truth in advertising. Perhaps it is because Senator Powell did not want to have the amendments she had put forward publicly put down and argued against in such a forceful way by the Human Rights Commissioner on the public record. Perhaps that is the reason why--

TALK.START.PARA: —I never did that.

—It is on the record now, because the Human Rights Commissioner, on a freedom of information application, released it and not because Senator Powell released it. I suggest to Senator Powell that the reason she did not want the inquiry was because she did not want the Human Rights Commissioner's correspondence responding to her range of amendments put on the public record at that time. I might add that it was not her initiative but that of the coalition that sought the FOI application and subsequently got it released publicly. That clearly identifies what we ought to be doing with Senator Powell's amendments to this legislation; they ought to be sent to the same waste paper basket as this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: What did the Australian Medical Association say? It said it had concerns that the ban would lead to violence as extreme groups, denied access to electronic advertising, forced protests to extremes to gain media news time. In response to the Minister's claim that `you can get on the news bulletins', everyone of us in this chamber would well understand that if we have to rely on the news bulletins and newsrooms to get our messages across, then we will have to rely on the subjective judgment of people in those newsrooms who cut the tape, cut the story and put to air what they think is an appropriate version of what we are saying--

TALK.START.PARA: —But if you don't have any money that's what you have to do now.

—My point is that if we have to rely on the subjective assessment of people in the newsrooms, we are going to have their views put to air, not necessarily our views communicated as accurately and incisively as we would put them. We cannot escape that. I have a pretty fair idea how some newsrooms in this country would put it to air.

SPEECH.PARA: What did the Media Council have to say? It said that the wide ranging ramifications of this Bill were just too mind boggling to comprehend-the implications of the legislation as it would affect rural Australia. Sixty-seven per cent of rural Australia depends on the electronic news services for news and information and, in terms of public meetings, relies on advertising on commercial stations to get a message across. That includes the ABC, I might add, in terms of a public meeting. What if someone in a small country town which does not have a local newspaper relied on the local news bulletin to advertise a meeting to debate the wool issue? It could not be put to air because it is a political issue and could not be advertised. How do those people get on in rural Australia, given that set of circumstances?

The Press Council went so far as to say that the legislation was unconstitutional with `horrific, wide ranging ramifications'. The Confederation of Australian Industry was so incensed that it was willing to be part of a High Court challenge. It called it a senseless and grossly cynical exercise--

TALK.START.PARA: —An unbiased lot.

—Senator Kernot, you might say, `An unbiased lot'. It also happened to include the Brotherhood of St Laurence and the Salvation Army. I am pointing out to you, Senator Kernot, that this coalition committee of inquiry covered a broad spectrum of people, including the Australian Conservation Foundation and one Phillip Toyne. I am sure you would agree with me that Phillip Toyne is not necessarily a friend of the coalition, or ever has been.
—Senator Olsen, it would help if you addressed your remarks through the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I want to pick up a point as it relates to the ACF and Minister Bolkus. We all would have noted the release on the 7.30 Report last night which was made at about five to eight so that it missed all the electronic news services. It was made so late that it compacted the print media, so that the story would become smaller because it was such a back-down. The Government tried to manage the news-ran it late at night and compacted the newsrooms. Therefore, the print media was not able to run it as high and as wide and as long as might be.

SPEECH.PARA: On that 7.30 Report the Minister said how he had support from the Australian Conservation Foundation. Let me put to the Minister what the Australian Conservation Foundation had to say about this disclosure. Phillip Toyne said that he `didn't like where the legislation was at and didn't like where it was going', yet there was the audacity of the Minister last night on the 7.30 Report saying, `Phillip Toyne and the ACF support what we are doing. We are going legislatively in the right direction'.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can he look in the mirror?

—He avoids it every morning, I can assure Senator Walters. What we have had is clearly a government that has been caught out with this legislation. There is a whole range of community groups that have opposed consistently the Government's direction-supported by the Democrats-which has let down the democratic process. The only consistent approach to this legislation has been by the coalition. It has been consistent now over a number of months in wanting this legislation referred to a committee of inquiry because it breached fundamental freedoms-freedom of expression.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is one basic and important principle in democracy that we ought to stand and fight for every day in this Parliament, it is freedom of expression and freedom of speech-the basic principle of democracy. That has been the driving principle which the coalition has fought for consistently. At last, public opinion and pressure has brought a back-down from this Minister who has fumbled the legislation consistently over that three or four months. As the shadow Minister, Senator Parer, said, we will support this referral to a committee because at last we have attained the objective we set out to attain some three or four months ago.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Earlier today I promised to make a statement regarding the current industrial dispute with the parliamentary catering staff. I apologise for the length of this statement, but I think I should complete it.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Hill-Do you have copies of it?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I do not have a copy of it because I have just completed it. However, I will make copies of it available as quickly as possible.

INTERJECT.PARA: Introduction

When the Parliament moved from the old Parliament House to this Parliament House in 1988, the then Presiding Officers had already looked at the most efficient and effective way of providing a range of services to the Parliament.

President McClelland and Speaker Jenkins took the decision in the old House to amalgamate the security and attendant groups to achieve staff savings. Speaker Child and I decided to contract out the cleaning service in this Parliament House because of the efficiencies and savings available.

Speaker Child and I considered contracting out the Parliamentary Catering Service at the same time but with all the other changes necessitated by this building and the move to contract cleaning it was decided to maintain an in-house catering service in the new Parliament House.
Why Did We Contract Out?
Mr Speaker and I have a responsibility to ensure that catering services are provided in the most cost efficient and effective way.

The Government has led the way in seeking efficiencies in its catering operations as a number of years ago it divested itself of the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services and recently adopted the recommendations of the Wrigley report which recommended the contracting out of catering services to the Defence Force.
Most major companies in Australia have long ago moved from carrying out in-house catering and handed it over to professional caterers.
The Parliamentary Catering Service has always needed a significant subsidy to cover its total net operating costs.

Mr Speaker and I have been concerned, for some time, about the size of that subsidy and as a consequence had a number of initiatives implemented during the last year which helped reduce the subsidy from around $2.6m in 1989-90 to $2.2m in 1990-91.
In fact I might mention that the subsidy in 1990-91 could have blown out to $3.4m had we not taken measures which included some staff shedding and reductions in levels of service.

Efforts to make the catering service more efficient, including the use of permanent part time workers, have been under discussion with the union for more than three years. It is only in the last 12 months that agreement to a small trial involving 14 staff was achieved.

However, the Speaker and I were advised that because of the combined impact of the Parliament's sitting pattern, long hours of business, the physical size of Parliament House, major design features of the building and its particular service requirements and the costs involved in running a catering service under public sector employment conditions it would be almost impossible to reduce the net operating subsidy below $2m per annum.

Aligned against this situation has been the continuing demands by the Government through the Department of Finance for the cost of the subsidy to be substantially reduced. The Department of Finance's aim was to reduce the subsidy level over the next three years to $1m per year.

In a survey of members and senators conducted on behalf of the Speaker and me by `Q Consulting' during February this year, 76 per cent of respondents had no objection to the investigation of the option of contracting out all or part of the catering service.

It was against this background that the Speaker and I met with the Joint House Committee on 6 June 1991. At that meeting the 10 members of the Committee present, comprising members of the Government and the Opposition parties, after considering a number of options agreed to contract out the Parliamentary Catering Service. I believe that decision was unanimous.
Options for Contracting Out

The Speaker and I discussed with the Joint House Committee the option of bringing in a management fee arrangement where either the staff continued to be employed by the Parliament or the staff were to be employed by a catering contractor.

While substantial savings were available under both options, a difficulty was foreseen in having public servants managed by a contractor. Senators may recall Senate Estimates Committee A comments on the problems this had caused in the Parliamentary Information Systems Office and the Speaker and I did not want such a situation to arise again.

The option of a private contractor employing its own staff but subject to the Speaker and me in consultation with the Joint House Committee setting levels of service and pricing was therefore proceeded with as the preferred option.

I remind honourable senators of the letter circulated by the Speaker and me on 14 June which brought our decision to the attention of all senators and members. I table a copy of that letter. I might point out that between 14 June and now we have received only five representations from members and senators, of which only two have indicated their opposition to contracting out the catering service.
Negotiations Between Staff and Unions
On 6 June, the Speaker and I advised the Liquor Union delegates and the local ACT Liquor Union official of our decision.
On the morning of 7 June the Secretary of the Joint House Department met with all catering staff, advised them of the decision and circulated information on the impact of the decision.
Included in the information circulated was the offer endorsed by Mr Speaker and me to offer all staff a guarantee of 12 months' employment with the successful tenderer.
The Joint House officials again discussed matters with the union on 11 June.

On 21 June the Speaker and I met with all PCS staff to outline the background to the decision and subsequently met on the same day with union officials and the Parliamentary Catering Service Staff Negotiating Committee.
Details of the separation offer were put to the Department of Finance for clearance.
However the Joint House Department was advised that in accordance with government policy it was not possible to offer staff their cashed-up superannuation package and a guarantee of employment.
Union officials and job delegates were given the option of accepting either a package of redundancy benefits and no job guarantee or a lesser package and a guarantee of a job for 12 months.
Both these options were consistent with the Government's retirement incomes policy.

The union, while maintaining its opposition to the decision to contract out, indicated that on behalf of its members it rejected the lesser benefits package and the guarantee of a job. The Joint House Department therefore withdrew the jobs guarantee offer and proceeded to deal with staff on the basis that the union had indicated that its members wished to obtain the maximum cash benefit.
A number of subsequent meetings were held between Joint House officials and union officials and the staff committee.

On 26 July 1991, the union, supported by the ACT Trades and Labour Council, notified a dispute in the Industrial Relations Commission claiming that the Speaker and I, as the nominated employers of parliamentary staff, are subject to the APS redundancy award; that all the negotiation and consultation requirements of the award had not been fulfilled; and that the contract should not be pursued until all the requirements of the award had been fulfilled.
The Industrial Relations Commission heard the union's arguments and adjourned until 5 August for the Joint House Department to respond to the union's case.

The advice provided to Mr Speaker and me was that the APS redundancy award did not apply to us. Nevertheless consultation required by that award had, for all intents and purposes, been met; and the awarding of a contract was not a matter under the jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Commission.

Throughout the whole period, including today, the Joint House Department with the assistance of the majority of its catering staff, has continued to maintain full catering services in Parliament House, except for two major functions.
Process Followed
As a consequence of our decision, a public tender process managed by the Department of Administrative Services was put in place.

Because it could have been reasonably expected that the Joint House Department consultants, Spotless, would submit a tender proposal, the Speaker and I wrote to the Secretary of the Joint House Department on 14 June stipulating that the tender and selection process was to be consistent with the Commonwealth's tendering arrangements. The Secretary was advised that in letting the contract, the Commonwealth's purchasing authority, the Department of Administrative Services, should work with Joint House Department officers throughout the process. Moreover, a DAS officer was to chair the tender selection panel and the Joint House Department was not to have a majority on the panel. The committee comprised the National Manager, Purchasing Services, Department of Administrative Services as chairperson; a senior consultant from Ernst and Young; and an Assistant Secretary, Joint House Department; and the panel secretary was the Manager, ACT Purchasing Services, Department of Administrative Services.

The tender process was advertised Australia-wide in mid-June 1991. On 22 June an industry briefing was held for potential tenderers at Parliament House. Representatives of 11 companies attended the briefing.
Tenders were received from seven major catering firms.
Tenderers short listed by the committee were interviewed in mid-July 1991. The committee unanimously recommended Spotless Catering Services Ltd.
After consulting us, the Secretary of the Joint House Department let a contract with Spotless Catering Services Ltd on 31 July 1991. That contract commenced on 12 August 1991.
Spotless Catering Services Ltd, an Australian company with the required expertise and capacity, was the lowest tender.
The contract price of $2m spread over two years is less than half the subsidy figure which would have been required to maintain an in-house service.
Why Only One Contractor?
The structural set-up of catering services in Parliament House was, and is, designed for a single provider.

If we were to engage more than one provider, significant and costly alterations to the building and services would be required to such areas as storage, cool rooms, beverage reticulation and related infrastructures.
Redundancy Provisions and Outcome

The redundancy provisions provided to staff are based on APS provisions: that is, two weeks' pay for each year of service with some additional benefit for long serving staff-for example, staff employed in excess of five years or 10 years.
In addition, staff have access to pay-outs of their superannuation entitlement multiplied by 2.5 times, recreation leave credits, long service leave credits and one month's pay in lieu of notice.
Some 147 staff are affected by the change. The 10 clerical staff in the PCS have been redeployed in accordance with the PSU award to comparable clerical positions in the JHD.

Of the remaining 137 staff, 118 applied for positions with the contractor. Seventy-two staff have been employed by the contractor including all apprentices, trainees and special placements. The remainder-46-either declined a job, were not offered a job, or did not apply for a job with the contractor. Some of these have retired. Some have secured alternative employment elsewhere. The JHD has assisted all those who requested it in registering with the CES to find jobs elsewhere.
Current Situation
During the imposition of pickets on Parliament House by the FLAIEU and the TLC, catering and other services are being maintained.
Industrial Relations Commission Decision of 13 August 1991
Commissioner Smith of the Industrial Relations Commission handed down his decision on the Parliamentary Catering Service dispute this afternoon.
The decision is that the Presiding Officers are not and were never bound by the APS redundancy award.
This means that the statement of the union and the ACT Trades and Labour Council about the Presiding Officers being in breach of the award and therefore acting illegally is plainly wrong.
The decision of `the umpire' should be respected and the union and the TLC, which appealed to the Industrial Relations Commission, should now stop their industrial action.
Conclusions

The Speaker and I believe the decisions we have taken are in the best interests of the Parliament and the public, and we have taken all reasonable steps to assist those persons affected by our decision.
Following the Industrial Relations Commission finding this afternoon, the ACT Trades and Labour Council should remove its picket.
I table the Commissioner's decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

Mr President, we appreciate your making this statement-perhaps a little later in the day than we had anticipated; but it certainly puts information before the Senate which we did not have earlier in the day and that should be helpful in the ensuing debate.

There are a number of issues involved, but it seems to me that they divide into two major, and in some ways unrelated, subjects. The first concerns the question of your obligation to provide an efficient service in this place-efficient both in the provision of the service and in terms of the cost to the taxpayer. Related to that is the decision which you and Mr Speaker made to change the catering arrangements, whereby they would cease to be in-house and, rather, become provided on a contracting basis. Therefore, the questions involved in that issue concern whether that decision was implemented in a way that was fair and reasonable to the staff that were losing their jobs and other related issues.

I think some of my colleagues may wish to speak on that subject. Obviously I have not had a chance to give any considered attention to your statement, but there seems to be a somewhat unusual situation in that certain offers were made which then seem to have been revoked and put in a different form-but no doubt that subject will be addressed.

A separate subject concerns your responsibility, Mr President, in our view to ensure the proper functioning of the parliamentary process and to ensure that it is not interrupted and that honourable senators are not hindered by industrial action or any other matters in the performance of their duties. I raised a number of questions with you this morning which had arisen out of things that had come to my attention-such as the fact that mail was not being delivered to honourable senators' offices in accordance with the normal delivery timetable; that other services were not being provided, such as newspapers; and, clearly, the disruption of transport arrangements and the like today.

I asked you this morning, Mr President, if you would advise the Senate what action you had taken during this industrial relations dispute to ensure that the parliamentary process, as I have just outlined it, was not disrupted. It does not seem that the statement which you have brought down has addressed that particular question. In fact, you have said in the statement that other services are being maintained. As I interpret it, that means that, in your opinion, all services have been maintained. As I have put to you, Mr President, that does not accord with the information that has been brought to my attention, and perhaps later in this debate you may wish to qualify that particular area.

Of course, the position now is that we still do not know whether disruption as it has occurred today-and as it has occurred on previous days-will in fact be continued tomorrow and on subsequent sitting days.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the transport pool.

—We are not even sure what the transport arrangements are tonight. There has been a suggestion that the cars will park on the other side of the picket line and when the Senate gets up in the middle of the night honourable senators will find their way to the end of the picket and see whether they are able to get transport. I know that this morning those on the other side of the chamber saw this as a laughing matter, but I regard that as an unsatisfactory disruption to the work of honourable senators. I hope that in the course of this debate you might also put to the Senate what the arrangements are in relation to honourable senators' services, such as transport tonight and tomorrow morning.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to continue at length now, but I do want to at least refer to this morning's contribution by my friend Senator Cooney who put the position, in his usual, very sincere way, that the course of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission should be allowed to proceed and that we should not be in here criticising the employees and their picket whilst that was taking place. With respect to Senator Cooney, it is the fact that the picket was taking place whilst the arbitration process was in progress which is the subject of our criticism. Now it seems from what you have put to us tonight, Mr President, that in fact the ACT Trades and Labour Council took the matter to the arbitration process. So on the one hand, the TLC took it to arbitration but, on the other hand, it put in place a picket and maintained that picket at least to some extent to the disruption of the parliamentary process.

TALK.START.PARA: —After they lost their jobs.

—That is not the point. I have great concern and sensitivity for anyone who loses his or her job in today's recession. I can quite understand that that is distressing. There are over 800,000 Australians out of work, largely as a result of the Government's economic policies.
—Really 1.1 million.

—It is 1.1 million according to my colleague's figures. That causes us distress. The argument this morning was that the union should be able to have it both ways. It should be able to maintain a picket and disrupt the parliamentary process, whilst at the same time go to arbitration and have the matter debated and resolved. When Senator Cooney reflects upon that I do not believe he will say that is a fair and proper way in which the process should work.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been told tonight that the decision put down today is that the Presiding Officers' position has been vindicated and that they have acted properly and justly. I presume, therefore, that those who support the arbitration process will now be calling for the picket to be removed; in fact, I hope the picket has been removed because those who stand on the other side and say that the arbitration and conciliation process we have in this country is the perfect answer to resolve industrial disputes will now accept the judge's decision, the arbiter's decision, and the picket would have been removed. I wonder whether the picket has been removed in accordance with the decision brought down in Melbourne today. That will be an interesting test for those who stand by this particular process.
Sitting suspended from 6.31 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I do not want to do much more than summarise what I said before the suspension of the sitting for dinner. Having had an opportunity to look at your statement during the dinner break, I have not varied any of my first reactions. However, I want to make it absolutely clear that we on this side of the chamber do not criticise your decision and that of Mr Speaker to privatise the catering functions. We recognise, from what you have put before us tonight, that it has enabled you-in your words-to provide the same service at a saving to the taxpayer of about $1m a year, and that is something that should be acknowledged. Whether you have done it in the best possible way is beyond my state of knowledge to debate.

SPEECH.PARA: You have put to us that there were difficulties in dividing the functions and we take that into account. I would say that one of our initial concerns has been that, as a result of this privatisation, there does not seem to be any greater competition in the provision of catering services within this building, and it is out of competition that efficiencies come. In other words, replacing a public monopoly with a private monopoly does not necessarily and often achieve the benefits that we see in a privatisation process. Nevertheless, you have put it to us that there would have been considerable costs involved in dividing the functions so as to allow for competition. I simply note that.

Mr President, it seems to us that you and Mr Speaker could reasonably be subject to some criticism of the way in which the first offer was handled. That seems to be confirmed now that I have looked at your statement in that from page 4 of your statement it seems that there was an offer to all staff of a guarantee of 12 months employment, which is what my colleagues understood the position to be and which they were disturbed about this morning when we found that that was not the case.

It seems that the original offer was varied as a result of your learning of government policy that it was not possible to offer staff a cashed-up superannuation package and a guarantee of employment. I can understand that, but it is a pity, if I may say so, that you were not apprised of government policy before the original offer was made. That might have avoided some of the ill feeling that seems to have been engendered in the minds of staff. On the face of this document we can see that there could be some reason for them to be disturbed about the fact that the original offer that was made had to be revoked because it was beyond government policy.

It seems to me, on reflection, that you, Mr President, and Mr Speaker should still be subject to some criticism for the disruption to the provision of services to senators that I mentioned earlier today. We on this side of the chamber think that you should now tell us what you will do to ensure that there is no further disruption of those services. We have not heard that from you yet.
