In particular, we believe that you should tell us what action you have taken to ensure proper transport services tonight.

We particularly criticise Minister Bolkus for today supporting industrial action in circumstances in which, we now know, the union had taken the matter to the Industrial Relations Commission. Neither the Government nor the union can have it both ways. It is wrong that the Minister, who is responsible in the first instance for the provision of these administrative functions, can say that he supports industrial action, supports a picket, whilst at the same time the unionists have taken their matter off for arbitration.

Now that the Industrial Relations Commission has met and apparently dismissed the union's case in this regard, that criticism will be doubly justified if we find tomorrow that Senator Bolkus maintains his position of earlier today. If that is the case, we will want to pursue it. We trust that no Minister will now endorse continuation of industrial action in the light of the decision of the Industrial Relations Commission. No case can be made for a continuation of disruption through pickets, and, Mr President, we endorse what you say in your statement-that this should be the end of the matter.

It has been a sorry affair, Mr President. There are still a number of unanswered questions to which we would appreciate answers, but we look forward to the future. Now the matter has been resolved by the Commission, we trust that the pickets will be withdrawn and that those providing services will do so in accordance with their normal conditions of contract.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. Mr President, I thank you for your comprehensive response to the questions that were raised in the brief debate this morning. I particularly thank you because all of the questions I posed in my notice of motion have been addressed comprehensively. Therefore, in no way would we consider your response inadequate. We thank you for the breadth of the response.

SPEECH.PARA: I support a number of things that Senator Hill said. There is a lack of competition in Parliament House. One instance is especially close to my heart. As one who is reluctant to bank with Westpac, I do not have any alternative but to do so. Sometimes I have been tempted to pose the question as to how that decision was arrived at and whether there is any possibility of expanding competition in the banking area. In reality we are confronted with a series of major monopolies and mini-monopolies. We could cite an even smaller monopoly which we all suffer the consequences of, which shall remain nameless. The phenomenon of monopoly is well established in this place.

Senator Hill hit the nail on the head when he asked, `Where are we at now?'. When we arrived here this morning, we were greeted with a situation which was clearly unsatisfactory. We need an answer, hopefully, to the question of whether the situation will be any more satisfactory when we walk out the doors tonight to go home than it was when we attempted to get in the doors this morning. With regard to some of the members of our own staff, people are beginning to ask: who are and who are not Commonwealth public servants in this place and what entitlements apply even to those who work for the Department of the Senate?

These questions have been put to me as very genuine ones, but there is some degree of confusion which I do not think has been clarified by the ruling of the Industrial Relations Commission today, and in fact the confusion has probably been compounded in some respects. Therefore, we are confronted with a series of genuine questions ranging through those posed most appropriately by Senator Hill as to where we are at now; what we are looking at in the next week or perhaps several weeks; and the circumstances of the people who are employed by the Department of the Senate in terms of entitlements. I would respectfully request that you, Mr President, answer some of those questions for us either tonight or perhaps later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I think Senator Hill has responded very adequately and there is not a great deal I can add to the substance of your statement, but I would like to say a couple of things for the edification of the Senate. You will recall the meeting at which the Joint House Committee discussed this matter when the Presiding Officers made it abundantly clear to members of that Committee that it is nothing more than an advisory committee-something I have resented over the period. You will recall reminding me in writing that it is an advisory committee and that my persistence with a certain point of view was the reason for your writing to me.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, you will know my long-held view about the Government's lack of outlays with respect to the functioning of the Parliament as distinct from the functioning of the Government. You will know that in particular I have raised questions of concern about the level of funding for the Catering Service. You will know that I have raised concerns about the cutbacks in the Catering Service and have asked for an enhancement of that service. You will also know of my robust defence of those employed by the Parliamentary Catering Service and of my complaints over time concerning the conditions under which they have had to work from time to time.

I raise these matters, Mr President, because you will know the genesis of this question of privatisation of the Catering Service. I say with respect that, if the Labor Party members of the Committee persist in their endeavours of misrepresentation and in distancing themselves from the decision of the Presiding Officers, I will happily ask you to make public the deliberations of the Committee when the decision was visited upon that Committee and we were invited to have a point of view. I will do that because then we will see who was sporting the sharp ends of skewers, particularly those members and senators who have affiliations with the union movement, and who embraced a point of view.

To the extent to which that Committee deliberates in private, those matters are not necessarily in the public domain. I would never retreat from decisions or positions I had taken in private simply because they had become uncomfortable matters in the public arena. With respect, I resent the dribbling and the obsequious way in which some on the side of the Government are putting around propaganda amongst the people whom they claim to be colleagues of and true believers with that in some way-as was put to me yesterday-Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Knowles were responsible for what we got. If my standing in this Parliament has been so enhanced that I am able to participate in some sort of decision-making which resolves in something constructive I am flattered, but even my foes in the Liberal Party in Western Australia would not dare to suggest that, with fewer than half the numbers, I can win any vote I want.

TALK.START.PARA: —They probably would but they would be wrong.

—With one notable exception to that. I think it is slightly obscene that we find ourselves in this situation with the Government winking and nodding at the picket line saying, `Don't blame me; I voted for you guys'.

SPEECH.PARA: That reminds me: I was fascinated this afternoon to hear Senator Bolkus ticking off and naming the Liberal and National Party senators and members who allegedly complained about the fact that they had got to the picket line and found they could not get through.

Mr President, I understand that you were rather uncomfortable about being confronted with the picket line when you arrived this morning; Senator Collins certainly was; and so was my dear colleague from Western Australia, Senator Giles, to name but three. Perhaps Senator Bolkus overlooked those names when discharging his duties and responsibilities in his enthusiasm to suggest something sinister about Liberal and National Party senators expressing their view that the functioning of Parliament ought not be inhibited as a result of industrial disputation that is reaching down to the bowels of the canteen.

One does not say lightly, having spent a billion dollars of taxpayers' money, as successive governments have, that there is anything wrong with the construction of this building. We all know that the construction and design of the building in respect to the provision, preparation and service of catering is absolutely appalling. That is reflected, frankly, in the quality of the food and the quality of the service.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was designed by a man.
—I think it was designed by a number of people--
—But men are never good at designing kitchens.

—One only has to look at the floor layout to understand that the floor space available in the dining room in this building is, if I remember, equal to or slightly smaller than that which was available in the old building, where we used to set up tables in the corridors during the Budget session. Obviously, that problem was not, I suggest, clearly acknowledged and confronted in the design of this building.

SPEECH.PARA: As to what virtue we will see from privatisation, as Senator Hill quite rightly points out, there is sometimes no lesser sin in having a monopoly public sector than there is in having a monopoly private sector. The difference is that one sector tends to look after itself and the other tends to look after its profits. We cannot be certain what we will see down the track, but I ventured into the dining room last night to see what was flowing from the new system and after 17 minutes, having ordered nothing more than a simple hamburger and it having not arrived, I rather wondered whether there was something we had to learn about the private enterprise system of which I was not aware. When it did arrive it was both uncooked and cold.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not a Big Mac?

—With respect, had I ordered a Big Mac the waitress could have trotted down in a pair of joggers, bought it and come back, and I could have eaten it well before the one I ordered arrived. I am certain that that was just a teething problem, notwithstanding the fact that I was the only person in the dining room. No doubt those matters will be resolved in future.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, you probably touched on the question of the cost of the running of the Parliament. I am not going to retrace the steps over which I have trod in previous debates about the functioning of this Parliament and the Government's priorities in terms of its own self-survival at the price of the Parliament being able to function, whatever service it might be. I have never been able to understand why the Speaker, without disclosing the machinations of the Committee, has not been prepared to accept the goodwill and the support that we have offered in terms of going to the Minister for Finance and asking for more substantial funding for this Parliament. I have rather felt I have been talking to Mr Willis and not to the Speaker on more than one occasion.

We can only hope that the object will ultimately be achieved. Clearly, Mr President, when you made the decision, you were confronted-given the Government guidelines, or those which were embraced by the Speaker-with either doubling the price of the food or finding a way to cut half the cost. Whether we are going down the right track is yet to be resolved.

I have to say that I was rather surprised to see on the news tonight the TLC spokesperson, a young lady, saying that you, Mr President, had in no way engaged in any negotiations with the TLC-which even I do not believe-and that you had not negotiated any redundancy package, which seems to be patently untrue. Knowing the patience with which you chair this chamber, I am sure that you would have gone to a great deal of pain to at least fulfil the guidelines as you initially proposed them at the committee stage. Senator Hill says that we can but wait and see what the ultimate outcome is.

Let me conclude by saying that I am absolutely appalled that there was an attempt made this morning to deny us normal and reasonable access to Parliament House. Some might suggest that making us walk is reasonable and normal. Some might suggest that it was simply perverse or bloody minded. Whatever, it was an attempt to make it more difficult to get into this building. If the catering service, the TLC or the union movement generally wants to engender goodwill, sympathy or empathy from honourable members and senators, in my view they are going very much the wrong way about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I would like to outline to the Senate that I am a financial member of the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia. I would like to outline the concerns that I have with respect to the current dispute. In discussing this matter with the picketers this morning, they indicated to me that there was no problem in my exercising my functions as a parliamentarian. However, I was requested to observe the normal procedures in a dispute like this in ensuring that I do not eat. I can assure honourable senators that at the present time I am starving.

SPEECH.PARA: For the edification of those opposite, I would like now to outline a number of problems that I believe this issue highlights. The first problem is this: is it fair and reasonable that a catering company-and the catering company is Spotless-which was in here in an advisory capacity for some time, I understand, tendered against other companies? Did it tender on an equitable basis against other companies? I would argue that it had far greater access to information as to how the catering service operated in this Parliament. Is it fair and reasonable that Spotless should have been allowed that access over other companies? I pose that point, first of all.

The second point I would like to make is this: the wages and conditions of employees as employed by PCS-the award coverage that applied-lapsed when a contractor was brought in. Some of the employees have been re-employed by the contractor. In fact, the new wages and conditions are substantially less than what employees were enjoying to the date of the termination of their employment. The new wages and conditions-depending on the classification and the rate of pay-are some 25 per cent less than the old wages and conditions. The superannuation benefits they received ranged between 10 and 12 per cent. The new superannuation payments are 3 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just give us the figures.

—I am just pointing this out as a matter of fact, so that those people opposite can understand why people react in the way they do when they are confronted with this situation. I would suggest to those opposite that no-one in this building, when confronted with that situation-including honourable senators opposite-would appreciate, when their employment is changed, suffering a severe reduction in wages and conditions, including superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: Further to that issue is the issue of continued employment. There is no doubt that, in terms of continued employment, there is a substantial change in the employees' status-moving from a government as an employer to a private contractor. What honourable senators should relate to is that contracts continually change. They may change every three, four or five years. New contracts are let.

Certainly, every time a new contract is let, the current employees have no government guarantee of a continuation of their employment. The catering employees are reduced to the level of politicians. Every three or four years, they are required to put their jobs on the line. They are not politicians and I pose the question: is that a reasonable situation in which to place catering employees?

TALK.START.PARA: —So do your staff.

—They knew what their conditions of employment were when they commenced their employment with me. The terms and conditions of employment of the catering employees have been changed quite substantially while they have been employed.

SPEECH.PARA: Another concern relates to the alleged victimisation of an employee who was a union activist. Spotless made some statements to her that she would not gain employment because of her union activity. If those opposite bothered to read the decision-or lack of it-by the Industrial Relations Commission, they would see that it is a technical judgment about whether the Australian Public Service redeployment and redundancy award applied to parliamentary catering staff. That was the issue before the Commission-not the merits of the continued employment of the employees, not the merits of any redundancy pay, and not the merits or otherwise of their continued wages and conditions.
If those opposite read the decision, they would see that the issue that was resolved related to whether the employees were covered by the redeployment and redundancy award.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who took the application?

—The TLC took the application. The employees believed that they were covered by the award. If those opposite bothered to read the decision, they would see that technically the employees were not covered by the award, because--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. May I seek clarification on this matter? Senator Sherry is lecturing us that we should read the determination. I ask you, Mr President: whose interpretation of the determination is correct-yours or Senator Sherry's?
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Sherry can make whatever comments he likes on this issue.

—In terms of the application of the award, the Commission found on a technical basis that the award did not apply. When original service of the award was made, it was made on Government Ministers and was apparently not made on the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate. That is a technical decision. If those opposite believe that will resolve a dispute about people's wages and conditions which have been reduced, about their continued employment and about their continued superannuation, then I doubt that they are right. One only has to talk to some of the workers who have been affected by this situation to understand the way they feel.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the savings to be brought about by the introduction of private contractors, I simply make this point in conclusion. Personally, in principle I am not necessarily opposed to contracting provided that in the changeover to a contracting system, the wages, conditions and superannuation and the rights of employment of employees are retained. In some situations, because of economies of scale and the technical knowledge of contract caterers, there is no doubt that there are advantages in having contract catering.

If those opposite believe that they will achieve efficiencies and save millions of dollars by quite substantially reducing the wages and conditions of the employees in the Parliamentary Catering Service-which is what happened-and by putting up the price of meals for politicians, then I condemn that utterly. That is the wrong way to go about it. For those reasons, I place my concerns and a number of concerns that fellow senators on this side of the chamber share in this issue on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks on this occasion will be brief because my colleagues have covered much of the issue. There are a couple of things that I would like to say about your statement, Mr President, which we are in fact debating. Your statement was just a catalogue of the negotiations for the appointment of the new contractor. It really did not enhance the knowledge that we have about the matter of the present dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning I asked you, Mr President, as did other senators, what future action you and the Speaker would take. You said that you could not respond this morning-that we had to wait for this wondrous statement. What precisely do the Presiding Officers intend to do to bring to an end the unlawful picketing of streets by people who are not authorised to stop traffic, who are making a selective judgment about which vehicles are permitted to go past to their destinations and which vehicles are not? By what right are those people doing that, and what action are you taking? What action is contemplated with regard to the action of Comcar drivers who are, presumably, members of the union? I was told this morning that they were instructed by their union as to how to behave. Their union is calling the shots.

I expect people such as Senator Sherry to stand up and speak as he did. He is the epitome of the ALP, which is the political wing of the trade union movement. Senator Sherry spoke not as a senator, not as an elected representative of the people who are opposed to compulsory unionism, but as a former paid employee of a union. He proudly told us that he was still part and parcel of it. He used his entitlement as a senator to speak, but he spoke wearing his other hat as a trade unionist. So I would have expected him to speak as he did.

Your own colleagues on the other side of the chamber, Mr President, who did not bother to talk with you about this previously and are taking the opportunity to do so only now, want to weep crocodile tears for 40 or so people who are left out in the cold. But they do not have an apology or a beg-your-pardon for the 800,000 Australians who are out of work, who have lost their jobs-not only their jobs but also their entire life savings-over a period of 20 years or more because of the policies which those opposite have put in place. Where are the crocodile tears being wept for those Australian people? We heard a very self-serving speech by Senator Sherry. No doubt we will hear from one or two other members of the left wing of the ALP and, in particular, those who remain card carrying trade unionists who are committed to compulsory trade unionism.

There was no problem getting staffers into the building this morning, I understand; there was only a problem for people arriving in Comcars. Mr President, what specific action are you and the Speaker taking to provide vehicles for people to leave this building tonight-that is, vehicles which are not Comcar vehicles, because they are part of the trade union cabal? What are you organising, Mr President, for tomorrow to ensure that people will be here? What are you doing to ensure that we will get the mail that our constituents send to us?

Finally, what are you doing to lay to rest the hypocrisy that we have been hearing about in this place today where a very small group of people are holding to ransom the business of the Senate? No doubt if they continue next week the business of the House of Representatives will be affected and, unless there are special privileges for those entering the executive wing, I presume the business of government will also be interrupted.

Mr President, you are the Presiding Officer and, with the Speaker, you have a responsibility. I did not want to hear a report which was merely a catalogue of events which led to the appointment of the particular contractor. I want to know what action you are taking to exercise the responsibility which you have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know of a particular industrial dispute that has ever been resolved in this chamber or in the other place. When industrial disputes are resolved, they are invariably resolved between the parties taking part in the dispute. That is an historical record; it is a fact of life that nobody can run away from. Yet why are we debating this matter this evening? We are debating it because a few of us very privileged people were inconvenienced this morning. We had to get out in the cold, open air and walk less than half a kilometre. Who caused us to do that? It was those real, nasty union people involved in the transport industry-a few people who are holding the nation's representatives to ransom, making them walk half a kilometre.

SPEECH.PARA: Two years ago the whole of the country was held to ransom by a few very privileged individuals. Where did those opposite stand when the pilots voluntarily gave up their employment and held the country to ransom? Where are the double standards that Senator Bishop spoke about, when the actions this morning of a few Comcar drivers are compared with those of the very elitist pilots who held the whole nation and its people to ransom two years ago? We did not resolve the pilots dispute in this chamber and we will not resolve in this chamber the dispute over the catering services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are they picketing?

—They are picketing because a number of them have lost their jobs. For working people that is extremely important, because they do not have-like Senator Tambling and some of his colleagues might-other businesses to fall back on. Their jobs are all that they have. Very few of them, because of the amount they are paid, have any savings whatsoever. That is why they are picketing. That is why workers take industrial action. The union people who are picketing feel aggrieved by what is happening at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not going to judge whether the grievance is correct or incorrect. I am not going to be supportive of the President's statement here tonight, or against it, because I do not know enough about the individual dispute. There has been a major breakdown in communications in this matter. We were advised by the President this afternoon when he tabled a letter of 14 June about what changes were going to come into place. There has been very little advice since then. In that way, Mr President, I am not castigating you personally in the matter. I am not judging you on it. I am saying-and this is probably an indictment upon myself as a representative of the people-that I did not seek to learn enough about it.

If there was any implied criticism of you, Mr President-and I have indicated that there was not-it would have to apply equally to the union people involved, because we have not fully heard their side of the story as yet. Since I returned to Canberra I have made an effort to correct that situation. It is the only way we will ever come to grips with this question or with any matters relating to industrial relations, because there will always be at least two sides to the story.

The dispute over the catering services is muddied, because now there are a number of sides to it. We have this morning's action by the Comcar drivers who refused to cross a picket line. We have the actions when police were involved and a couple of people were arrested. That is a very dangerous situation to get into, because, as things roll on and develop, one will lose sight of what the dispute was about in the first place. We can end up with the dispute not being resolved, but with a dozen or more issues that need to be resolved thereafter. It will take the wisdom of Solomon to resolve some of them.

I want to reiterate a point made by Senator Sherry a short while ago, because a great deal was made of it in Senator Hill's comments to the chamber tonight. I listened carefully, both in the chamber and in my room, to what Senator Hill was saying. I do not believe he was seeking to inflame the situation at all. Senator Hill put a lot of emphasis on the decision by the Commission this afternoon. Senator Sherry put it clearly on the record. The union had made an application, which was its right in law, to have the Commission determine whether its employment conditions came under the Public Service Redeployment and Retirement (Redundancy) Award 1987. That is what the application was about.

The Commissioner gave a relatively short judgment, but he made a number of points in it. As I said earlier, I am not saying that I am an expert. In his conclusion in handing down the decision, Commissioner Smith stated:
This decision can not, and should not, be seen as endorsing or rejecting the actions of either party. The merits are not in issue, only the application or otherwise of the award.
He continued, and I will quote only part of it:
The position put by the union is not unreasonable.

Mr President, the officers who advise you will understand a great deal more about the meaning of the Commissioner's words because they have had the opportunity of being present in the Commission arguing the case and of reading the transcript, which I have not had. The Commissioner also stated right at the end of the judgment:
If the Industrial Relations Act 1988 had not materially changed the approach to be adopted in relation to the presiding officers then it may have been desirable to vary the award.
This decision from the Commission today has absolutely nothing to do with whether those people should be employed by the new caterer or by the Commonwealth Parliamentary Catering Service.

I do not know where we go from this point. Collectively we have to put the matter in perspective. Certainly we and a number of other people-not only members of Parliament but the people who serve us in carrying out duties on behalf of the people of Australia-have been inconvenienced. A number of inflammatory statements have probably been made. This always happens in an industrial dispute situation, and they are regretted at a later time. Action is needed, reasonably speedily, to resolve this matter.

We are talking of a number of working class people who have very little to fall back on other than their employment and the skills that go with that. They do need employment. A decision has been made by the Presiding Officers, on the advice of the Joint House Committee, and obviously endorsed by the Government. It may be that some elements of that decision are not accurate. Certainly a whole host of questions emanate from that decision. Some of the questions concern members of the catering organisation which currently has the contract. They were actually consultants in this place for an extensive period. In putting forward a tender bid, they obviously would have information available to them which would not have been available to the other 15, 17 or whatever number of bidders there were for the contract. That certainly caused me a little concern when I got to know about it this evening.

Mr President, you also advised us of the contract price that has finally been agreed upon. I think your words were-and I will not try to go to the page, but you can certainly correct me if I am misquoting you-that the new contract price was something like $2m, half of what the deficit for this current financial year might be.

I have made a disclaimer about your precise words. I have seen some information from the union movement that tells me that the Parliament will subsidise the new caterer to the tune of $1m. That is a statement that has been made. I am not making it; I am repeating an allegation that was made outside. If that is true, a number of questions again need to be asked about the situation that we find ourselves in. We have to put our feet on the ground and try to get an early and speedy resolution to this problem, as a delayed resolution will mean accommodations and compromises, probably on both sides. That may be difficult when people take stances, but it is something that will have to happen.

In conclusion, I urge that whatever can possibly be done to get the aggrieved parties together to resolve this matter at an early date before it escalates indeed be done. I am certain that a number of people could offer advice that might bring about that resolution. I hope that it will happen early. A number of people are hurting because of this, and I am not referring to those of us who have had to walk half a kilometre in the cold.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may surprise you, Mr President, that not all motorists approaching the precincts of Parliament House had previously been warned of the picket line. It has been drawn to my attention that those people on the roads enforcing the picket line at night are not dressed in safety clothing. Are you aware that some of those picketers are so dressed and so position themselves that they are endangering themselves to approaching motorists? I ask you, Mr President, what is the position of the Presiding Officers in relation to an accident involving these people on the pickets operating in the precincts of Parliament House, given that this afternoon the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) gave some sort of endorsement to their actions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McKiernan earlier referred to us as privileged individuals, and in some respects we are, clearly. We are privileged to represent the people of Australia. Each in our respective area has a duty and privilege to do that. I do not myself claim to have the knowledge to discuss the rights and wrongs of the claims of the union. I do, however, as one human being have great sympathy with any human being who has lost a livelihood.

SPEECH.PARA: When I arrived at the picket line this morning members of the union came to the window of my car, told me why they were picketing and gave me a piece of paper telling me about it. They said that I should have sympathy with them because they were exercising their right and duty as members of a union to support those of their members who had lost their jobs. I said to them then that I recognised that they were there, in a sense, out of a recognition of a principle of solidarity with their workmates but that I, too, was sitting there in my car and would not move also for a principle and that principle to me, in that circumstance, takes priority over the principle for which they were standing in the road.

The principle for which I sat firm was that the work of the Parliament and the representatives of the people must not be impeded, and I claimed the right of passage along that thoroughfare as a senator, not as a private individual. In no way do I claim to be privileged in the sense of my own person; I claim it for the people whom I represent. Therefore, it was in every sense a philosophical confrontation, if you like-a very civilised confrontation. There have been allegations this evening that I might have been one of the senators who was accused by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) of threatening a driver with losing his job. I take this opportunity-as I have already taken it earlier with the press-to say that I unequivocally deny that I ever threatened any person throughout the whole of this morning's activities.

I stayed in that car for an hour and a quarter asking for passage through a picket line to fulfil my role as a representative of the people of Australia. I may have been inconvenienced, but that was not the point-it was not me as an individual, as a private citizen. I made no inflammatory statements. No inflammatory statements, in fact, were made to me. But I do have to put on the record that the answer which the Minister gave to me today was incorrect. Although my driver told me that he could not cross the picket line because he was a member of the TWU, and although I was present when the union organiser told him he could not cross the picket line, he had previously, in my presence and over the Comcar radio net, been told by Comcar that in no circumstances-despite the fact that he said a senator had given him a direction, which I claim is lawful, of course-was he to cross the picket line.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard that. I was listening to your conversation.

—There you are, Mr President: my colleagues were listening in on the radio net, as I assume were many more people. The Minister today, in telling the Senate that the TWU had directed the drivers and that Comcar had not intervened in the matter-which I think is roughly a translation of what he told the Senate-was incorrect. He misled the Senate. Mr President, I draw that to your attention as a serious reflection on that Minister and on his credibility. I think it is a dereliction of his duty to the people of Australia to discuss this matter in an honest and open fashion.

SPEECH.PARA: As a senator I take great exception to Senator Bolkus misleading the Senate, as I do to his implication that I and other of my colleagues may have threatened drivers. I certainly deny that on my own behalf. As other honourable senators have already explained, this is a difficult situation. I want my role this morning to be on the record in case it is misunderstood. Whether in my dealings with the driver, the people on the picket line or the police, all conversations over that hour and a quarter this morning were conducted in a civilised and proper manner. Each of us in our corners believed we were supporting a principle.

However, as a senator representing the people of Australia, I still have to claim that the principle of the Senate's work being undertaken without any impediment and the work of a senator-especially in gaining access to the Senate-should not be impeded in any way. That has to be the primary goal and it has to be beyond question. Therefore I urge you, Mr President, and the other Presiding Officer to see that in no way is democracy ever hindered in its work, because although in some respects this may be seen to be a little matter of a few senators being required to walk up a hill, it is a principle which if taken any further--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Senator McKiernan, where do you draw the line with your `Oh'? When does it cease to be an inconvenience? When does it start to become a total impediment to the work of the Parliament? I cannot get mail in from my constituents; I cannot get mail out; and my office has been running out of paper. Is this the way in which the business of the Parliament should be conducted? At what stage will Government senators say that enough is enough? I say that the beginning is enough; the principle is what is important, not the degree of inconvenience.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Cooney, I seek the indulgence of the Senate to make a statement at this stage. I do this although I do not close the debate. I have been asked a number of questions tonight and I want to deal with a couple of them quickly. In response to Senator Watson, I believe the picketers are not in the precincts of Parliament House; they are outside its precincts. This Parliament has operated during various industrial disputes in the past and will continue to operate in the future. As I said in an earlier statement today, while I am a Presiding Officer I will do everything in my power to ensure that the Parliament operates.

INTERJECT.PARA: I have been asked a number of questions tonight about the tender process. I again say to certain honourable senators that I will make available the people who sat on the tendering committee-I was not in Australia at the time-to reassure them that the information they have been given is wrong. Senator Sherry was one of only five senators and members who wrote to the Presiding Officers when the circular went out on 14 June, and everything he said tonight he put in a letter to the Presiding Officers at that stage.

I have been asked a number of questions tonight about whether people are getting their mail. At a meeting with the Black Rod prior to coming here this evening I was assured that honourable senators and members are getting their mail, that mail is getting out and that newspapers are getting in. They may not be on time, but they are getting in. The reason I make a statement at this stage is quite simply that Senator Hill and Senator Bishop both asked me, `Where are we now?'. I can tell honourable senators that the position is still very fluid; I am doing everything I can to avoid disruption. I am unable to give honourable senators any guarantees about transport tonight or in the morning.

I make this statement because a series of meetings is now about to take place in my office to try to ensure that the questions asked by honourable senators are resolved by 10.30 p.m. and also that arrangements are in place to bring honourable senators into parliament tomorrow morning. As I have said, I do not want to close the debate. I have been asked about a number of issues and I want to leave the chamber and address those issues at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I ask you two more questions?

—I am sure that there are a number of other questions to be asked. Senator McLean, Senator Bishop and Senator Hill have asked questions which I have not answered, but-I say again-I made this statement so that I could go and take part in a series of meetings and thus, I hope, avoid some of the disruption and the issues that honourable senators have raised tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the various speakers who have spoken tonight. I thought Senator Newman put her position very well and very unemotionally. Some people on the other side have invited you, Mr President, to do what you are about to do-that is, discuss the issue. As Senator Sherry and Senator McKiernan have said, we are in a difficult position. There is a clash of rights and principles and clearly, as we all know, the Senate chamber is not the most happy forum in which to negotiate the settlement of a dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not heard anybody say tonight that these people who are on strike and who have served us over the years in the dining room and elsewhere are anything but decent people. What honourable senators have said is that these people are taking action which disturbs the running of the Senate. I think that is a fair point to make. But it seems to me that there has been nothing in the discussion so far to say that we should in some way impeach or in any way punish the people out there before there is a proper discussion about the matter and that, as I understand it, is what the President is doing now.

Of course, one of the problems concerns this decision taken today. It is a decision which, in a certain sense, is not a decision at all because the Industrial Relations Commission has said that it does not have the jurisdiction to settle this dispute. It has had to come back to us, as a parliament, and to the officers whom we all respect-the President and the Speaker. As the President has said, he is going off to discuss that issue now.

I think it is a healthy debate, but I do not think that we can come to any conclusions tonight about what ought or ought not to be done. The people on the other side have said that their legitimate purpose is to make sure they can come here to legislate. That right has certainly not been disturbed today. Whatever else has happened, it is quite clear that the function that this chamber performs has not been disturbed and is not being disturbed now. What is at issue is the fact that people on both sides of the Senate are disturbed by people who feel-and I would have thought feel most legitimately-that they have been badly used.
I think the proper procedure has been taken and neither Mr President nor I want to stifle debate. I think the most useful way out is to see what can be negotiated next over a period of time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would seem to me that Senator Sherry has a problem with Mr President, Mr Speaker and the Department of Finance. I can understand and I share his concern because he pointed out-as I did early this morning-that there seems to have been a gross injustice done. On 6 June, 7 June, 11 June and right up until 21 June, negotiations were undertaken with the staff of the Parliamentary Catering Service.

SPEECH.PARA: The staff understood and were given certain promises and the Department of Finance reneged on those promises. I am sure that the Speaker and the President, with all the goodwill in the world, negotiated the deal that they thought would be best for the staff and would cause less friction. It was the Department of Finance and, indeed, the Government's policy that caused the problem.

What happens in a company if a manager makes a promise to staff and then he is let down by the boss, by the owner? I would imagine that the manager would resign if he were not supported by the boss, having negotiated and made certain promises to the staff. It seems to me that a very similar situation has occurred, which is the main problem. As I said, promises were made to the staff with all the goodwill in the world of the President and the Speaker. They have been overridden by the Department of Finance and by the Government's policy. I think that the Government, the Department of Finance and the Minister have a lot to answer for. It is up to the Minister to finalise the situation.

I understand the President's concern. It is his responsibility to oversee the functioning of the Senate. We are sitting a week earlier than the House of Representatives, so the Speaker, at least, is relieved of any responsibility at the moment. What will happen next week if this matter remains unresolved? This should be of great concern to us all. If it is not resolved in the next 24 hours, next week we will have a problem that is so great that members of the staff who are already serving here will find it very difficult to continue to do so. I believe that the Department of Finance should now step in and do the right thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. Most of what I want to say has been said already. I thank the President for his historical recapitulation of what changes have occurred in the Parliamentary Catering Service, but I do not wish to talk about the Catering Service. I utterly reject the comments made by Senator McKiernan that we are privileged people suffering a minor inconvenience. It is a far greater issue than that. It is a very flippant approach and trivialises what I regard as the most important reason; that is, the primacy of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: To me there is a huge difference between the catering services-the provision of food and drink to members of parliament-and the actual operations of the Parliament. We are involved with the provision of power, light and all the services within the building but, over and above everything else, the free and unhindered access of members of parliament to this Parliament. That is what has been threatened today by the Commonwealth car drivers, the TLC and the pickets on the access roads.

I ask: who are the people picketing? I have been in this place for 14 years and I have never seen the three people who picketed the road I came in on. It may be that they have been working in the building for 30 years. All I can say with absolute vehemence is that I have never seen them before. I refer to the President's speech, where he said that only 46 of the former 160 or 170 staff have not been reappointed. Of those 46 staff a number have retired and a number have taken alternative employment. That leaves at most about 30 people who could form these pickets. I wonder whether we have some of the rent-a-mob crowd out on the access roads causing us trouble.

I make no apology for my view that the actions of those people who hindered the access of parliamentarians to this chamber today are in contempt of the Parliament and they should be brought to account for that. There is contempt of the Parliament when Commonwealth drivers refuse to obey a lawful command. That lawful command is to drive through the picket line and deliver a senator, whom they have contracted to deliver, to the Parliament. If the drivers are not prepared to fulfil that contract, why did they pick us up in the first place? If they are not prepared to honour the agreement, why do the job in a half-hearted manner? By conforming to union pressures, the drivers place themselves in a position of supporting a secondary boycott, which is specifically prohibited in legislation.

We heard on the ABC news tonight that the TLC-chamber or council, whatever the body in Canberra is called-has rejected the IRC decision today. It will go ahead and maintain the picket line. I put it to you, Mr Deputy President, representing the President, that this is an absolutely intolerable situation. The fundamental right of a parliamentarian to have access to Parliament House is being compromised by the actions of these people. It is contempt of the Parliament, and the situation must be corrected as soon as possible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the motion put forward earlier today by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), I can state that for many years-in fact, for the entire time of our existence as a political party and for as long as we have been in this chamber-the Australian Democrats have been very conscious of the need to break the hold of the mighty dollar over the democratic process. We must, as I think the Minister said earlier, do something about the reliance of the political process on the corporate dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats have a fine record in this chamber on electoral reform issues. We have consistently tried to make the electoral process more open to all candidates and political parties and more readily understood by the general public. We have tried repeatedly to simplify our complex electoral laws and to inspire greater public confidence in the electoral process. We have been involved in reforms of many kinds based on these goals and principles: public funding; the disclosure of campaign funding; the naming of political parties on ballot papers and a range of other measures, all of which were designed to open up the political process and make it more effective and efficient.

The story of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, about which the Minister has moved a motion to have it sent off to a committee, is one that we are all aware of but one that has been surrounded by some mystery from time to time, and misrepresentation. It began earlier this year with a proposal from the Minister, which later emerged by way of legislation, that two things should happen at once under the same piece of legislation: that paid electronic political advertisements be banned totally, all year, all the time; and that there be full disclosure of political funds, political donations.

From the outset the Democrats opposed the Government's proposition for a complete ban on electronic advertising. We agreed with the Opposition about that. Of course, that immediately put us in a balance of power position when we did not agree with the Opposition that the whole Bill should go to a committee immediately and be taken off the agenda. On the one hand, we agreed with the Opposition and, on the other hand, we were absolutely delighted to find the Australian Labor Party, the Hawke Government, move from its position in 1984 for campaign disclosure only and go all the way to full disclosure of political donations.

In the beginning that became our complete goal. In 1984 the Hawke Government came forward with legislation to disclose campaign funding. It could have gone all the way; it had the numbers in this chamber. But on that occasion, as we see now, it lined up with the Opposition. It conceded to the Opposition, which did not want to see that full disclosure.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: Senator Powell knows very well that the Opposition moved to have the Bill divided. She has not referred to that. She is talking about sending it to a committee. We asked for a division of the Bill. Senator Powell is not telling the truth.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—It is a story that is well known but has often been misrepresented. The question of full disclosure of campaign funding has been a major matter of principle for the Democrats since our inception. We imposed it upon ourselves in our original constitution and we pursued it year after year in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1984 the Hawke Government failed to go all the way and capitulated to the Opposition. I do not know why, because it did not have to. We were pleased with this year's move but it was inexorably linked by the Government to its blanket ban on advertising with which both the Opposition and the Democrats totally disagreed. The Government used its proposed advertising ban like a sword of Damocles. In April of this year, in introducing this legislation and by the public statements of the Minister, the Government used its proposed ban on political advertising like the sword of Damocles over the head of full and open disclosure of political funding. That is a position which the Government maintained until last week.

The Opposition's original proposal to split the Bill and send parts of it off to committees was totally rejected by the Government on the basis that the legislation would not proceed unless it proceeded intact. As the Opposition chooses to ignore in its misrepresentative public campaign, the Government runs the show around here. The Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan) sits there in the full knowledge--

TALK.START.PARA: —With your votes!

—No. The allocation of the Government business of the day is not a question of votes; it is a question of the Manager of Government Business getting up and saying what the Government business will be. It has nothing whatsoever to do with votes. If the Manager of Government Business wanted to stand up and take this Bill off the agenda right now, he could. I do not know what sort of a government those opposite will make after the next election, but we will be here, trying to help them along their way, which I am quite sure they will need.

SPEECH.PARA: If a Minister says, `We will not put this Bill forward unless we can do so in its entirety', and he means it, then that Bill disappears. That is exactly what the Opposition wanted all along. It is a matter of regret to the Democrats that tonight the Opposition is going a long way down that track, having persuaded the Government to go down that track with it. Nevertheless, the Minister says he is committed to bringing it back after due process in committee and we will have to see whether that happens.

In 1984, the Government gave way to the Opposition. I fear that is what it has done again in this case. The goal of the Democrats all along, since this legislation was first put forward in April of this year, has been to ensure the implementation of full disclosure of political donations. Until last week the Government refused to move. Nevertheless, the Democrats stayed in the negotiations because one fact was clear: we did not support the Government's proposed ban, so there would be advertisements. That was clear. We have another policy; not just the policy of disclosure.

I can count like the Minister. If the Democrats and the Opposition opposed his blanket ban, then clearly there would be ads. That makes sense. The Democrats have other policies besides disclosure, and one of those is a policy about truth in advertising. It is a longstanding policy which is written down and which has been acted upon in this chamber most recently by the former Leader of the Democrats, Senator Macklin, as he then was, in May of last year. That policy reads:

Political advertising will be regulated so that the obligations that apply to companies with regard to truth and accuracy in advertising under the Trade Practices Act will also apply to political advertising under the Electoral Act.

At the moment the Electoral Act is a licence to lie, which members of the Opposition quite enjoy and which, frankly, members of the Government quite enjoy. However, the Democrats do not. It is a matter of policy-and I have just quoted point 14 of our electoral reform policy-that truth in advertising is a major project for us.

Former Senator Macklin moved amendments, after negotiating year after year to bring them down to the most simple amendments we could get to, to try to get the Government and the Opposition, or the Government or the Opposition, to agree to. That was what we needed to pursue, given that there would be advertisements. We would not ban advertisements, so we stayed in the negotiations in order to do two things: to save disclosure from being shoved off either by the Government or by the Opposition, and to make sure that since we would have advertisements they would be forced at least to be truthful.

For the public record, let me say that we have never kidded ourselves that we could stop politicians from making promises that they could not fulfil or from being misleading. At the very base, our amendments to the Electoral Act to bring truth into advertising are the simplest matters of fact. That is all we think we can do, but it is something that we believe is worth striving to do as there will be political advertisements in the future.

So we stayed in the negotiations and up came the smokescreen from the Opposition, terrified that it had failed on its first attempt to get rid of the disclosure proposition. What was it going to do if it had to open up its books to the general public? I must say that I was amazed that the ALP was prepared to do that anyway. Up went the smokescreen with all this stuff about the Democrats being on the Government side with its blanket ban about deals but, as Opposition senators very well know, they were negotiations.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did a deal.

—We are quite prepared to negotiate with the Opposition, especially on a little matter which I will raise later with Senator Parer. Our goal was and remains to ensure that disclosure is implemented, and the sooner the better. It is and was to ensure that the advertisements, which will continue, will be regulated in the interests of truth at least, if not in other aspects. As I said, we also share with the Government an enormous concern about the costs of campaigns. We have a policy for the regulation of advertisements and, as I say, there will be advertisements, because we have opposed that blanket ban all along. We have kept disclosure alive until today. We have stayed in the negotiations, which would have been dead if the Opposition had had its way in April or at any stage since.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It has not been an easy road and some of the uneasiness of that road is being articulated by way of interjection now, but it has been successful because disclosure still lives. Our truth in advertising amendments will go to the committee which will be set up. The Minister has moved dramatically twice in less than a week. The Democrats' policy of disclosure is still being pursued and will still be pursued.

SPEECH.PARA: This is where I want to talk about negotiating with Senator Parer. We should be having disclosure now. I thought it would be today, but possibly even tomorrow we would be having full disclosure. It is open to us to do that. The Opposition says that it is strongly in support of disclosure provisions. Senator Parer was vehement in his speech. Therefore, I contend that we in the Senate tonight should not be referring that section of the Bill with regard to disclosure off to this committee. Senator Bolkus referred to his concern that the Liberal Party is establishing a slush fund right now, I think properly referred to as a trust account.

TALK.START.PARA: —He lied!
—I am just saying that he is concerned about it. I say to Senator Bolkus that, if he is concerned, let him join with the Democrats and pass the disclosure provisions now and stop it.

SPEECH.PARA: Either the Opposition has a strong commitment, will join us and will allow us to work towards disclosure now and not at some later date after something crawls back out of a committee; or the Government, genuinely concerned about what the Opposition might be going on with, ought to be doing that if the Opposition does not. I will, therefore, be moving an amendment to the Minister's motion which is available for circulation. I think it may have even been circulated; if not, it is available. That amendment reads:
After ``refers the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991, as proposed to be amended by the Government,'' add ``with the exception of Part 3''.
That is the disclosure provision. We do not need to send it off to a committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are perfect, are they? They cannot be improved?
—I will move that amendment at the end of my discussion. Here is everyone's opportunity to affirm their commitment--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Vanstone!

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. This is everyone's opportunity to come up with something genuine about their so-called commitment to disclosure. I heard Senator Vanstone ask the question: is part 3 of the Bill perfect? No, Senator Vanstone, but when we are dealing here with legislation that is not perfect, it is customary to amend it. The Democrats have amendments; no doubt the Opposition has got amendments. That is something that we can do in this place; it is something that we always do in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very clear that what Opposition senators wanted us to do all along was to take precipitate action which they knew would sink the whole legislation. They should be absolutely joyous tonight that they have gone a fair way down that track, not with the Democrats' connivance, not by a deal with the Democrats, but with the Government. Senator Bolkus himself was obliging the Opposition by sending this off to a committee instead of dealing with it today. The Government's brinkmanship on this all along has made it really clear that that is what would have happened if we had been precipitate, which is exactly what the Opposition wanted us to do. We avoided that. We stayed in the negotiations and we have moved the Government. Now we have got Tweedledum and Tweedledee back again, revisited-the Government obliging the Opposition to send the Bill to a committee.

Part 3 can stand here in the Senate and be dealt with, if my amendment passes. However, if the Opposition and the Government fail to support my amendment-which will not surprise me-there is a second chance. As honourable senators will be aware from notices of motion this morning, tomorrow I will be introducing a private member's Bill-something the Opposition said it would do if advertising went to a committee, but where is it?-which constitutes the disclosure provisions of the Government's legislation, plus the Democrats amendments.
Senator Olsen interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that is perfect, either, Senator Olsen. The Bill that I will introduce tomorrow is not perfect, but it is of course amendable, as are all Bills.
—Why did you not release it a week ago so we could look at it?

—It will not be debated in the Senate tomorrow, Senator Olsen. In case it has escaped Senator Olsen's attention, private member's Bills do not customarily get debated on the day of their introduction. They generally do not get debated for some time. However, if Opposition senators, who have General Business access much more often than the Democrats, really want to get this up, I am very happy for that to happen. The Bill will be there and it will be a reminder that disclosure has been before this chamber, should still be before this chamber, and should have been passed by this chamber, albeit amended from the Government's legislation, if necessary. That is why I am introducing that private member's Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted Senator Parer's vehemence and I expect him now seriously to lead the Opposition in addressing the Democrats Bill, which, as I say, will be here tomorrow. I am afraid that we will be `disappointed', as we have been tonight, at the lack of commitment by the Opposition, an Opposition which of course must be overjoyed in that tonight it has got the Government doing what it wants it to do.

I think it is inevitable-I accept it; I can count, too, as the Minister said-that both parts of this Bill will go off to a committee. I assure the Senate-because the Minister, perhaps, put a question mark over this-that the Democrats will meet the challenge that the Minister talked about, as we have thus far. We will continue to work for the passage of legislation to ensure full, open and contemporaneous disclosure of political donations. Because there will be political advertisements, we will pursue our policy-which we have pursued throughout the years and which we continue to make a major priority-of truth in advertising and any other advertising regulations which are going to that goal of ours to improve the electoral process and to make it more open and accessible.

The Opposition wants the status quo-no change. The Democrats want reform. The Opposition has tried to ditch a most progressive piece of legislation-at least one part of it-for many months now. As I said, the Democrats want reform in the electoral process. We have a fine record, and here I pay tribute to my former colleague Senator Macklin for all the work that he has done over the years in that area. We want to add now to the reforms that we have made in the past. We will not shrink from our goals and our policies, in spite of all the pressure being exerted by the Opposition or the Government, whose own commitment must now be in question. The Democrats' views, our amendments and our determination for reform will all be before that committee. Meanwhile, we stress that this is a black day for the Senate-when we had the opportunity to open up the books of all political parties and organisations involved in political campaigns, and we have failed to do it. Nevertheless, the challenge goes first--

TALK.START.PARA: —In May and June you had that opportunity and you rejected it.

—Senator Olsen, you know very well-through you, Mr Acting Deputy President-that to have acted before now would have seen the legislation go off. When you are in government, you will find out how easy that is to do.
—Order! Senator Powell, I encourage you to direct your remarks through the Chair. You will probably get fewer interjections.
—I did say `through you', Mr Acting Deputy President, and I will continue to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: We will continue our thrust for reform in this area. Therefore, I move:
Paragraph 1: After ``refers the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991, as proposed to be amended by the Government,'' add ``with the exception of Part 3''.
This amendment to Senator Bolkus's motion has the effect of keeping part 3 before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the chamber this evening is the culmination of a series of very sad and confusing sagas, particularly in the area of trying to understand the game played by the Australian Democrats. In looking at the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 which was before the Senate, and which the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) now seeks to place before a committee for further consideration, we need to look very carefully at its two important, discrete parts. The first relates to broadcasting, and the second relates to disclosure.

SPEECH.PARA: Suspicion surrounds the proposal to ban political advertising on television and radio at all times. I say `suspicion' because people are questioning the motives of the Hawke Federal Government and, more importantly, weighing up the costs of muzzling our democratic right to free speech. Basically, the ban will end political advertising on two of the most important channels of communication-television and radio. Advertisements can continue in the press or direct mail, but if a government introduces legislation which is abhorrent to an individual or to groups of individuals, it will be illegal for them to air their views on radio or television advertisements.

From my point of view, it is even worse for the people who are living in rural and remote Australia and who have limited access to newspapers and direct mail. The irony is that, whilst radio and television have brought regional and metropolitan Australia closer together, the Hawke Labor Government is trying to force political communication back to the nineteenth century.

The people that I would identify as being most affected are those living in the Federal electorates of Kalgoorlie in Western Australia; Grey in South Australia; the Northern Territory, with which I am familiar; Kennedy, Maranoa and Leichhardt in Queensland; and Riverina-Darling in New South Wales. Under the ban it is particularly important to note that Aborigines, like other Australians in remote and rural areas, will be denied the right to hear the views of political parties.

Surely this makes an absolute mockery of the policies of the Australian Democrats and the position they are now taking and the policies of the Hawke Labor Government, which has put a separate piece of legislation on today's Notice Paper seeking a special council of reconciliation in the Aboriginal portfolio. We are talking about the participation of Aboriginal Australians in the Australian community.

Understandably, the proposed advertising ban has come under fire from civil liberties groups, the editorials of major Australian newspapers and a range of community organisations. The Northern Territory Police Association, for example, describes itself as a non-political body, yet it has grave concerns about the effect of such a ban on its freedom to speak publicly, particularly in relation to professional matters.

Looking further at the Northern Territory, I note that the amendments made by the Bill to the Broadcasting Act 1942 break with recent convention by not treating the Northern Territory as a State. Consequently, the category of matter which will be prohibited under the broadcast ban during the lead-up to a Northern Territory election will be wider than that prohibited during the lead-up to a State election.

For example, during the lead-up to a State election, the broadcast of political advertisements will be prohibited. During the lead-up to a Territory or Commonwealth election, the Bill will ban the broadcast of any matter other than exempt matter, for or on behalf of the Government or a government authority of the Territory or the Commonwealth. I therefore support the efforts of the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Marshall Perron, to amend the Bill so that the Northern Territory can be treated consistently with the States.

The hidden agenda of this Bill was highlighted by the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, when he said that it was designed to give Labor a slim chance of winning the next election. He told the House of Representatives in May this year that the legislation:

. . . is designed to stop us from running advertisements on radio and television that are critical of the Government and draw attention to the inadequacies of the Government. It is designed to stop any attempt to remind Australians of the hardship, the very genuine hardship, that the Government has inflicted unnecessarily on so many Australians and their families. It is simply designed to save the Government's political skin.

The second part of the legislation under consideration deals with disclosure of donations received by political parties. Of course, disclosure has the support of all parties in the Federal Parliament, so much so that the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in May this year urging him not to jeopardise the spirit of tripartisan cooperation by linking the advertising ban with disclosure provisions. Yet the Federal Government refused to split the Bill and, in so doing, refused us the opportunity to deal with each issue on its merits.

Needless to say, the coalition supports full, fair and equitable disclosure of political donations. Firstly, we want to ensure that no donor to a political party is singled out for punitive action by a government or a third party as a result of making a donation. Secondly, we want to ensure that parties have a common position so that there is no tax advantage from donations made by unions to the ALP. Thirdly, we want to ensure that donations are voluntary. I sincerely trust that these issues will be most prominent in the consideration of the committee to which this Bill will be referred.

The ALP practice of completing election disclosure returns has made a mockery of the very legislation it introduced in the 1980s. The Labor Party has consistently breached the spirit, if not the letter, of the law. I draw the Senate's attention to the various returns lodged with the Australian Electoral Commission, particularly the one that I am most familiar with, the 1987 return of the Northern Territory Federal Labor member, Warren Snowdon.

Different versions of Mr Snowdon's return wound up being on public display in Electoral Commission offices in Darwin and Canberra. Inquiries ascertained that they had been subsequently altered in Canberra by clerks of the Electoral Commission after requests for amendment by Mr Snowdon. I had to challenge Mr Snowdon to clarify his position and to clarify why there were different forms, different returns and different amounts of money shown on those returns of the Labor Party and Mr Snowdon. These were most important.

I also draw the Senate's attention to a question I placed on notice in the Senate on 20 June, before we rose for the winter recess. I directed a question to the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, who is the Minister with responsibility for this Bill. In question No. 990, listed on page 171 of today's Notice Paper, I raised a number of issues relating to disclosed donations on the ALP returns for 1987, which raised a number of possible conflicts of interest with a real estate development company in the Northern Territory and actions of the Department of Administrative Services, the Department which Senator Bolkus now administers. It was a request for information in regard to various meetings between the Minister, other Federal Ministers and Mr Snowdon, and the solicited party donations.

I specifically asked questions about the relationship between Senator Bolkus and the donor of $5,000 to the Northern Territory ALP with regard to the re-election of Mr Snowdon. That was six weeks ago. I have not been given an answer in the interim period, and I will certainly pursue it with Senator Bolkus at the end of Question Time tomorrow when I will ask him, under the 30-day rule, to give me an explanation as to why no answer has been given to that very important question, particularly in light of this debate relating to disclosure. I wonder whether it is not subtly part of the reason the Government may be backing off on this legislation and tending to hide it at this time.

The debate in this place and the position that the Australian Democrats have taken disappoint us. The Democrats are the self-proclaimed guardians of civil liberties. Over recent months I have heard media reports of Senator Bolkus trying to do backroom deals with the Democrats over the political advertising issue. Such reports leave me questioning the sincerity of the Federal Government as well as the sincerity of the Party claiming to `keep the bastards honest'. I refer to an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald of 4 July, during the winter recess, which warns:

The Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Brian Burdekin, has left the Democrats no other option but to reject the Federal Government's legislation designed to ban electronic political advertising. When legislation is as bad as this legislation is, rejection rather than a compromise is the only proper political response. As Mr Burdekin has advised the Democrats, their proposed compromise law would still be in breach of Australia's obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

What are the motives of the Hawke Labor Government? First, the ban is a ruthless attempt to gag criticism from the Federal coalition and interest groups in the run-up to the next election. Secondly, Labor sees it as a cure to the massive financial hangover it suffered at the last election-a hangover, I might add, said to have cost between $7m and $10m. The last word on political advertising must go to the Professor of Law at the Queensland University of Technology, Christopher Gilbert, who has been reported as saying:

It is not surprising that television has been targeted. It is the most influential medium of our age. All modern dictators place control of television stations among their top priorities. The Saddam Husseins of this world know the power of ``the box''. So apparently does Mr Hawke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill is about to claim one head-that of Senator Powell. It may well claim another-that of Senator Bolkus. The civil liberties counsel who came before the Liberal Party committee of inquiry into this legislation during the break, Ron Merkel, QC, described this legislation as the most ill-conceived, ill-researched, erroneous piece of legislation ever to be brought before the Australian Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Powell's colleagues and branch members were clearly outraged that the Leader of their Party could even contemplate doing a deal on this legislation. I have argued on many occasions in this chamber that the Australian Democrats are out of touch with their own supporters. We only have to listen to the President of the Queensland branch of the Australian Democrats who just last week on the radio was attacking Senator Powell for dealing with the Government over this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you have misquoted me there.
—This should act as a warning to Senator McLean on his `invitation to strike Bill'.
—Don't you misquote me.

—Senator McLean was very quick to signal his challenge to Senator Powell, but I suggest to him that he will suffer the same fate as Senator Powell unless he abandons his ill-conceived legislation on labour courts, the so-called `invitation to strike Bill'.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course this Bill should be referred to a committee. But it took the Government three months of twisting and turning before it finally accepted the position of the Liberal-National Party coalition. Three days ago, Senator Bolkus made his final attempt to attract the Democrats. He offered a ban on election advertising only during election campaigns. Now he has been forced to put this Bill to a committee, which in the past was the policy of the Democrats. Their policy was always to put controversial Bills to Senate committees. Suddenly, when this Bill appeared, that policy went out the window. I suggest to Senator Powell that she will be going out the window fairly soon after it, if one can judge from the comments of her own supporters.

The coalition supports political disclosure. There is no question about that. There is great irony in the Labor Party bringing forward this legislation at this time. Senator Bolkus, in his opening remarks on the motion to refer the Bill to a committee, said that he was worried about the political dollar dictating the political agenda. He was worried about what he described as the `potential for stark and direct corruption'.
