He was worried about the potential for what he described as undue influence and its impact on the electoral process.

There is no mention in Senator Bolkus's speech of the possible corrupting effect of the union dollar. This was referred to by Senator Tambling. In the Electoral Act there are some astonishing anomalies, untouched by this Bill which has been brought before the Parliament, in the union dollar and the relationship between unions and the Labor Party. In reference to the corporate dollar, Senator Bolkus must have been persuaded by Labor Party experience and the influence that the corporate dollar may have had on the Labor Party.

It was no coincidence that this Bill was floated in speculation in the press just before the royal commission in Western Australia commenced its hearings. We should remember that; in politics they call it the pre-emptive strike. Senator Bolkus started to talk about disclosure only when threatened with what can only be described as the greatest disclosure scandal in Australian history which directly affected the Labor Party. That is the background to this Bill being brought before this chamber.

The section to ban political advertising is motivated entirely by the Labor Party's proposal to inhibit the Opposition from reminding the public at the next election of the lies of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-make no mistake about that-his lies about the recession; his promises in the last election about higher living standards for Australian workers; and his lie, repeated day after day in the last election campaign, about his commitment to stay on for another three years. Day after day, we can all recall, Mr Hawke made this lie to the Australian public while at the same time he had made a commitment to Mr Keating to stand down. Of course the Labor Party does not want the public to be reminded about those lies or that famous picture of the three corporate donors in the rowboat with the Prime Minister, not to mention the historic photograph of Mr Hawke, Mr Bond, Laurie Connell and the boys from the John Curtin Foundation. Mr Hawke does not want the public to be reminded of those deals.

In attempting to justify his broken promise to Mr Keating, the Prime Minister confessed that, in his view, anything was justified in order to win an election. That is a fair statement of the principles of our Prime Minister. They are not the statements, and do not in any way represent the principles, of the Australian public. That is why the Prime Minister and Senator Bolkus were prepared to attempt to limit freedom of speech in this country.

To illustrate the position of the Labor Party on disclosure, I will quote a famous American State legislator, half of whose constituents were Bible belt Baptists while the other half were keen consumers of moonshine. When asked his position on banning alcohol prohibition, the legislator said that he was in favour of the law but was not in favour of enforcing it. The Labor Party during its term of office has shown that it is in favour of disclosure laws but not in favour of enforcing them.

Let me make some comments about the Labor Party's record on disclosure. The Labor Party has spent much of the last nine years trying to avoid the disclosure laws as set out in its own legislation. ALP gifts and legacies were set up after 1984 to launder gifts to the ALP. We are delighted that Senator McMullan is in the chamber because he will remember the famous letter that he wrote in 1985 to a large list of private companies telling them how to avoid Electoral Act requirements which the Labor Party had enacted. Does Senator McMullan remember that?

In the 1987 campaign, $2m was laundered through ALP legacies and gifts. In January 1988, the Labor Party tripped very badly over its hypocrisy on the matter of its own disclosure laws. All of us in this chamber remember the famous Harris Daishowa case, which ended up with Mick Young resigning from this Parliament, all over the Labor Party's behaviour on disclosure.

Then came the daddy of them all-the famous gold tax luncheon in the run-up to the 1987 election. Both Laurie Connell and Alan Bond said they received guarantees about the gold tax policy of the Labor Party at that particular luncheon at which, I might say, the Labor Party received $1m-not a bad sum. I can tell Senator Faulkner that not a cent of it was declared. The Labor Party is in favour of disclosure laws; the Labor Party is not in favour of enforcing disclosure laws. We can judge that from its own behaviour over a very long period. If the Labor Party is fair dinkum about disclosure, it will be tested at the forthcoming committee hearings.

What are the issues that this committee should turn its mind to to ensure proper disclosure and equity? Let us start with Senator Faulkner's union mates for, after all, as comrade Ferguson has told us, the unions are part and parcel of the Government. Contributions to unions which are passed on to the ALP are tax deductible; donations to the Liberal Party are not tax deductible. This is a matter that this committee will have to investigate. Individuals who are forced to join unions are also then forced to contribute to the Labor Party through compulsory union dues. I ask Senator Faulkner whether this is fair. After all, 40 to 50 per cent of union members vote for the Liberal Party. I think the committee should certainly turn its mind to that particular issue.

What about the role of the Government in providing huge amounts of money by way of government grants to the union movement, and then receiving back from the unions campaign contributions? The ACTU-just to remind Senator Faulkner-has received over $12m from the Government since the ALP came to office. The union movement overall has probably received $30m. Part of John Curtin House was apparently purchased by the ACTU to help fund Labor's debts of over $4m. We do not know the actual details of that transaction-nothing has been disclosed. The people who are talking about disclosure all the time have got an awful lot to disclose, I suggest to those opposite, about the money that was spent to purchase John Curtin House-how that money was raised and what that money was used for. Let us have a little bit of disclosure about that. I hope that this will be a matter of discussion at the hearings of the committee.

My colleagues have outlined in some detail the opposition of many community groups to the Government's attempt to ban freedom of speech. These groups, happily, will have a chance to produce their evidence before this committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you knock Alston off the ballot? Who won the ballot?

—I ask Senator Faulkner whether he can make a contribution that has some merit. Here we have the Labor Party-the party of deals which has, over eight or nine years, attempted to flout its own disclosure laws-now bringing before this Parliament a Bill which it claims seeks to make people honest. I suggest that Senator Faulkner might speak to his own colleagues and encourage them to obey the laws which they have already enacted.

SPEECH.PARA: I strongly support the reference of this Bill to a committee. I strongly support that it be properly inquired into in every aspect. It is my hope that the Australian people will never have to put up with a piece of legislation coming before this Parliament which would have such a dramatic effect on the exercise of their own freedom of speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an embarrassing debate we have had this evening, listening to the Australian Democrats making their contributions and trying to explain that what was not the case when we left the Parliament at the end of the last session is now the case for them. By that I mean that the Democrats were given a clear opportunity at the end of the Autumn session to demand that this Bill be split in two and that the Bill, either in two parts or as a whole, be sent to a committee.

SPEECH.PARA: What did the Australian Democrats do? They rejected that request. The explanation given today by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Powell, is that these two matters are inexorably linked. By that the Leader of the Democrats means that the Government has sucked the Democrats into believing that, unless they went along with these two matters staying together, all the legislation-this trojan horse of a Bill-would be lost. The Australian Democrats were so unprepared to follow their generally principled views about matters going before a committee and legislation dealing with one matter and one matter alone that they were prepared to forsake those views and go along with the Government in the hope that something better would happen.

The Democrats now say that as a consequence of their prevarication on this matter the Bill is being referred to a select committee, which we all know is utter rubbish. In particular the Democrats wanted to raise this evening their view that the coalition has not properly supported their demands for truth in advertising. Senator Powell would have done well to mention the reply she received from the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Burdekin, in respect of her proposals on this matter. The Human Rights Commissioner told Senator Powell that proposals for truth in advertising, as outlined by the Democrats, may well suppress political debate.

Senators on the Government side of the House might not think much of the concept of legislative proposals in some way suppressing political debate, but it is very germane to this matter. In fact the Human Rights Commissioner suggests that would be the consequence of implementing the proposals of the Australian Democrats. These proposals for truth in advertising-and in fact for others in relation to limits on advertising-have been referred to in the United States as having a chilling effect. That is, people-be they broadcasting licensees, people who place advertisements or whoever-become so apprehensive about the risks of contravening the law as enacted that they fall short of what they actually could do and say far less than the law allows them to say; namely, the effect is a substantial reduction in the amount of political information put forward.

One can talk about what the Human Rights Commissioner has said. Quite simply, while I do not disagree with anything I have read in respect of what Mr Burdekin has said thus far, I do not take that alone as the guiding light. One can look at what the Cato Institute, Article 19 and all sorts of foreign organisations have to say for advice on the importance of freedom of expression in the proper operation of a free democracy and one can quote them if one will.

However, I think before even bothering to go to those sorts of advisers one should ask oneself what one believes in and how the system one believes in could operate if the legislation as proposed were enacted. I happen to believe in a democratic system where people-however I may judge them as individuals and however they may judge me-have the opportunity to vote and to say whom they want to govern them. It is the old story of only the wearer can tell whether the shoe pinches. I am not one of those people who says, `Let us go to those we think know best and follow what they say'. It has to be a blend between taking advice from people who are specialists in a particular area and understanding what the electorate wants and giving it the opportunity to express that view.

If one follows that line of thought, one comes to the point that Senator Bolkus and the Democrats have totally missed in this debate. I put before the chamber three quotes that I think make this abundantly clear. The first, which is for the benefit of members opposite rather than for the Democrats, is from Mr Justice Lionel Murphy, who recognised the importance of free political expression at election times in a case that has been described as Ansett Transport Industries Pty Ltd v. the Commonwealth. In that case, he had this to say:

. . . election of Federal Parliament provided for in the Constitution requires freedom of movement, speech and other communication, not only between the States, but in and between every part of the Commonwealth. From these provisions and from the concept of the Commonwealth arises an implication of a constitutional guarantee of such freedoms,-
this is the important part-
freedoms so elementary that it was not necessary to mention them in the Constitution.

What the former Senator Murphy, then Justice Lionel Murphy, was saying was that if democracy is to work there has to be freedom of expression. It is just so obvious that he was saying even the founding fathers thought one need not mention it in framing the Constitution. It is so obvious that a blatant idiot could not miss it. That was what Murphy was saying. I do not know where that leaves Senator Bolkus and others who support this Bill, but that was the point he was making. If we want a democratic election and if we want people to be able to vote on the basis of some sort of informed choice, we have to allow them to be informed; we cannot do that by restricting the information which they receive.

This point has not been lost on the Australian Law Council, which also sees freedom of expression as fundamental to the fair running of elections. Reminding the Government of a comment by the International Commission of Jurists, the Council said:

Freedom of expression through the press and other media of communication is an essential element of free elections and is also necessary to ensure the development of an informed and responsible electorate.

In effect, they are saying the same thing. We can talk until we are blue in the face about the international obligations of section 19 and we can draw comparisons between that and article 1 of the United States constitution-which is loosely referred to as the freedom of expression requirement-but that article and the United States freedom of expression requirement relate to expression in general. They cover all sorts of expression and say that, in general, you and I ought to be able to be free to say what we choose.

But what these quotes are saying is that the right to freedom of political expression is much more fundamental than the right to freedom of expression in general. Murphy recognised that and the Law Council has recognised that. Freedom of political expression is far more important; it is more central to the existence and proper functioning of a democracy than freedom of any other expression. To express that view does not necessarily concede the right to limit other forms of expression, but it does concede that the right to freedom of political expression is absolutely central.

Those who follow politics in the United States will know that the United States Solicitor General, Robert Bork, was very conservative. He was criticised by many liberal jurists for his views. But he put forward the view that:

. . . representative democracy (is) a form of Government that would be meaningless without freedom to discuss government and its policies. Freedom for political speech could and should be inferred even if there were no first amendment.

These are the points that have been missed. Everybody has been running off to the Human Rights Commissioner asking for advice on some variation of article 19-asking would it fit in or would it not-without coming back to this basic question: can the institution of democracy survive if the electors have some limit imposed on the information that is forwarded to them?

For the Democrats to come in here tonight, particularly Senator Powell, simply under the pressure of a leadership challenge, and say that they have never supported a ban-only as a consequence of interjections from this side do they admit that they have never supported a total ban-is somewhat hypocritical. The Democrats have never said outright that they would support no ban whatsoever. They have always left it open to some sort of bargaining. Senator Spindler now admits that they want some sort of bargaining, something to trade here on this matter. We on this side have said that freedom of political expression is not a tradable commodity. It is not something we hold out for some sort of concession here or there to see where we are going to get. This is the point that the Democrats have absolutely missed and simply not understood. It is an important point.

I want to make a couple more points. I will be brief because I know that there are other people who want to speak on this matter. I have just been reminded of those who do. There seems to be some acceptance abroad-perhaps even amongst some of my colleagues-that we should be worried about the cost of advertising for elections. I do not know why we instantly rush to that acceptance. I do not rush to that acceptance at all. I looked at the last report of who spent what at the last election-it may have been the election before it-and concluded that about $16m was spent. It works out at about $1.60 a voter. Some hare-brained scheme has been put forward by one of the Democrats that each party can put in an A4 page and the Australian Electoral Commission can send that out. Can honourable senators imagine what an administrative mess-up that would be. I will lay London to a brick that it cannot be done for less than $1.60 a page.

The cost of political advertising is the price we pay for tuition on the issues. It is true that we put out some stupid advertisements that are not very informative. It is equally true that the Government does that, as do the Democrats. There is something else that is equally true too; that is, the electorate is not stupid and it will judge us. It will judge my Party, the Australian Labor Party and the Democrats by their advertisements. The electors will say amongst themselves, `That is a stupid ad and it doesn't promise anything. They haven't given a clear indication of what they'll do there', and they will make their own assessment.

It is not appropriate for us to say that we can in some way define what should go into political advertisements and what should not. The reason for the motivation of the Democrats is that they think they are somehow a catcher in the rye that will save this poor ignorant electorate from doing what it will. The mistake they make is assuming that the electorate is ignorant; it is not. A free market in political advertisements is fine by me. I have absolute confidence in the electorate to make its choice.

There are many more things I would like to say. I conclude by saying that I think it is a disgraceful exercise for the Democrats to say that in some way they are now coming to a position that they have always held. They are coming to a position that they have been pushed into by their internal squabbles. They had plenty of opportunities at the end of the last session to come to this position and did not. They have been pushed into it now and they are trying to squirm around and say they are somehow at the forefront of this debate when what they should have agreed to in the beginning was this trojan horse of a Bill being split into two. They had that opportunity and rejected it.

Senator McLean can sit and point as much as he likes tonight, spread his arms apart and say, `Do it now, let's do it now', like he is some evangelist. It will not work. The facts of the matter are that the Democrats had this chance before and they neglected it. Their hands have been dirtied and they stay dirtied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is most interesting in the course of this debate, and reading the terms in which the reference is set out, to recall that over the recess many of us who have been totally concerned with this attempt to ban freedom of speech have made speeches. We have said that, if we want to preserve the right to have freedom of speech, then the people on whom we must put the pressure are the Australian Democrats because they hold the balance of power in this matter. We have made our position clear that under no circumstances will we allow a Bill containing a ban on the freedom of speech to pass without vigorous opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Democrats appear to be quite willing to acquiesce in this matter. I can only say that there seems to be some sense coming out of Queensland when the President of the Democrats in Queensland decided that the leadership of the Democrats on this issue was so poor that the Leader needed to be removed. I am informed veritably today that not only have the 100 signatures needed to cause a spill in the Democrats been obtained, but also that 200 signatures have been obtained and they have already been dispatched. So the spill is on. Some sense has been brought to bear on a party which has purported to say that it wants to keep the bastards honest, but the difference is that there was a need to find somebody else to keep those bastards honest.

As a result of all those machinations, as a result of the breakdown in the covert deals that were done between the ALP and the Democrats, I would like to see-and Senator McLean is constantly calling for full disclosure-the full disclosure of any deals that were done to give the Democrats extra staff, or extra this, or extra that. Those deals never see the light of day. The Democrats have many more staff than the rest of us put together. I would like to know the terms and conditions of those extra staff, the dates on which they were given them and how the Democrats voted on the day before they were given them.

Let me go to the actual terms and the recitals in the motion that we are debating tonight. We in the Opposition support the reference of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill to a committee. What I do not and cannot agree with is the inference in the recitals that are set out as part of this motion. I would like to see the three recitals set out in the first item of the proposed motion replaced with the following recitals. The new motion would say: firstly, `noting that the ALP is a poor manager of its own finances and overspent at the last election, resulting in its present level of debt'; secondly, `noting the ALP's unpopularity with the electorate and its leadership crisis means that it will be unable to attract donations to repay the debt and to finance the next campaign'; thirdly, `noting the Government's hypocrisy in its back-down to this compromise, limited ban'-that is, that there can somehow be freedom of speech up to an election being called but not after it is called- `and that the ALP has chosen to spend its money on direct mail, which is to remain untouched'.

I did hear one of the Government speakers earlier in the day talk about the fact that in the United States-or perhaps it was the United Kingdom-there was curtailment of some expenditure. However, the speaker failed to say that the United States has moved to restrict the amount of money that is spent on direct mail because of the ability to manipulate the electorate. If we put that together with the fact that in this country we have compulsory voting, direct mail has a much more potent effect because we know that people must turn out to vote, that we do not have to go out and collect them.

The fourth point in the amended recital would say, `noting the hypocrisy of the Government in arriving at this back-down position'. That is particularly pertinent when we note statements by Senator Gareth Evans when he was dealing with the crisis in our relationship with Malaysia that in Australia we would not interfere with the right of a playwright to have his play, which was insulting to a foreign neighbour, namely Malaysia, broadcast on national television. However, at the same time Senator Evans and the rest of the Government were contemplating banning forever the right of all Australians to express their political views and to have them broadcast on radio and television in their own country. What hypocrisy can that be?

If we replace the recitals in the current motion with those recitals, I think we might get a clearer reason as to why this matter is in fact being referred to a committee. Whilst we are looking at the matters that will be referred, it is quite important to look at the other information that has been circulated by the Government today entitled `Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991: Amendments to be moved on behalf of the Government'.

Earlier today, one of the Opposition speakers pointed out that indeed the original drafting of the Bill was sufficiently deficient that it was required to move further amendments to make it explicit as to who may and who may not have a view aired. It is most interesting to note the definitions section. In the original Bill-that is, the one banning political free speech for ever-an election was defined to include by-elections. It is most significant to note that the amendment proposed by the Government specifically says that an election does not include a by-election. Presumably, we have the situation that in the Government's view the electorate is able to cope with advertisements on radio and television in a by-election period but is quite unable to cope with them during a normal election period. Again, there is total inconsistency in the Government's argument on these issues.

Very simply, it is important to point out the duplicity in portraying the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters entitled Who pays the piper calls the tune as being totally supportive of the Government's point of view, as the Government tries to do in the recitals contained in the motion. It is important to note that in its report the Committee reported at paragraph 9.8:

While some viewers may support a complete ban on political advertising it would have a direct effect on freedom of speech by reducing opportunities for discussion during election periods when voters are determining the candidate or party they wish to support.

Most witnesses disagreed with a complete ban on political advertising, claiming that it would have an adverse effect on freedom of speech and in particular would disadvantage citizens and groups who wished to bring issues before the electorate. The beneficiaries of a complete ban would be the existing major parties.
Mr Burdekin, of whom we have heard quite an amount, in dealing with how this would restrict a right that is enshrined in an international declaration, said:

The important point from a human rights perspective (and this is a well developed concept elsewhere-for example in United States jurisprudence on freedom of expression) is the danger of accepting government or government agencies as the arbiters of truth and falsity.

Yet in this country under this proposed legislation it would be the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal-headed by a former Labor Party apparatchik who, no matter how well he performs his task, will be seen to be a former Labor Party apparatchik-which would determine, because of the way the legislation is drafted, whether a television or radio station continued to keep its licence. In other words, shareholders' investments, and wages and jobs, are placed in jeopardy.

We have had a whole debate tonight about the jobs of some people who have been working in a dining room under various work practices. What about the jobs that would be placed in jeopardy if a television or radio licence were cancelled because a broadcaster put to air something which a former apparatchik of the Labor Party finally decided was a political advertisement? What an outrageous situation! Mr Burdekin went on to say:
An equally important corollary-
that is, of the statement that there is a danger in accepting government or government agencies as the arbiters of truth or falsity-
is the importance of permitting the free expression of competing ideas-between which people may choose.

In this day of the electronic media honourable senators can speak to each other across this chamber. But we know that when the proceedings are being broadcast, as they are today, we will reach a very large audience, and we will reach it without having to get to it by interpretation of the people who normally sit in the press gallery and put their slant on how they think anybody has performed. In other words, we are able to speak directly to the people who elect us. Yet the whole purpose of this Bill is to stop that right to communicate and speak directly to the people who will have the right to choose between competing ideas.

We are looking at an important watershed issue. The Labor Party lost the attempt to ban freedom of speech absolutely because sensible members of the Democrats put pressure on their organisation to sack their Leader because she was seen to be in cahoots with the Labor Party; they demanded that there be a fresh leader who would at least uphold some of their principles. At the very root of this Bill is the question of what is right and what is wrong.

On the question of disclosure, it becomes a very emotional event. We on this side of the House have said that we are in support of fair and equitable disclosure. That means it falls evenly on all parties; that there should be no favours for the trade union movement which allow it to act as a warehousing operation; that there be no little loophole through which the Government can clip its extra dollars, if it ever manages to attract them again. The point at issue is simply that there are some people who argue that it is part of their freedom of expression to make a donation to a political party of their choice. They find that being told their amount must be disclosed is akin to being told that they must disclose any donation they make to a charity or to a religion. Indeed, it might be said to be akin to saying, `How much do you put on the plate in the church?'.

Nonetheless, there has been a commitment given on this side of the House to support full, fair and equitable disclosure which is not biased and not slanted. That is why it is important that the entire Bill in its present form be sent to the committee for discussion and examination. The bottom line is that one cannot legislate for integrity. No amount of legislation will prevent the grubby revelations that we are seeing with the golden-shoe brigade appearing daily before the WA Inc. royal commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean Hawke's mates.

—Indeed they are Hawke's mates. The point about WA Inc.-and I saw the figures added up last night-is that the corruption of the Western Australian Labor Government has cost the Western Australian taxpayers $700m.
—Don't we know it! We can't even afford to turn on a light globe.

—Quite right. As we say, we should refer this matter to a committee. We do it in full recognition of the fact that this has been a grubby trick which has been attempted to be perpetrated upon the Australian people, but the Australian people are having the sense to fight back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find myself in support of what I believe to be the very important piece of legislation before the Senate. I am disappointed that we cannot proceed to deal with it at this time and I am disappointed that it is going to a committee. I hope that at the end of this committee's deliberations we will see some genuine reform in this area, which is most important for our nation. What has happened in the last few weeks is that divisions within the Australian Democrats have somewhat derailed the processes of this legislation, but that does not alter the fact that it is a package of proposals of fundamental importance to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: These proposals and this legislation will remove the influence of money from the Australian political system. They will get rid of the sleaze factor in Australian politics. We have heard of some selective areas where there have been problems, such as WA Inc., and it is fair enough that the Opposition refer to them. I could go through a whole range of other recent examples in Australian politics. We could talk about the Fitzgerald inquiry in Queensland; we could talk about the investigation by ICAC in New South Wales into north coast development; we could talk about a royal commission currently occurring in Tasmania; and so it goes on. All those cases prove that there is a need for us to act in this situation.

The real problem that we have is that political parties face enormous costs in Australian election campaigns-all political parties: the Opposition parties, the Labor Party and any other political party that one cares to mention. Many political parties have cut corners because of those costs. There appears to be only one way to deal with this situation, that is, the package of proposals that the Government has brought forward. On the one hand, there is a necessity for us to limit the costs of election campaigns and, on the other hand, there is a need for donations and contributions to political parties to be fully disclosed. If we see that package of proposals in place, then I believe we will go a long way towards dealing with this sleaze factor that has infested Australian politics in recent times.

Both full disclosure of political donations and the banning of electronic political advertising have been on Labor's agenda for several years. I am personally sorry that it has taken both so long to appear on our legislative agenda. It is a tragedy, because of the problems we have with the leadership of the Australian Democrats, that there is some serious risk that the original proposals that the Government has put forward will be significantly changed.

I would like to have seen these matters addressed very early in the term of this Government, in 1983 or 1984, when Labor was clearly and unambiguously on the ascendant. But the facts of the matter are that the justification for introducing this package of reforms remains as strong now-if not stronger-as it ever was, and all the trends in Australian political campaigning and in the political process in this country over the last several years really have reinforced the need for the sorts of reforms that the Government is proposing.

We have heard from the Opposition about free speech. We have heard about it ad nauseam. I must say that it is easy for the Opposition-or anyone else-to score points with cynical and cheap scare tactics about free speech. I do not think many people examine this issue very closely, they naturally react on a superficial level.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I received a cable recently from the National Organisation for Women Inc. in Washington. I would like to share with the Senate the contents of this cable and the matters that it is addressing, not because it is a matter of joy but because it is a matter of the greatest gravity.

SPEECH.PARA: The fax message advises me of a commemoration day-which happens to be today, 13 August-for the senseless violence towards and murder of 19 girls in a boarding school in Kenya. Nineteen girls were murdered and 71 girls were raped by their male schoolmates on 14 July 1991. There has been a call for a worldwide vigil in cooperation with a feminist group, Maendeleo ya Wanawake. That is a Kenya-wide women's organisation based in Nairobi. It has organised this vigil to take place simultaneously in Kenya, Canada, Australia, Brazil, Switzerland, Ireland and India.
On the first page of this message there is a quote from the deputy principal of St Kizito boarding school. The deputy principal is quoted as saying:
The boys never meant any harm against the girls. They just wanted to rape.

I raise this matter in the Senate today, partly as some contribution to the vigil around the world held for this appalling event, partly because I have been a receiver of the hospitality of the Maendeleo ya Wanawake group in Nairobi and, indeed, met some of the representatives of that women's organisation when they visited this country-and partly because I think an issue of this gravity is something that the world ought to think about. Certainly its parliaments ought to think about it.

I believe it is reasonable and, indeed, responsible for Australia to raise this because violence against women is not something raised for the first time by me tonight. It is something that many people have spoken about in this chamber over some time. I do not believe I could draw much distinction between any honourable senators in this place in their united view of opposition to violence against women in this society. What I can mention-and I am proud to do so because it deserves mention-is the efforts made by this Government to legitimise the rights of women and to make violence against women illegitimate and illegal.

The facts of that attack in the boarding school in Kenya on 14 July 1991 are not known in any great detail to me, nor are they conveyed in great detail in this article. I am just told that something like 300 boys from the boarding school in Meru, Kenya, brutally attacked their female classmates. The cable read as follows:

In a planned attack, the boys cut the telephone and electricity lines and then invaded the dormitory in which all the girls had hidden in fear of an attack. 19 girls lost their lives in the chaos which followed, most likely due to trampling as the terrified girls ran for safety.

Subsequent reports suggest that most of the girls died of asphyxiation because they were crushed one on top of the other and were unable to breathe. It says in the cable that they may have been trampled but, in fact, the subsequent medical reports suggested that they were asphyxiated. The cable continues:

Over 100 were injured, and 71 raped. It was, said one survivor, ``like being attacked by a pack of hungry hyenas, except the boys outside our dormitory that night were more terrifying''. Police arrived hours late, ignoring calls for investigation. Kenyan president Arap Moi, moved to tears by the site of destruction, described what happened as the ``most ugly'' incident he had ever encountered in his life.

It is certainly true that many Kenyans were absolutely shocked by this appalling event, as were women across the world. When I read that story, I suffered the dropping away feeling in my stomach that yet again we have this kind of violence against women. This case related to girls in a boarding school, a place where one might have thought that we could expect our girls to feel safe. Maendeleo ya Wanawake wrote:
The boys received legitimization for their brutal acts from the subjugation of women present in Kenyan society as a whole.

That is its comment, not mine. There are a number of comments which elaborate on that point contained in the associated material which came with this message. There are articles which I think are from the New York Times which address this evil. One such article, written by Jane Perlez, is headed `The Evil Men Do To Women in Kenya'. It appears to have been published on 8 April 1991, which is a bit exciting if the event did not happen until July. So I would have to say that I am not quite sure of the facts of that matter. The article refers to the St Kizito incident, so I must have some information here wrong. The article states:
An educational comic strip in the booklet makes the point that beating is not a symbol of love, as many women believe.

The article mentions a number of the points that have been raised in this place, I think more by the women than the men. That is not necessarily a criticism of men; it is just a comment that these are the sorts of attitudes that women in this place have brought to the attention of the Senate and, hopefully, a wider audience than just the Senate. The article continues:
``I think the boys are as much a victim as the girls,'' said Wanjika Mwoita, who until two years ago was a lecturer in French at Nairobi University.

``I'm sure these boys did not set out to kill,'' she said. ``They've been socialised to believe that if you want to get sex, you get it and that if you want anything there is no way a woman is going to stand in the way. They have been taught to believe that girls are to be used.''

I have only put some of the quotes from the material given to me into the record tonight, because they actually say the same thing again and again. I mention again the massive depression that I felt on hearing this news. I sometimes get the feeling that we are not learning and that the crimes against women and girls do not cease.

It was not very long ago that we heard of the massacre of female students I think in a Canadian university. There was a call at that time for another worldwide vigil because of the violence committed against women. I think that it is a matter of the gravest depression. I do think that we have to hope that we can change this situation, but I sometimes feel that it may take so long that we will not notice any signs of change.

In case I was forgetting this situation and feeling a little optimistic, I opened the Melbourne Age on 9 August this year and read the headline, `Rape trauma less for prostitute says judge'. The article stated:
A County Court judge who yesterday jailed a man for rape said the gravity of the crime was lessened because the victim was a prostitute.
This is a newspaper report, not a full account of the court report. I do not think that we should leap to a judgment against the judge, which this headline might lead us to do.

If one reads the article more closely, I believe one can say that the judge deserves our sternest concern. According to this report-and perhaps it is not as bad as the headline might have led me to believe-the judge said:
. . . because prostitutes were involved in sex as a business, rape was likely to cause them less psychological harm than other women.

I would have to say to the judge, with respect, that that is to miss the point, let alone to miss the facts or the psychological concerns of prostitution. Whether a person is a prostitute ought to have no place at all in assessing whether a person is guilty of rape, or in making some assessment of the punishment for the crime of rape. One wonders what the judge might conclude about rape in marriage. My mind boggles to think of the logic he would go to. If he argues about prostitution being somehow a capacity to reduce the crime of rape against a prostitute, what would that learned judge have to say about rape in marriage?

I must say that I am very concerned to find that such attitudes still occur in learned and senior people in the society in which I live. I mentioned the story of the Kenyan women's violation as part of the worldwide acknowledgment on this day of mourning the senseless violence against them, and also to say that I do not take too much comfort sometimes from the attitudes we see reflected in our own society. I would hope that the attitudes which allow violence against women as the norm will go.

I think it is critical that the Senate-not only its women but also its men-make it absolutely clear that violence against women in this society, or in any other society, is absolutely not on. It is totally unacceptable to in any way perpetuate the myth that women are somehow deserving of being beaten, that they are somehow lesser mortals, that they are creatures of burden or creatures of subjugation. That is not what our society says about women. The Senate needs to reflect that both in its legislation and in its attitudes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assure Senator Crowley that there are many males both in this place and outside it who would say `Hear, hear' to what she has just said and who share her deep depression and very, very serious concern. Women are not alone in that depression and those concerns regarding the matters Senator Crowley so appropriately raised in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators are well aware of the fact that I have used the adjournment debate, I believe very effectively, to pursue the issue of banking malpractice and corrupt practices. Honourable senators will probably be a little alarmed to learn that I intend to continue to use it quite extensively in this session. I believe that what has been achieved in the last 2 1/2 years is a sensitising of the Australian community to bank practice, and I think it is appropriate that we move beyond the stage of sensitising the community to actually demanding and ensuring that action occur in relation to the issues.

I am sure that honourable senators will recall the drama in this place, let alone outside it, surrounding the Westpac letters. I have continued to pursue the question of the Westpac letters, which I believe provided prima facie evidence of fraud, conspiracy and a number of other very serious crimes. I have in fact written to the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) and the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) asking how and when they will pursue the revelations of criminal activity which were exposed so effectively by the Westpac letters.

I have received a reply from the Treasurer who, in a very brief letter, drew my attention to the fact that the matter really belongs with the Attorney-General. I have received a reply from the Attorney-General telling me that the matter belongs with the Australian Federal Police and that he has referred certain aspects of it to the Federal Police. With respect to that body, I draw attention to the fact that there was a dual allegation advanced by me in this place, and that is that the Federal Police in the past have been less than diligent in their pursuit of these allegations of fraud in relation to bank issues. So I must admit to having some lack of confidence that there will be speed or effectiveness. Sadly, I say that of the Federal Police in relation to these matters.

The Attorney-General also draws my attention to the fact that he has referred the matter to the Director of Public Prosecutions and that the responsibility lies with State law enforcement agencies. Frankly, I am not particularly encouraged by the response from the Attorney-General to think that there will be any major thrust concerning the important aspects in relation to bank fraud which are clearly revealed in the Westpac letters.

The Attorney-General also refers me to the fact that the review of the Australian financial system by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, the Martin committee, is still proceeding with its hearings. I think the Martin committee now rightly deserves the reputation of being a soft committee. I do not expect that it will seriously address the tough issues inherent in banking. I believe it will deliver to the Parliament a soft report with recommendations which step around the real matters. I would be delighted to be proven wrong on that matter.

I have gone around the country in the last few months since my appearance before the Martin committee on 15 March. Putting it bluntly, by my assessment, the way in which my evidence was treated by that inquiry, which encouraged people to appear before it, was a mere farce. It was simply through making honest statements that I had a bad experience before that Committee and I do not have a lot of confidence in it. I have been asked to appear before it again, and I will be doing so in the hope that, slowly but surely, the Committee is toughening its position in relation to the sorts of issues that I have placed before it.

In recent days we have again seen the question of foreign currency loans raised before the Martin committee. There has been a suggestion that there are confidential Commonwealth Bank documents-internal memos-which clearly and openly admit negligence on the part of the Commonwealth Bank in relation to foreign currency loans. One can assess where this negligence sits only by what we have been able to gather from the press, because Mr Martin and his committee have not insisted that the Commonwealth Bank table those documents. In fact, that is a source of some grave concern to those of us who have followed this issue from the beginning, and who have followed the inquiry since its beginning. We are amazed that after three months Mr Martin is not insisting that the Committee has access to those documents.

As recently as yesterday we have received a declaration by the Commonwealth Bank that it is continuing to pursue precisely the practices in relation to foreign currency loans that it had referred to as being flawed and inadequate in the confidential documents which the Martin committee has failed to demand. I believe that this inadequacy on the part of the Martin committee clearly indicates its lack of moral courage and its lack of fortitude and will in relation to this tough issue. I have no confidence that it is going to put any significant pressure upon any bank in relation to any significant act of corruption or malpractice. Indeed, as I have just said, we see the Commonwealth Bank flouting the Committee by saying that it will proceed to continue with precisely the same practices in relation to foreign currency loans.

I sent copies of the Westpac letters to all senators, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Attorney-General, the Treasurer and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), who returned them unopened. Hopefully, some people on the distribution list have read the Westpac letters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have.

—I know that Senator Schacht has because he immediately picked up a very serious dimension of them-namely, the cost of justice and the virtual impossibility of significant numbers of people seriously taking banks to court. There will be marginal success, and thankfully there already has been, but I sadly believe that it will be infrequent and only marginal success. Even Sir Ninian Stephen and the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of a State have said that in these respects ordinary Australians get shoddy treatment from the judicial system.

SPEECH.PARA: Any of us who have read the Westpac letters would be absolutely dismayed to read the latest issue of the Westpac magazine, Issues. I have the last issue-Volume 13, July-August 1991-in front of me. There is an article entitled `Into Professional Forex Market'. In the preface to the article, Westpac says:
Up to now, only banks or large corporations had direct access to the professional foreign exchange market. Now a new Westpac service opens this market to a wide range of players.
Westpac is now starting to promote yet again the very process which was exposed as fraudulent and corrupt in the Westpac letters. Under a subtitle the article states:
Each day we revalue each position against a current market exchange rate and unrealised profit or loss will arise.

Anybody who has read the Westpac letters will acknowledge this as being absolute mockery. It is a diabolical affront to the Australian populace that Westpac would now advocate itself as a professional manager on the foreign exchange market when clearly the Westpac letters provide evidence that it took points, switched deals, acted fraudulently, abandoned the fiduciary obligations of its clients, evaded tax and stepped outside its statutory obligations to a gutless Reserve Bank that has not challenged Westpac concerning the serious allegations contained in the Westpac letters.

Sadly, we must continue this task of pursuing bank malpractice and corrupt practices. I do not believe that the Treasurer of this country will do so on our behalf or that the Attorney-General has the will to do so on our behalf. I reluctantly have doubts as to whether the Federal Police has the will or the resources to do so on our behalf. Already the banks are simply defying the activities of the Martin Committee, flying in the face of the parliamentary inquiry into banking practice in this country. Most Australians, like me, would be alarmed that we now discover that the Australian Bankers Association, the peak organisation of bankers in this country, has employed at its own expense a consultant who has sat cheek by jowl as adviser to the banking inquiry for the last few months. So we have rampant malpractice. I use those words quite advisedly because I believe that is the magnitude of the problem. I believe that we have shown only the tip of the iceberg to date in this respect, and I believe it is my duty and the duty of others to continue to pursue the matter.

I was delighted today to hear Senator Panizza ask a question which went directly to the issues that I have been raising in this place. I know why-because he has been approached by people in Western Australia and elsewhere who are hurting. I have been there for the last few days, and I was in Queensland before that and in every other State. I was in the United States of America two weeks prior to that pursuing--

TALK.START.PARA: —Seven people came to one of your meetings.

—Seven people? I can tell Senator Kemp that 230 people came to a meeting at 9.00 a.m. on a Monday in Merredin in a freezing hall. I believe 230 was the number-certainly it was in excess of 200. Senator Kemp does not know the facts.
—You got seven people in Maryborough and eight press.
—I accept the fact that in some places the numbers were down, but Senator Kemp also has got to accept the fact that in some places the numbers were up. He was not there and I was.

SPEECH.PARA: I am delighted that one of his colleagues, Senator Panizza, has finally become sensitised to an issue that his constituents are highly incensed about and highly sensitised to. Senator Kemp is an insensitive individual. I do not expect him ever to be sensitised about this issue. I understand that-I am prepared to admit defeat-but I am delighted that other honourable senators on his side of politics are sensitised. Senator Schacht is my first major victory on the Government side, Senator Panizza is my first major victory on the Opposition side. I am prepared to write off Senator Kemp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly tonight on a matter that was raised today in the Senate in Question Time on the print media inquiry announced by the Government recently. In the Senate today Senator Kernot for the Australian Democrats asked a question of the Minister in the Senate representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley. In that question she asked for details of the structure of the committee to conduct the inquiry and, in particular, she raised the point of why was it not a joint committee of the Parliament with representatives of both Houses but only a House of Representatives committee. In that question she made the following remarks:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it not true that Senators Childs and Schacht are keen to serve on this committee and obviously do not consider themselves to be too overloaded?

On 7 August, in a couple of comments made to the press by Senator Powell, the Leader of the Democrats, similar implications were made that the Government was putting this inquiry to a House of Representatives committee only because it did not want either myself or Senator Childs-who have shown considerable interest in the concentration of print media ownership in Australia-to be involved in any joint committee because of our interest, and because we may be more willing than members of the House of Representatives to ask tough questions.

I want to put the record straight. I was consulted by Mr Beazley in early August and took part in a discussion with him about the structure of this media inquiry. I was involved in that discussion because I was the first person to raise within the Labor Party, some three and a quarter years ago, the need to have an inquiry into the structure of print media ownership in Australia. The need for such an inquiry has been a long campaign on behalf of myself and several others-including Senator Childs-within the parliamentary Labor Party and the community.

I know there were many doubting Thomases in the media and elsewhere who never believed that such an inquiry would take place. I am certainly very pleased that, as a result of a resolution carried at the National Conference of the Labor Party in Hobart in late June this year, the Government agreed to conduct such an inquiry with broad and comprehensive terms of reference.

Initially, two or three years ago, I asked for the inquiry to be conducted by the Trade Practices Commission, but I am more than happy to support a parliamentary committee. Such a committee would have broader powers to seek evidence than the Trade Practices Commission and obviously that would be very useful to the committee.

As far as whether it should be a joint parliamentary committee or a House of Representatives committee, I do not deny that if all other things were equal I would be more than interested in serving on a parliamentary inquiry into print media ownership in Australia because of my long interest in this issue. However, all things are not equal and looking at the workload of the Senate, through both its standing committees and the ever-increasing proliferation of select committees-many of them being established, I must say, at the request and instigation of the Australian Democrats as a way for the Government to proceed to get some agreement on its legislative program-it is becoming very difficult for back bench members of the Government in this place to be able to serve effectively on all the committees that have now been established. I must say that, even had the joint committee been established, I do not know whether I would have been able to serve on it, in view of my workload as the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and as a member of other standing committees of the Senate.

Therefore I was agreeable to, and accepted, the suggestion made by the Minister that the most efficient way for this inquiry to be conducted quickly was through a committee of the House of Representatives. I accepted that view without being subject to any pressure at all and I am more than confident that there are plenty of people in the House of Representatives-on both sides of the Parliament-who will be able to make a very worthwhile contribution to that inquiry.

I note also that the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, has indicated that there will be a deadline at the end of the year for that committee to report so that, if the Government needs to consider amendments to legislation as a result of any findings of this House of Representatives select committee, it can do so in the autumn session of parliament next year. I believe that the timetable for legislation is a much more important consideration than any personal view that one may have about satisfying one's own interests by serving on a joint committee. I believe that the suggestions made by Senator Kernot, Senator Powell and other Australian Democrats in recent days-that the establishment of a House of Representatives committee is a whitewash-are utterly false. This committee will not be a whitewash; the Government members of the House of Representatives who I know are interested in serving on the committee have certainly indicated that they will not be on that committee to make a whitewash of the issue. They are very keen for the committee to bring down some worthwhile recommendations after a properly conducted public inquiry.

In conclusion, I believe that in the past twelve months there has been a considerable increase in public concern about the media situation-particularly about the print media-in Australia. Much of that concern has been driven by the collapse of the Fairfax empire and speculation about potential bidders for the Fairfax Press. Obviously the terms of reference as outlined by the Minister for Transport and Communications do not specifically mention the Fairfax Press, but they are certainly broad enough to cover issues relating to its future. I am sure members of the Australian community will take the opportunity to put their views forward to the committee. I also hope that the Australian Journalists Association and other groups associated with the media, which have argued for such an inquiry for a long time, take this opportunity to put their views forward and to create a broader community debate.

There has been some suggestion that people in the industry itself, because of its already very high concentration of ownership, will be a bit nervous about putting forward their views about the way in which it is presently operating. I hope that is not true. The Committee will be hearing evidence with all of the privileges of the Parliament and of course it can conduct hearings in camera where necessary. I hope that all of those people who in the past have complained privately about the operation of the media in Australia do use this opportunity-which I think is a unique one-which the Government has now given to the Australian community.

I look forward to the inquiry being conducted. I look forward to its recommendations and, if the recommendations of the Committee of inquiry mean legislative change, I hope that the Government can act accordingly in the Autumn session.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has any bank at any time failed to comply with the capital adequacy standards based on the standards of the Bank for International Settlements promulgated by the Reserve Bank in 1988; if so: (a) which banks failed to comply; and (b) at which dates did those banks fail to comply.

(2) Do the answers to (1) (a) and (b) include failure to comply with those standards by State Banks and the trustee banks in Tasmania; if not, what would be the answers to (1) (a) and (b) if the State Banks and the trustee banks in Tasmania were included.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Reserve Bank has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The capital adequacy guidelines were introduced in 1988, but the Reserve Bank permitted transitional arrangements for some Australian banks until June 1990. These allowed banks not initially meeting the minimum ratio of 8 per cent time to do so. (The international Basle guidelines allow for transition periods up to end 1992). Since June 1990, all banks have been required to operate in excess of the minimum ratio. When a bank has come close to breaching this ratio, prompt corrective action has been taken by the bank concerned, under the guidance of the Reserve Bank.
These arrangements apply to State banks and to the trustee bank in Tasmania.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which regulatory provisions imposed on authorised banks under the Banking Act 1959 apply to State Banks.
(2) What are the responsibilities of (a) the Reserve Bank; and (b) the Treasurer for the regulation of State Banks.
(3) What measures, if any, would be taken in respect of State Banks which failed to comply with these regulatory provisions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Reserve Bank has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 6 (1) of the Banking Act provides that nothing in Parts II or V, or in Sections 61 to 69 (inclusive), of the Act applies with respect to State banking. Parts III, IV and VI of the Act, which are not covered by these exclusions, are concerned with:
Part III Foreign Exchange, Foreign Investment, etc, including the authority to deal in foreign exchange;
Part IV Gold: this Part is suspended;
Part VI Collection and publication of information about banks;

(2) and (3) Part II (Provisions Relating to the Carrying on of Banking Business) of the Banking Act does not apply to State banks, ie a State bank does not require authorisation under that Part of the Banking Act to conduct banking business, is not subject to the provisions relating to prudential supervision by the Reserve Bank and is not covered by the Protection of Depositor provisions. However, by agreement between the Reserve Bank and the Board of each State Bank, State banks have undertaken voluntarily to comply with Reserve Bank prudential requirements. This means that, for practical purposes, in its supervision the Reserve Bank makes no distinction between State banks and banks authorised under the Banking Act. The Treasurer is aware of these voluntary arrangements but is not part of them.

If the Reserve Bank were to become aware of a problem in a State bank, it would press the management and Board of the bank to clarify the nature and extent of the difficulty and to put in place strategies to maintain the viability of the bank, protect its depositors and deal with the problem. If the problem was judged severe enough to threaten the viability of the bank concerned, the Reserve Bank would normally seek to discuss its views with the State Government concerned. At this point, the powers and responsibilities of the Reserve Bank are quite different in respect of a State Bank than they would be in respect of a Banking Act bank in similar circumstances. If a bank authorised under the Banking Act was in serious difficulty, the Reserve Bank could assume control of the bank and manage it in the interests of depositors.
