ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Credit Reporting Industry: Code of Conduct

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 8 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress has been made in the Code of Conduct for the credit reporting industry which is being developed by the Privacy Commissioner in accordance with Australia's privacy legislation and what is the likely implementation date.

(2) What steps have been taken, or will be taken, to ensure the accuracy of information currently held on millions of Australian individuals in the files of the Credit Reference Association of Australia (CRAA).
(3) Will the subjects of those CRAA files be given access to, or sent copies of, their files to check the accuracy of the information contained in them; if not, why not.
(4) Is there any legal or administrative impediment to the subjects of the CRAA files being sent copies of those files before the implementation of the Code of Conduct; if so, what is it.
(5) How could the Code of Conduct operate effectively unless the existing files were checked and rendered accurate before the Code comes into operation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Very substantial progress has been made in the development of the Code of Conduct. A draft Code has been prepared and was issued by the Privacy Commissioner on 5 June 1991 for public comment. Subsection 18A(2) of the Privacy Act 1988, as amended by the Privacy Amendment Act 1990, requires consultation with government, commercial, consumer and other relevant organisations before issuing the Code. To this end, a draft Code of Conduct was drawn up at a series of meetings convened by the Privacy Commissioner, Mr Kevin O'Connor, during March, April and May 1991. The Code of Conduct will come into effect upon the commencement of the Privacy Amendment Act. It is expected that this will occur on 24 September 1991 which is the latest possible date for commencement.

The bodies and organisations which were involved in the preparation of the draft Code are: Australian Finance Conference; Retail Traders Association of Australia; Australian Federation of Credit Unions; Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies; Australian Bankers' Association; Credit Reference Association of Australia Limited; New South Wales Privacy Committee; the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations and Australian Financial Counselling and Credit Reform Association. Officers from the Attorney-General's Department's Justice Division and the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs have attended the consultation meetings in advisory and observer roles.

(2) The Privacy Act, as amended, provides, at section 18J, that credit reporting agencies, such as the Credit Reference Association of Australia, must take reasonable steps by way of appropriate corrections, deletions and additions to ensure that personal information contained in a credit information file or a credit report to ensure that the file or report is accurate, up-to-date, complete and not misleading. The Code will seek to ensure that credit reporting agencies will make publicly known procedures by which access by individuals to their own credit information files may be obtained and amendments to the information contained therein may be made.

(3) and (4) Individual subjects of credit reporting agencies' files will at all times have a right of access to their own files. There is no legal impediment to subjects being sent copies of their files. However, there is also no power under any law to require this to be done.

(5) I am advised by the CRAA that its existing practices ensure, as far as practicable, the accuracy of its data. Individuals have always been made aware of their right of access to their own files and to advise of errors. I am also advised that credit providers using CRAA under a voluntary code, which predates the Privacy Amendment Act 1990, automatically advise individuals who have been refused credit because of a CRAA file of their right to contact CRAA and request a copy of that file. I understand that approximately 35,000 individuals a year already make use of this means of access to their files.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the fact that s.7 of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 gives approval to the ratification by Australia of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination, but that there is no similar provision in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986, does the Government intend to submit a Bill to Parliament with the aim of removing the limitations contained in both s.6(1) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Act 1986, which presently `does not bind the Crown in right of a State' and s.6(2) of the same Act; if so when.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Section 7 of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 gives approval to ratification of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. Australia ratified that Convention on 30 September 1975. No such provision was necessary in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986; Australia had already ratified, on 13 August 1980, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. This convention is a schedule to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act.
On ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Australia lodged a declaration in the following terms:

`Australia has a federal constitutional system in which legislative, executive and judicial powers are shared or distributed between the Commonwealth and the constituent States. The implementation of the treaty throughout Australia will be effected by the Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities having regard to their constitutional powers and arrangements concerning their exercise.'

A federal statement such as this does not affect Australia's obligations as a party to the Covenant. It draws attention to the division of powers under the federal system and indicates that the States also have a role in the implementation of the Covenant's obligations.

Australia reports to the United Nations at regular intervals on the measures taken to give effect to the rights recognised in the Covenant. These reports include information on the measures taken by State governments to implement obligations under the Covenant.
The Government has no plans to amend subsection 6(1) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act to bind the Crown in right of the States.

The second issue raised by the honourable senator concerns subsection 6(2) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act. The subsection provides that the Crown in right of the Commonwealth, or a State, or Norfolk Island, shall not be liable to be prosecuted for an offence under the Act. A similar provision also appears in the Racial Discrimination Act. This is in accordance with the policy and practice applying to Commonwealth legislation, that criminal liability is not imposed on the Crown.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the decision to provide separate funding in the Federal Budget for palliative care taken and acted upon.
(2) On what grounds did the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services decide to specifically fund palliative care.
(3) On what basis is the level of funding for palliative care determined.
(4) How are annual increases in palliative care funding determined.
(5) Once the total federal allocation is determined, on what basis are funds for palliative care then distributed to the states.
(6) Has the department calculated any projections on future demand for palliative care; if so, what are they.

(7) What discussions, if any, have taken place between the Federal and State Governments in relation to: (a) level of funding; and (b) distribution of allocated funds to individual hospices, hospitals and other services providing palliative care.
(8) What services are available from Commonwealth departments for: (a) at-home care for the dying; and (b) nursing home care for the dying.
(9) What Commonwealth regulations apply to at- home care for the dying.
(10) What medical benefits apply to medical and nursing treatment of the dying: (a) at home; (b) in hospices; (c) in hospitals; and (d) in nursing homes.
(11) To what extent are pain killing drugs available to the dying: (a) at home; (b) in hospices; (c) in hospitals; and (d) in nursing homes.
(12) How is the cost of such drugs covered or subsidised.
(13) Who is allowed to administer these drugs and are there any limits on amounts which can be administered or occasions on which they can be administered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)-(7) The current hospital funding arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories were introduced in 1988. The Commonwealth Hospital Funding Grants contain a specific component (the Medicare Incentives Package--MIP) which provides grants to the States/Territories for the development of innovative projects aimed at improving the efficiency of public hospitals by substituting in-hospital effort with day surgery, post acute early discharge and palliative care programs.

The MIP component is indexed annually in the same manner as the general Hospital Funding Grant--that is, for prices and award wages increases in line with national economic indicators and real growth based on age and sex-weighted annual population growth.

Each year MIP funding is nominally allocated to the States/Territories on a per capita basis weighted to take account of age/sex distribution profiles. Each State/Territory Health Minister distributes the funds to individual projects in accordance with local priorities but within agreed broad priority areas. Accordingly the proportion of MIP funding devoted to palliative care varies from year to year and between States/Territories.

The MIP arrangements were discussed with State/Territory health authorities and agreed by Health Ministers and the Premiers before their introduction. Ongoing discussions occur at officer level on individual projects and priorities.
The role of the Commonwealth in regard to palliative care relates to funding rather than service delivery.

(8) The Home and Community Care (HACC) Program makes available home help and home nursing services to people who are dying. HACC growth funds, however, are not available for specific palliative care services.

In addition, the Medicare Incentive Packages also assist those requiring palliative care. The packages are expected to cover the needs of palliative care patients, including nursing, physiotherapy, and home help services. Co-ordination is provided by the funded hospital/nursing service.
Funding is also included under MIP for contributions towards the cost of treatment and care in hospital of people with AIDS.

The AIDS Matched Funding Program is cost- shared between the Commonwealth and States and Territories. Responsibility for the provision of services rests with the States/Territories. Under the agreed Program activities, funding may be directed to the provision of home care services and hospice services for people with HIV as well as self help and care programs developed by community-based organisations for people with HIV, including their carers. In addition, the Program provides training to actual or prospective professional and volunteer care-givers of people with HIV/AIDS.

(10) The Medicare Benefits Schedule lists the various medical services for which Medicare benefits are attracted when rendered by medical practitioners to patients: (a) at home; (b) in hospices; (c) in hospitals; and (d) in nursing homes. Medicare benefits are not payable in respect of services rendered by nurses.

Medicare benefits are payable at the rate of 85 per cent of the Schedule fee listed in the Medicare Benefits Schedule for out-of-hospital services with a maximum payment by the patient of S26 for each service where the Schedule fee is charged (where the doctor direct-bills the Government for services rendered there is no charge to the patient). However, where a doctor charges above the Schedule fee, the patient is responsible for any amount in excess of the Schedule fee in addition to the 15 per cent/$26 `patient gap'.

For out-of-hospital services Medicare has a $240 `safety net' for patients needing continuous medical treatment. Where an individual incurs expenditure on `gaps' (the difference between the Medicare benefit and Schedule fee) equal to $240 in any one financial year, Medicare will meet 100 per cent of the Schedule fee for medical expenses incurred for out-of-hospital services during the remainder of the year.

For services to private patients in hospitals and day hospital facilities, Medicare benefits are paid at 75 per cent of the Schedule fee, with private health insurance funds being required to pay the gap between the benefit and the Schedule fee for insured patients.

Under the Medicare arrangements Australian residents are eligible for free treatment in public hospitals (including out-patient treatment) as public patients, and the Federal Government provides considerable funding to the States/Territories for health purposes to ensure availability of, and access to, such treatment.
(11) Pain killing narcotic analgesic drugs are available to the dying at home, in hospices, in hospitals and in nursing homes at the discretion of the medical practitioner.

(12) The cost of such drugs to the patients in State run institutions is the responsibility of the State Government. The cost of those narcotic analgesics which are Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme (PBS) items is subsidised by the Commonwealth whether at home, in a hospice, a private hospital or a nursing home.

(13) The supply of narcotic analgesics which are PBS items is subject to restrictions recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. The Schedule of Pharmaceutical Benefits stipulates the maximum quantity that may be supplied on one prescription. They may be prescribed in cases where there is present severe disabling pain not responding to non-narcotic analgesics. Authorities for increased maximum quantities and/or repeats will be granted subject to any restrictions stated in the Schedule of Benefits. The administered dose is at the discretion of the medical practitioner. The persons who may administer the medication to the patient is a matter of State law.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 15 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Are officers of the Minister's department regularly supplied with newspapers or magazines; if so (a) which officer classifications are entitled to this facility; (b) what is each officer's entitlement; (c) which newspapers and magazines are supplied; (d) what was the cost of providing this facility in (i) 1986-87, (ii) 1987-88, (iii) 1988-89, (iv) 1989-90; (e) who supplies the newspapers and magazines to the department; (f) if tenders were called for the supply of the newspapers and magazines, how was the successful tender selected; and (g) if tenders were not called for, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Available to Division Heads and Regional Directors who made them available to other officers if they wished. Some financial newspapers, e.g. the Financial Review, were available to other senior staff;
(b) National morning papers and selected magazines and local papers for Regional Directors;

(c) Financial Review, Melbourne Age, Australian, Canberra Times, Sydney Morning Herald, Bulletin, Australian Business, Independent Monthly and the Business Review Weekly were available to Division Heads. Regional Offices received the West Australian, Australian, Sunday Times, Canberra Times and Bulletin (Perth), Advertiser, Financial Review, Australian, Bulletin, PC World, Health Yourself and G.O. (Adelaide), Mercury, Australian, Canberra Times, Bulletin, Computerworld, Computing and Direction in Government (Hobart), Sydney Morning Herald, Financial Review, Australian Personal Computer, Your Computer, PC World, Directions in Government and Bulletin (Sydney), Courier Mail, Financial Review, Weekend Australian and Bulletin (Brisbane), Centralian Advocate, Australian, Tennant Creek and District Times, NT News, Canberra Times and Bulletin (Darwin), Financial Review, Melbourne Age, Canberra Times, Bulletin, Directions in Government, New Accountant, Australian Accountant and PC World (Melbourne).

The Department also purchased, until October 1990, the following daily papers for a newspaper clipping service: Financial Review, Sydney Morning Herald, Melbourne Age, Australian, Canberra Times, Melbourne Sun, Daily Telegraph, Courier Mail, Adelaide Advertiser and the West Australian.

(g) Tenders were not called in the States as the costs were below the tender threshold. In the ACT there is a monopoly situation relating to the purchase of newspapers. The Newsagency Council of NSW and the ACT determine territories within which an accredited newsagent may operate. The Department of Finance falls within the territory covered by the Manuka Newsagency.
(a) Senior Executive Officers, Senior Officers and equivalent grades.
(b) An annual amount up to the value of $500 for the home delivery of newspapers and magazines.

(c) The newspapers and magazines purchased must be work related and selected from the following list: Financial Review, Melbourne Age, Sydney Morning Herald, Australian, Canberra Times, Bulletin, Business Review Weekly, Australian Business, Independent Monthly, professional publications and appropriate computer journals. In addition officers in the Regional Offices are able to select local newspapers.

(a) The Commission supplies newspapers and magazines to Officers of the Commission only where those newspapers or magazines are related directly to the performance of the duties of particular positions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 15 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What grants has the department made, or will it make, to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) subsequent, and in addition to, those grants detailed in my previous Questions on Notice Nos 232-249 concerning grants to the ACTU.
(2) What grants does the department anticipate making in the financial year 1991-92.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No grants have been made to the ACTU subsequent and in addition to those advised in response to Question on Notice No 242. However, in response to a request from an executive of the ACTU, the Minister for Resources agreed to reimburse the three union members on the Consultative Committee on Safety in the Offshore Petroleum Industry (COSOP), 50 per cent of the cost of their return airfares to Perth, for the purpose of attending the 30 April-1 May 1991 meeting of the committee. (2) No further grants are anticipated in financial year 1991-92; however, reimbursement for travel and accommodation expenses will continue throughout the duration of the ESD Strategy process which is due to be completed in October 1991.

(3) Does the Minister agree that an expenditure of approximately $40 per day on duty and tax free alcohol equates to an expenditure of approximately $75 per day on alcohol at normal Australian retail prices and that such allowances are not available to Members of the House of Representatives, Senators, senior Commonwealth officers or diplomats.

(4) Was the ``bar bill'' incurred in the entertainment of either or both of the two members of the Territories Sub-committee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs who participated in the voyage; if so, what portion of the "bar bill" was spent on their entertainment.
(5) What was the average daily amount incurred by voyage leaders and paid for by the Commonwealth on the purchase of alcohol, excluding the voyage referred to in (1), during the 1990- 91 season.
(6) Is there a maximum daily limit applied to such expenditures by voyage leaders; if so what is that limit.
(7) What action has the Minister taken, or will she take, to limit future expenditure of Commonwealth funds in this way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to parts (1) to (7) of the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The voyage accounts for one voyage in the 1990/91 season included an amount of $1,779.87 for alcohol and related items for the voyage and for field and station provisions. Included in this amount was $40.80 for private expenditure which was reimbursed by the Voyage Leader.

The Voyage Leader stated that the expenditure was incurred in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 5, Section 7, Sub-section 5.7.11, of the ANARE Operations Manual (Provisional) 1990. These provisions are as follows:

``Voyage Leaders are authorised to incur reasonable expenses for the purchase of drinks on board ship for recognised social occasions, such as pre-dinner drinks with expeditioners and 'elevenses' with ship's officers. The drinks are to be limited to basic spirits (eg non premium grades of scotch, rum and gin), beer, cask wine and soft drinks.''

The account for $1,779.87 included amounts for station provisions, cargo operations and field groups. While other voyages included some of these items no other voyage included all of these items. However, the average daily amount paid by the Commonwealth on the purchase of alcohol and related items, during the 1990-91 season, but excluding the voyage referred to in question (1) was $6.24 per day.

Two members of the Territories Sub-committee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs were present on occasions when some of the expenses covered by the account for $1,779.87 were incurred. No information is available on the portion, if any, which applied to these members.
I have asked my Department to review its guidelines for expenditure on alcohol and related items on voyages.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: RAAF: Laverton and Point Cook Bases

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the considerable anxiety expressed by the communities of Werribee, Sunshine and Altona regarding arrangements planned for staffing, equipment and facilities at the Royal Australian Airforce bases at Laverton and Point Cook:
(1) What steps is the Government taking to alleviate the negative economic effects to the local community and what financial and other resources will be allocated by the Government to this task.
(2) What process of community consultation has been, or is to be put in place to deal with this issue.
(3) What involvement has there been to date from the Victorian Government in this process and what resources is the State Government allocating to the process.

(4) What involvement has the Commonwealth sought from the City Councils of Werribee, Sunshine and Altona and is the Government satisfied that the role of local government in this matter has been properly recognized.
(5) Can the Minister arrange for a meeting between the relevant Commonwealth and State Ministers and the `Save the RAAF Bases' group to provide for a regular exchange of information on this issue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Earlier this month, I met with the Federal member for Lalor the Hon. Barry Jones and State and local authorities including the Premier of Victoria and representatives of Werribee Council and the Western Region Development Committee. As I announced on 30 May, the RAAF pilot training system will be restructured to involve civilian flight screening and all through PC-9 training at Pearce. Consequently, No. 1 Flying Training School at Point Cook will be disbanded and the CT-4 aircraft retired, probably about the end of 1992.

The airfield at Point Cook will be sold but the base, including Headquarters Training Command, RAAF College, Institute of Aviation Medicine and RAAF Museum will be retained. Other Victorian units may be relocated to Point Cook.

The airfield and the base at Laverton will be sold with existing units being gradually relocated or closed. No. 1 Aircraft Depot will be closed and the Central Photographic Establishment relocated along with the other units. No. 6 RAAF Hospital may be retained as an Australian Defence Force (ADF) medical facility for the Melbourne area.
I have agreed to the establishment of a consultative committee, to be chaired by Mr Jones to advise me on the range of issues associated with the future use and disposal of the airfields.
I expect to respond shortly to all outstanding representations to me with details of the consultative arrangements once these have been finalised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the Department of Defence involved in working on a project referred to as a study of barriers to Australian industry tendering for defence work.
(2) What did this study involve.

(3) Did the study involve sending a questionnaire to defence industries; if so, can a copy of the questionnaire and the covering letter under which the questionnaire was sent to the industry be provided.
(4) Under whose authority was the study conducted.
(5) When did the study begin.
(6) (a) When was the study completed; (b) if it has not been completed, why not; and (c) when will it be completed.
(7) What role, if any, did the Defence Industry Committee have in the development of the study.
(8) If the study has been completed: (a) who has access to the final results; and (b) can a copy of the final study be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Defence was involved in a study called Barriers to Industry Participation in Defence Work.

(2) The study involved a survey of Australian firms to assess the problems they had in obtaining defence work. The survey questionnaires went to over 5,400 Australian firms selected at random by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It covered firms of all sizes and was not biased toward firms with a history of doing defence business.
(3) As I mentioned above, the study involved sending a questionnaire to firms. Copies of the covering letter and the questionnaire will be provided to the honourable senator.
(4) The study was conducted under the auspices of the Defence Industry Committee (DIC).
(5) The survey package was released to Australian industry on 3 April 1989.
(6) The Defence Industry Committee Report On Barriers To Industry Participation In Defence Work was completed in April 1991 and sent to me for consideration and approval on 30 May 1991.

(7) As has been customary for past studies carried out under the auspices of the Defence Industry Committee, a business member of the DIC (the late Bruce Price) acted as Chairman of the study. After Mr Price's death in September 1989, Mr John Hooke, the Chairman of the DIC took over as Chairman of the study. While the actual analysis and drafting of the report was carried out in the Department of Defence, the DIC considered the report and made recommendations to me (these are presented in the report).

(8) Departmental officers, members of the Defence Industry committee and myself have seen the final results of the study. Access to the report is the responsibility of the Chairman of the DIC and will be decided at the next DIC meeting on 16 July. I am still considering the study and will suggest to the Chairman of the DIC that he make a copy available to the Honourable Senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 28 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: How many places in each of the department's labour market assistance programs are currently earmarked for people with disabilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department does not earmark specific numbers of places for people with disabilities within its labour market programs. It does however articulate target groups for its labour market programs, and people with disabilities form one such target group. The policy of the Department is to encourage people from the various target groups to participate in labour market programs at a level which reflects their representation amongst unemployed people. At present it is accepted that people with disabilities form 12.2 per cent of the total unemployed population (Australian Bureau of Statistics--Disabled and Aged Persons Survey 1988). The following information is provided about the number of people with disabilities accessing labour market assistance programs:-

(a) the Australian Traineeship System (ATS)-- the ATS has a target of 15 per cent of all commencements for people from disadvantaged groups (of which people with disabilities is one group). In the period August 1985--April 1991, people with disabilities formed 2 per cent of total ATS participants. This represents:
(b) In 1989-90 15.6 per cent (15,952) of the participants in Employment Access Programs (Jobstart, Jobtrain and Job Search Training) were people with disabilities.

SkillShare--In 1990 8.9 per cent (9,063) of SkillShare participants were people with disabilities. It is expected that there will be a substantial increase in the number of people with disabilities assisted under SkillShare in 1991 as a result of a number of enhancements to the program which relate to people with disabilities. These include:

Funding of $2.5m for the establishment of 10 Disability Access Support Units (DASUs). The role of the DASUs is to provide training and assistance to SkillShare project staff to increase their ability to provide services to people with disabilities;

Funding for 18 Group Focused Projects. These SkillShare projects provide Structured Skills Training for people with disabilities who require more individualised training than is available at a generic SkillShare project; and,

Community outreach module funding for SkillShare projects working to increase the proportion of people with disabilities in SkillShare to a level closer to their representation amongst the unemployed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 29 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to an article by Graeme O'Neill in The Age on Tuesday, 28 May 1991, which claims a cure for certain cancers of the ovary caused by a rise in the reproductive hormone inhibin following menopause, will the diagnostic tests used to detect inhibin in the blood be available for Australian women in the `high risk' category.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The article in The Age referred to above, mentions a research team involving Professor H Burger. Professor Burger and others have received departmental funding through the National Health and Medical Research area for several years for inhibin research. My Department has approached Professor Burger to seek more information on the status of the use of testing for inhibin levels in blood in the diagnosis and follow-up of ovarian cancer. At present, no Medicare benefit is available for blood tests to detect inhibin. Whether a Medicare benefit should be available for the diagnostic tests used to detect inhibin for Australian women in the `high risk' category is a matter on which the Minister would take the expert advice of the Pathology Services Table Committee. The reasons for taking that advice include being sure that such tests have passed the stage of clinical trials and are in fact a worthwhile diagnostic test.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were existing commercial services considered for visits to Thailand by Mr Costello, Deputy Secretary, Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on 16 December 1989, and 27 April 1990 to 2 May 1990; if not, why not; if so, on what basis were they eliminated.
(2) What were the purposes of the visits and who accompanied Mr Costello on each occasion.
(3) What was the nature of the visits which made it impossible for them to be scheduled around existing commercial services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. With regard to the flight on 16 December 1989, a RAAF aircraft flew Mr Costello and Mr McCready (Counsellor, Australian Embassy, Bangkok) from Phnom Pehn to Bangkok. Original plans for travel by car from Phnom Pehn to Ho Chi Minh City and then by Commercial flight to Bangkok had to be changed because of positive developments regarding advancement of Australia's peace initiative on Cambodia. At that time no commercial air service between Phnom Pehn and Bangkok existed. The use of RAAF aircraft was necessary to enable Mr Costello to catch a commercial flight out of Bangkok on 16 December 1989 to keep vital appointments in Beijing.

With regard to the RAAF aircraft flights from 27 April to 2 May 1990, the rapid emergence of prospects of a breakthrough in negotiations initiated by Australia regarding a cessation of hostilities in Cambodia required urgent and reliable travel arrangements for discussions with the Cambodian parties and regional governments. An examination of commercial services at the time showed that these were either not available, or, where services did exist, they were infrequent, unreliable and over-booked, and reliance on them would have made impossible rapid movement between major players to further negotiations on a ceasefire.

(2) The purpose of the visit was to hold discussions with the Cambodian parties and with regional countries in relation to Australia's peace initiative on Cambodia. Passengers accompanying Mr Costello were:
Bangkok/Phnom Penh/Hanoi/Beijing/ Bangkok/New Delhi Mr Waters, Ms Moustafine, Ms Fiebig (all from the Australian Embassy, Bangkok) Bangkok/Phnom Penh/ Hanoi/Beijing/Bangkok

(3) The visits all involved meetings with Ministers and senior officials of regional countries and the Cambodian parties. These meetings were vital to the advancement of Australia's peace initiative on Cambodia. Existing commercial services were used wherever possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 30 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the estimated relative costs to the nation of alcohol, heroin, tobacco and other drug abuses.
(2) What are the relative costs to the taxpayer of the treatment of addicts of these drugs.
(3) What are the manufacturing costs of `nicorettes'.
(4) What taxes, if any, are imposed upon the production, distribution or consumption of `nicorettes'.
(5) By what rationale does the Government maintain disincentives to the use of an effective treatment for nicotine addiction.
(6) Has the Government undertaken any studies comparing the effectiveness of various treatments for nicotine addiction.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Recent estimates of costs to the nation of alcohol abuse and tobacco use are at least $6.03 billion and $6.84 billion per annum respectively. The cost to the nation of heroin abuse has not been specifically estimated. However, the combined costs of the abuse of all illicit drugs has been estimated to be at least $1.44 billion. Estimates of the costs of other drug abuses are not available.

(2) Not known. The actual costs of drug abuse treatment which is provided predominantly by the States and Territories, are met from a complex mix of revenue sourced from their own and Federal taxes. A recent attempt has been made to estimate the impact of drug abuse on the Federal Budget by calculating the excess of government outlays on medical, hospital and accommodation services in association with drug treatment over the revenue derived from the taxes and excise on the sale of these drugs and the income tax revenue forgone as a result of drug-induced premature deaths. The estimated annual impact on the Federal Budget of alcohol abuse is $289.7m, of tobacco use is $104.6m and of illicit drug abuse is $152.6m.
(4) and (5) Federal tax matters are the responsibility of the Treasurer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 3 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to recent reports, including a book by a former CSIRO officer, Mr Dalton, that high tension powerlines may cause leukaemia in children, what information is available to the Government as to:
(1) Whether electromagnetic fields from high tension powerlines have the potential to cause serious health problems, including cancers, for persons living near to them.

(2) Whether the potential health problems in (1) apply only in respect of high tension powerlines above 100 000 volts, or whether health problems may also be associated with powerlines carrying less than 100 000 volts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The possibility that magnetic fields generated by powerlines may be responsible for an increase in cancer incidence is a hypothesis which is receiving consideration among scientists in this country and overseas.

This hypothesis rests mainly on five studies that have reported significant associations between the incidence of cancer and exposure to higher than average residential magnetic fields and on studies of subjects suspected of being exposed to magnetic fields due to their employment. Other residential studies have reported inconclusive results, neither confirming nor disproving the suspected association.
A number of laboratory studies have shown that electromagnetic fields are capable of affecting biological processes although the human health implications are unknown.

The Department of Health, Housing and Community Services through the Australian Radiation Laboratory, is conducting research in this area as well as monitoring and assessing evidence obtained overseas.

(2) If a risk truly exists, it would not be limited to high voltage powerlines. Magnetic fields of the type and strength suspected of being associated with increased cancer incidence are also generated by low voltage distribution lines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since 1985-86 the year the Home and Community Care (HACC) program was established, the total Commonwealth expenditure in Western Australia under the program comprises:

(2) In the first two years of funding (1985-86 and 1986-87), the Commonwealth and State contributions to the program maintained in real terms the 1984-85 level of funding under the four Acts subsumed by HACC legislation. In addition, the Commonwealth made funds available nationally for new projects and the expansion of existing services. In 1984-85 $10m was made available nationally by the Commonwealth for this purpose; in 1985-86 $25m (on a $3 Commonwealth-$1 State/Territory basis; and in 1986-87 $30m (on a $2 Commonwealth-$1 State/Territory basis). In all cases any balance could be rolled-over into the succeeding year.

Since 1987-88, the HACC payments system in each State and Territory has rested on the calculation of a prevailing ratio which is applied to the total of any HACC payment to determine the Commonwealth's share of that payment. The prevailing ratio, then represents the Commonwealth's share of funds available to the HACC program in any year, excluding money which is provided outside the HACC Agreements (e.g the unmatched money from 1987 to 1991).

In 1987-88 the prevailing ratio in each State and Territory was determined on the basis of continuing the relative Commonwealth and State obligations of acquitted expenditure in 1986-87 with the amount of $2-S1 money unexpended in 1986-87 and rolled-over into 1987-88. The prevailing ratio in Western Australia is currently 57.91 per cent.

In the 1986-87 Budget context the Commonwealth provided additional unmatched funds outside the HACC Agreements. The distribution of these funds amongst States and Territories was on a per capita basis to allow equitable distribution, although the original allocations were subject to States and Territories maintaining their effort under the HACC Agreements ie States that indexed their HACC expenditure above the national average benefited to a greater degree than those which indexed below the national average.
The prevailing ratio in Western Australia will increase slightly in 1991-92 when its share of the unmatched funds provided in the 1986-87 Budget context are incorporated under the HACC Agreements.
(b) Unmatched Commonwealth funds provided to the State of Western Australia since the inception of the HACC Program comprise:
The 1985-86 unmatched funds were used to fund new or expanded projects under the HACC Agreement between the Commonwealth and Western Australia.

The Commonwealth unmatched funds provided in the 1986-87 Budget context were part of the Commonwealth's overall strategy to achieve a better balance between residential care and community care. These funds are being used to develop innovative service models which will explore the best ways of matching services to individual needs, as well as the evaluation of those delivery methods. They have been paid in each of the four financial years from 1987-88 to 1990-91. These funds will be incorporated into the HACC Agreements in the 1991-92 financial year.

(4) Since 1987-88 the funds available in any State/Territory have been based on the application of a negotiated indexation factor applied to the previous year's cash outlays. The Commonwealth matches the indexation factor applied by the State or Territory in its Budget context, and provides on the basis of the prevailing ratio, the Commonwealth's share of the State appropriation of total funds for the Program. There is no instance in which money has been unexpended nationally due to a lack of matching in Western Australia.

In particular, these require a Destruction and Removal Efficiency (DRE) of 99.9999% at each facility, in relation to the hazardous component for destruction.
(5) (a) Under Section 17(1) of the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989 (the Act), "the Minister must grant a permit if the Minister is satisfied", inter alia:

Ontario Hydro is expected to replace the Denison contract with purchases from other, lower cost, Canadian uranium producers and Denison is expected to shut down its Elliot Lake mining operations next year. This is a favourable development from the point of view of the Australian uranium industry.

(8) The development of the Koongarra deposit, and other potential uranium mines, is precluded under current Government policy. If that policy did not exist, Denison's ability to meet the Government's stringent requirements would be examined in the same manner as for any other company seeking to develop Australia's uranium resources.

(9) A group of mining companies, including Denison Australia, has been seeking a change to the Government's three mines policy. Joint representations and discussions centred on the policy, not whether approvals should be given or withheld in relation to individual projects.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 4 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Faculty of Business at the Victoria University of Technology, also known as the Footscray Institute of Technology, levy fees on overseas students during their Co-operative Education Year, otherwise known as the Industrial Training Year, when students are physically absent from the campus for the full academic year; if so: (a) how much is being charged; (b) what is the justification for this charge, including an itemisation of the costs involved; (c) are students informed about this charge before commencing their courses; if so, how, and what are they told; (d) do students have a right to decline any service provided in levelling that fee; and (e) has the charge been approved; if not, is the charge regarded as inappropriate or excessive and what action will the Government take.
(2) Is it true that an overseas student may be required to pay this charge even if the Victoria University of Technology cannot secure the student's placement with an employer during that year.

(3) Does the Government approve of the practice of the university to `reserve' placement during the Co-operative Education Year for Australian students only, thereby discriminating against overseas students during their course of study.
(4) Is it true that overseas students have been threatened with expulsion if they do not accept a placement which requires them to return to their home country for their industrial training year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Higher education institutions are self-governing bodies established under State legislation. The Commonwealth has the responsibility to set minimum fees for overseas students enrolling in courses; in this case it is satisfied that given the services provided to students in the year, it is reasonable for the fee for the Co-operative Education Year to be less than the usual minimum indicative fee. The Commonwealth does not have responsibility for, and does not collect information about, aspects of course provision such as those referred to in the honourable senator's question. I am advised that those issues have been widely canvassed by a group of students known as the FIT Overseas Students Collective and that their grievances have been addressed at Institute, departmental and faculty levels with the Victoria University of Technology, as well as on an individual basis. The honourable senator's question should therefore be directed to the Victoria University of Technology.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the current and/or proposed readiness requirements for: (a) major force elements of the Regular Army; (b) major force elements of the Army Reserve; and (c) the Ready Reserve.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The ADF is required to maintain forces at appropriate states of readiness to deal effectively with the types of military contingencies that could arise in the shorter term and to perform peacetime operational tasks.

The operational readiness tasks of the major force elements of the Regular Army include counter terrorist operations, the capability to respond to short warning time credible threats in the defence of Australia and its direct interests, and the provision of assistance to governments of the South West Pacific region.

The operational readiness tasks of the major force elements of the Army Reserve are aligned with longer warning time credible threats in the defence of Australia. These include the protection of vital assets and the maintenance of a base from which Army could be expanded to meet longer term threats.

The operational readiness tasks of the Ready Reserve will be progressively developed. The Ready Reserve will have a vehicle mounted capability, which will enable it to be tasked with reaction operations aligned with medium warning time credible threats in the defence of Australia.
The Army operational readiness tasks I have outlined will not be changed as a result of the recent Force Structure Review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In regard to minimising the adverse effects of commercialisation on the Australian Defence Force readiness and expansion potential, what is meant by the proposal in the report of the Interdepartmental Committee (IDC) on the Wrigley Report to include `performance specifications deriving from preparedness criteria in the contracting negotiations'

(2) With reference to the report on the IDC which observes at the paragraph 44 that `Defence maintains various buffer arrangements to provide a degree of insurance against various unpredictable events', please list and describe these arrangements as they relate to commercialisation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Chief of the Defence Force sets preparedness standards for the Australian Defence Force (ADF) within the framework of his Operational Readiness Directive. This Directive specifies the notice at which given units of the ADF are to be ready for defined tasks and roles in the support of Australia's security.

Preparedness is a force management technique which provides broad performance parameters for the ADF. Defence uses preparedness mechanisms to provide guidance on the increase in number of forces needed for expansion, and the time within which they are required to be ready.
Performance specifications derived from preparedness criteria will be included in contracts to ensure that the operational readiness of ADF elements supported by these activities is not impaired.

(2) Defence has negotiated a number of cooperative logistics support arrangements with Australia's defence partners and allies. The principal arrangements are Cooperative Defence Logistics Support Agreements with the United States and with New Zealand. These arrangements provide assurances of logistics support, which includes the acquisition of defence equipment and services from within the logistics systems of the Defence Forces of these nations, in a range of circumstances during peacetime and in contingencies.

In addition, the Force Structure Review notes that Memoranda of Understanding have been developed with the transport industry to provide agreed arrangements for the use of civil transport resources in times of Defence need (including exercises). They provide a framework for commercial contracts to be raised and implemented quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 June 1991:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 June:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the `element of double counting' in the costing of the Wrigley Report referred to in the Report of the Interdepartmental Committee (IDC) on that report.

(2) Please outline the method by which the IDC arrived at the conclusion that the civilian labour would cost 20 to 25 per cent less than Australian Defence Force labour in performing the same support functions.
(3) Was this costing used to produce the cost `ready reckoner' referred to in the IDC report which will be provided to defence operational managers with which to assess different labour costs.
(4) What information sources were available to the IDC in its evaluation of the costs of the commercialisation/civilianisation proposal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The IDC adjusted downward Mr Wrigley's long term savings estimate of $396m per annum from commercialisation of defence support activities, to remove an apparent element of double counting in savings in Defence indirect costs. These costs relate to personnel providing indirect services, catering etc who were identified elsewhere in the Wrigley Report as direct savings.

(2) The IDC concluded that civilians are approximately 20-25 per cent cheaper than military personnel if account is taken of salaries, superannuation, housing, removal expenses and other personnel costs.

(3) No. The Ready Reckoner has been developed by the Department of Defence using the set of principles for costing and financial analysis, which were jointly developed by the Departments of Finance and Defence as part of the IDC's work. The rates in the Ready Reckoner were developed from Defence budgetary data and relevant award rates. The source of some of the material used in the Ready Reckoner was the Defence Costing Manual and the Department of Finance publication, `Guidelines for the Costing of Government Activities'.

(4) A variety of information sources were used, including official US and UK publications on their commercial support programs, representations from various industry groups, the Defence Costing Manual, information provided by the ADF and presentations by Mr Wrigley, his staff and officials of the Departments of Finance, Defence and the Australian Defence Force.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 6 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the findings of the study undertaken by the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) about 18 months ago, to check the accuracy of the Auditor-General's figures regarding incorrect pensioner/concession numbers in pharmacy claims.

(2) (a) What percentage of incorrect pensioner/concession numbers in pharmacy claims is due to the incorrect inputting of numbers by pharmacists, and (b) what percentage of these incorrect numbers result in people obtaining benefits to which they are not entitled.
(3) What effect would an inaccurate assessment by the HIC of the ratio between incorrectly inputted numbers and ineligible claimants have on the projected savings from eligibility checking.
(4) Will the Minister provide a detailed breakdown of the net and gross savings to be derived from pharmaceutical eligibility checking in 1991- 92, 1992-93, 1993-94, and 1994-95.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)-(4) The study undertaken by the Health Insurance Commission in August-September 1989, was aimed at assessing the level of incorrect payment resulting from the lack of entitlement checking within the program. Prior to this the Auditor-General had referred to major deficiencies in the administration of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme program, including the lack of entitlement checking, but had not quantified the amount of incorrect payment.

The study was undertaken by comparing entitlement information supplied by pharmacists for three months' claims against entitlement information supplied by the Department of Social Security (DSS). Where a valid pensioner/concession number was quoted, the study indicated that approximately 3.5 per cent of the services were found to have no pensioner or concessional entitlement at the date the service was provided. It was also found that some 18 per cent of data was claimed using invalid numbers. This did not necessarily mean that 18 per cent of services were paid incorrectly as it could be assumed that once the correct number was found, the level of error would be similar to that where valid numbers were used.

Later that financial year the Australian Audit Office in its annual audit of the program undertook its own study to evaluate the level of error in the program. That study showed that 5.22 per cent of scripts that were checked against DSS entitlements showed that the person's entitlement had lapsed.

The Commission has taken action to ensure that the number keyed by pharmacists is correct by supplying pharmacy software companies with check digit routines that validate the construction of the number at the time that the number is entered into pharmacy PC systems. Accordingly the use of invalid numbers has no impact on the estimate of projected savings from eligibility checking.

Projected full year savings were calculated assuming an error rate of 4.5 per cent of pensioner and concessional scripts claimed. As the two studies undertaken were not identical in their methodology and as the checks carried out by the Australian Audit Office were conducted on a smaller sample of claims this rate was considered more appropriate for calculating the savings. This rate was then applied to the expected annual volume of pensioner and concessional prescriptions of 72 million and to the expected saving of $12.50 per script, being the difference in the Government benefit for general and pensioner/concessional prescriptions. The estimated saving of $40m represents the full year saving assuming that all pharmacists check entitlements using the interactive system. It would be expected that this would be achieved in 1993-94.

Estimated savings for 1991-92 reflect the assessed benefit to be gained from some level of post payment checking of eligibility which the Commission would expect to begin in September or October. Estimates for 1992-93 reflect the movement towards on-line entitlement checking by pharmacists in this year.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Armed Forces Television and Radio Service

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 6 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the US military requested the Australian Government to exempt it from Australian broadcasting laws so it can directly broadcast US Armed Services Television and Radio to areas surrounding the Nurrungar defence communications base in South Australia.
(2) Would such a service be in competition in the Woomera township area with Imparja, the only Australian commercial service available in the area.

(3) (a) Did the US military at some past date also seek to broadcast to the Exmouth region from the North West Cape communications station; (b) was the plan dropped following strong opposition from the Golden Network; if so, when.
(4) Has the Department of Defence supported this proposal; if so, why.

(5) If the US Armed Forces Radio and Television Service were given permission to broadcast in South Australia, would this: (a) in effect be allowing an unlicensed foreign-owned free-to-air service to operate in the area of a licensed operator; and (b) mean that such a service would not be subject to any of the usual constraints or sanctions, as it would not be licensed under the Broadcasting Act 1942.
(6) Will the Government publish details of the request from the US Armed Forces Radio and Television Service; if not, why not.
(7) When will the Government make a decision on the request, and will the decision be made public; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The US Department of Defense has asked for the advice and assistance of the Australian Department of Defence in developing a system that would make it easier for US personnel stationed at Woomera to receive a satellite TV news service.
(2) No. The nature of the service is such that it would not compete significantly with Imparja or the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in Woomera.
(3) (a) Yes. The US Department of Defense request referred to in part (1) above also included North West Cape because of US personnel stationed at the Harold E Holt Naval Communications Station.

(b) No. The US Armed Forces Radio and Television Service (AFRTS) subsequently indicated that it did not wish to proceed with this proposal until the future of the US personnel at the Station was clarified in the course of management and operational updates being undertaken in conjunction with the transition of the Station to Australian ownership.

(4) Yes. The broadcast will directly support the operational efficiency of the Joint Defence Facility --Nurrungar by contributing to the morale and welfare of the men and women who work there or in the town of Woomera in support of the Joint Facility.
(5) (a) No. The Government has agreed that the broadcast will be undertaken by the Department of Defence.

(b) No. Although the Department of Defence is not presently subject to the provisions of the Broadcasting Act 1942, the Department of Defence has undertaken that the transmission will conform to relevant program standards of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.
(6) Yes. The Government will make an announcement when all details of the service have been finalised.
(7) See the answers to parts (1) - (6) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many people are currently in receipt of (a) sickness benefits; and (b) the invalid pension, due to their having contracted AIDS.

(2) Under the current guidelines, does the department consider those who are HIV positive, but are asymptomatic of the AIDS virus, to be eligible for sickness benefits or the invalid pension; if so, how many people are currently in receipt of (a) sickness benefits; or (b) the invalid pension, even though they are merely HIV positive and their condition is not symptomatic of their having AIDS.

(3) Does the department have a policy of advising those who are HIV positive who lose their jobs, not to apply for unemployment benefits but to apply for either sickness benefits or the invalid pension, even though the prospective client may not have any AIDS-related symptoms.

(4) How many persons are currently, wholly or partly, in receipt of the invalid pension or sickness benefits as a result of being diagnosed as sufferers of (a) soft tissue injuries; (b) stress and stress- related conditions; (c) psychosomatic illnesses; and (d) non-physical injuries or impairment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Social Security computer system does not hold information on the nature of a client's medical condition. Information is not available on the numbers of people receiving sickness benefit or invalid pension because of the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS). However, information derived from a survey of invalid pensioners granted pension between 1 January and 30 June 1988 indicates that 100 grants during this period were to people whose main medical condition was AIDS.

(2) The Department's guidelines on income support for people infected by the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) and those who have acquired AIDS recognise the varying impact of these conditions on individuals' capacity for work. Those who are asymptomatic to the HIV virus usually receive unemployment benefit unless there are unrelated medical factors that would qualify them for either sickness benefit or invalid pension.
(3) The Department has no such policy. Persons in need of assistance who have a capacity for work are paid unemployment benefit.

(4) As the Department of Social Security computer system does not hold information on the nature of a client's medical condition this information is not available. Information, derived from surveys, is available on the characteristics of persons receiving invalid pension or sickness benefit.

The 1988 survey of invalid pensioners granted pension between January and June 1988 indicated that the main medical conditions among invalid pensioners were: musculoskeletal and connective tissue diseases (27.7 per cent) (including disorders of the spine (16.6 per cent)), mental disorders (19.3 per cent), circulatory system diseases (15.0 per cent) and nervous system and sense organs diseases (12.8 per cent).

A 1983 survey of sickness beneficiaries indicated that the most common conditions among male beneficiaries were: spinal conditions (16 per cent), neuroses (10 per cent), heart conditions (8 per cent), amputations and fractures (7 per cent), arthritic conditions (6 per cent), and drug or alcohol dependence (6 per cent). The same survey among female beneficiaries recorded neuroses (14 per cent), spinal conditions (9 per cent), and amputations and fractures (7 per cent) as the most common conditions.

In addition, a survey of long-term sickness beneficiaries in February 1988 indicated that the main medical conditions suffered were: musculoskeletal system (30.6 per cent), mental disorders (21.6 per cent) and injuries and poisoning (18.4 per cent).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 19 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Have there been any claims in the media that child care funding for Defence Force personnel may be cut, if so, by how much and when will the funding be cut.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware of any such media claims. In 1989-90 and 1990-91, a total of $152,013 was spent on childcare through the Family Support Funding Program.

The extension of relief to the parents of children in private centres and work related long day care, which began on January 1, 1991 opens up a range of possibilities to expand the provision of childcare for defence families. These are being actively pursued.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Are any military air traffic control units in Australia to be civilianised or contracted out; if so:
(a) which ones;
(b) when is it likely to go ahead;
(c) what stage has it reached; and
(d) how much is it estimated to save the Government;
if not, has the idea been discussed and discounted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There are no plans to civilianise or contract out any military air traffic control units.

The recent Force Structure Review looked at opportunities for reducing the numbers of service personnel in areas where it considered civilianisation, or a change to commercial support, operationally feasible, practicable and cost effective. The outcome included no change to the present arrangements for the ADF's air traffic control capability.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that the United States Government assured the British Government during the Gulf War that B-52 bombers deployed through the USAF bases at Fairford in Gloucestershire would not carry nuclear weapons.
(2) What are the implications for US warships visiting Australian ports of the US decision to depart from its `Neither Confirm Nor Deny' policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) None. The Australian Government does not require its allies to disclose whether nuclear weapons are on board their visiting warships.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission: Grants

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 20 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What grants have been made by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission for the year l990-91 under the Community Speakers Program which is part of the Government's Community Relations Strategy.
(2) What is the amount and proposed program for each grant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has been provided with the following information by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No grants have been made by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission under the Community Speakers Program during 1990-91.
The Community Speakers Program is not a grant program. Funds for this program will be used to sponsor individual Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander speakers participating in the program.
The program is expected to commence in late July or early August 1991.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 20 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What grants have been made by the Office of Local Government for the year 1990-91 under the Local Government Community Relations Program which is part of the Government's Community Relations Strategy.
(2) What is the amount and proposed program for each grant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Three projects were approved in 1990-91 under the Local Government Community Relations Program. The grants made to these projects in 1990-91 were:
(a) $44,597 to Eyles, Miltenyi and Davis Pty Ltd;
(b) $8,000 to the New South Wales Local Government and Shires Associations; and
(c) $7,650 to the Western Australian Municipal Association.
(2) The total grant amount and proposed program for these projects includes:

(a) $44,597 enabling Eyles, Miltenyi and Davis Pty Ltd to make an initial assessment of a range of strategies for the implementation of the Local Government Community Relations Program. This project provided the OLG with a framework for administering the Program;

(b) $112,850 to the New South Wales Local Government and Shires Associations for the purposes of increasing the understanding, skills and performance of councils through the development of practical community relations strategies.

(c) $60,650 to the Western Australian Municipal Association for the purposes of providing practical advice, and training on community relations issues to councils in a variety of locations throughout the State.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Australian Journal of Chinese Affairs, a publication put out by the Australian National University Research of Pacific Studies' Contemporary China Centre:
(1) Is it correct that in 1989 the Department of Defence raised a purchase order to the value of $30,000 for a subscription to the Journal.
(2) Is it correct that in 1990 the department raised a purchase order to the value of $55,000 for a subscription to the Journal.
(3) Is it correct that in 1991 the department sent a cheque to the value of $6,250 to Ms Dianne Stacey at the Contemporary China Centre for a subscription to the Journal.
(4) Were any of the transactions processed; if so, which ones.
(5) How much has the department spent on the Journal over the past three years.
(6) Is it a fact that a subscription to the Journal costs $20.
(7) What justification does the department have for its apparent expenditure on subscriptions to the Journal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Defence Library in 1989 raised a bulk order for $30,000 for subscriptions for a range of journals and the like. Each of the suppliers is provided with a copy of the bulk order so that they may quote a reference when submitting accounts for payment.
(2) No. The Defence Library raised a bulk order for $55,000 in 1990 to cover subscriptions for a range of Journals and the like.

(3) No. A cheque for $6,250 payable to the ANU for an Army Fellowship, was incorrectly sent to ANU's Research School of Pacific Studies Contemporary China Centre. Payment of that cheque was stopped and a new one forwarded to the correct address.
(4) The only transactions processed were payments for annual subscriptions.
(7) The need to keep abreast of current affairs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 20 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the remarkable success of America's immigration policy 34,000,000 people from all parts of the world entered that country and the fact that the immigrants were the catalyst for a surge of growth that has made America the country it is today, with the example set by the American immigration policy and the success of our migration policies during the 1940s and 1950s, does the Government intend to re-examine its present migration policy to see if a major influx of migrants could have a beneficial effect on Australia's economy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has migration policies in place which are relevant to Australia's needs and which have been the subject of rigorous examination and review. The effects of immigration on the Australian economy are far better understood now than they were in the 1940s and 1950s. One of the reasons for this is the existence of the Bureau of Immigration Research (BIR) which was established by the Government in early 1989 as part of its response to the report of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies (CAAIP).

The considerable amount of research produced by the BIR and by other agencies such as the National Population Council, is taken into account in the formulation of the migration program and policies along with the findings of inquiries such as CAAIP and the results of consultations with Commonwealth, State and Territory government agencies and the community. The views of the Parliament also inform policy development, for example, through the work of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations.

A growing body of research by the BIR has found that, appropriately targeted, immigration confers positive economic benefits on the Australian population, particularly in the longer term. The 1991-92 migration program announced on 30 April 1991 takes this research into account. Our program and policies maintain a balance between economic, social and humanitarian objectives. At the same time they recognise the importance of short and medium term factors such as falling demand for migration to Australia, and current labour market conditions.

The planning levels for 1992-93 and 1993-94 announced at the same time are set in anticipation of an increased demand for migration created by a stronger economy. These levels will be kept under review by the Government, particularly in light of the current inquiry by the National Population Council into the economic, social and environmental impacts of various levels of population growth in Australia through to the year 2030. The Council has produced a discussion paper and will make its final report to the Government late this year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With the planned reduction of armed services personnel, as foreshadowed by the Minister earlier in 1991, will the military fighting strength of the Australian Armed Forces be lowered.

(2) Does Australia have a well-trained, well-armed deterrent force on hand, equipped with the latest high technology weaponry, ships, planes, tanks, guns and navigation devices and is this force sufficient and competent enough to protect the country.
(3) What was the motivation behind scaling down the number of permanent defence personnel.
(4) To what degree is the forces administration to be privatised and what are the likely efficiency improvements to be gained.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. A key principle of the Force Structure Review was to maximise the combat capabilities of the Australian Defence Force.

(2) The Government is developing a force able to undertake current and foreseeable tasks, deal effectively with military pressure arising over shorter time-scales, and provide a suitable basis for expansion to meet higher levels of threat; such a force provides a significant level of deterrence in our strategic circumstances.

(3) Programs for the more efficient use of personnel have been instituted. These include the greater use of reserves, civilians and commercial support, while the number of permanent service personnel involved in headquarters and base support tasks will be reduced to maintain operating levels, and to maintain a significant level of capital equipment and facilities investment across the decade.

(4) The Force Structure Review proposes some 3,900 service and 1,100 civilian positions as the planning figure for reductions flowing from increasing commercial support to the ADF, with an anticipated average saving of 20% of these current staff costs from the commercial support program.
